headline: Arthur J Gallagher & Co., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: So Doug and I have had a friendly argument over the last year, and oftentimes, Doug's response has been, "Look, if somebody wants to sell us our business and they want stock, we're going to give them stock." And now you're saying that, probably, the door'
componenttext: So Doug and I have had a friendly argument over the last year, and oftentimes, Doug's response has been, "Look, if somebody wants to sell us our business and they want stock, we're going to give them stock." And now you're saying that, probably, the door's closed for that in 2016. Can we talk about the change of heart a little bit?

headline: Arthur J Gallagher & Co., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, let me clarify that, is that if we have somebody that really wants our stock, if they need it in a tax-free reorg [ph], we might give it to them, and we'll just buy shares back in the market to keep the share count at level.
componenttext: Well, let me clarify that, is that if we have somebody that really wants our stock, if they need it in a tax-free reorg [ph], we might give it to them, and we'll just buy shares back in the market to keep the share count at level.

headline: Arthur J Gallagher & Co., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: So you're still of mind to do it, but you're not going to dilute shareholders in any stock transaction?
componenttext: So you're still of mind to do it, but you're not going to dilute shareholders in any stock transaction?

headline: Arthur J Gallagher & Co., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, first of all, none of these are dilutive. if we're buying at 7.5x, we don't see that as dilutive. But it is something that we do not see ourselves weighting into stock. If somebody has to have it for a certain structure, then we'll have what -- we h
componenttext: Well, first of all, none of these are dilutive. if we're buying at 7.5x, we don't see that as dilutive. But it is something that we do not see ourselves weighting into stock. If somebody has to have it for a certain structure, then we'll have what -- we have ways in order to minimize the impact on shares outstanding. But I wouldn't consider it to be dilutive.

headline: Arthur J Gallagher & Co., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: All right. And so the -- my other question, as you probably know, what would have to happen for you to think your stock is more attractive than doing acquisitions?
componenttext: All right. And so the -- my other question, as you probably know, what would have to happen for you to think your stock is more attractive than doing acquisitions?

headline: Arthur J Gallagher & Co., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I think you've got to look at it over the long term. I think that, in this case, we really are having success with our smaller acquisition roll-ins. As a matter of fact, we had one deal, one merger, that was $50 million in revenue. If you take that
componenttext: Well, I think you've got to look at it over the long term. I think that, in this case, we really are having success with our smaller acquisition roll-ins. As a matter of fact, we had one deal, one merger, that was $50 million in revenue. If you take that one out, our weighted average multiple's somewhere around 7, 7.2. We see a pipeline right now that is robust. We like our ideas of growing the franchise. When you buy a share of stock back, you don't get trade into London. You don't get using our niches, you don't get organic growth ultimately out of a share of stock repurchased. We still have a lot of opportunities to grow out our franchise, especially here in the U.S. There are cities that we just don't have presence in right now.

headline: Arthur J Gallagher & Co., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, besides, Josh -- let me make a comment, this is Pat. When we do an acquisition, we want a continuing revenue stream and we want an earnings stream, that's a given. But we're putting great resources, terrific people into the company, and that's very
componenttext: Well, besides, Josh -- let me make a comment, this is Pat. When we do an acquisition, we want a continuing revenue stream and we want an earnings stream, that's a given. But we're putting great resources, terrific people into the company, and that's very hard to put a price on. I mean, our pricing folks do a good job of holding the line. As Doug said earlier, we don't dilute our shareholders. But on top of it, these are new producers, these are new teams. You don't do that acquisition and someone else does, it's gone forever. So I've answered this question over 30 years the same way. When we've got a great acquisition partner that we want to put on, I'll buy that all day over buying a share.

headline: Arthur J Gallagher & Co., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: I understand. And then, just on the improved margin outlook for the Risk Management business. Do you feel there's a ceiling to just how good the margins could get on this business? Or can you always find ways to improve it? And even though 17% is a very e
componenttext: I understand. And then, just on the improved margin outlook for the Risk Management business. Do you feel there's a ceiling to just how good the margins could get on this business? Or can you always find ways to improve it? And even though 17% is a very excellent margin, do you think there's an opportunity ever to make that better?

headline: Arthur J Gallagher & Co., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Listen, I think that the great strides have been made over the last 5 years. We've just done a tremendous job of retooling that business. The management team down there is -- and the fact that we're growing organically in the 10% range really shows that w
componenttext: Listen, I think that the great strides have been made over the last 5 years. We've just done a tremendous job of retooling that business. The management team down there is -- and the fact that we're growing organically in the 10% range really shows that we have an offering that we consistently demonstrate better claim outcomes than what their other choices are out there in the marketplace. Where do I see margins ultimately on that business? Not nearly as geared business at the Brokerage segment is. When you pick up a new client, you have to put adjustors behind the desk, and you've got to be ready to handle claims. So we feel comfortable with 17 points of margin right now. We'll take a look at it at the end of this year, see how we do, and we'll either adjust next year or we'll leave it 17% for another year. But that business, it's a scale business, there's great opportunities for it. It's a value-added business, so it's not a commodity. So over time, we'll see where margins ultimately get.

headline: Arthur J Gallagher & Co., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Well, congratulations to both David and Joel on the transition also to RPS.
componenttext: Okay. Well, congratulations to both David and Joel on the transition also to RPS.

componenttext: And our next question comes from the line of Quentin McMillan with KBW.

headline: Arthur J Gallagher & Co., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Doug, thanks very much for the comments [indiscernible]  share repo. I just had a -- all right, not share repo, share -- just maintaining flat shares. Just had a quick question in terms of the stock comp and what you'd be using for a number this year for
componenttext: Doug, thanks very much for the comments [indiscernible]  share repo. I just had a -- all right, not share repo, share -- just maintaining flat shares. Just had a quick question in terms of the stock comp and what you'd be using for a number this year for stock-based compensation growth in the shares. I think you had said at the Investor Day, maybe around $1 million, is that a decent estimate for the year?

headline: Arthur J Gallagher & Co., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. If you look at the back of our investor supplement, we actually have a schedule in there that shows the change in shares outstanding. That's on Page 16 of that supplement. And if you look at the impact that's related to stock-based compensation for e
componenttext: Yes. If you look at the back of our investor supplement, we actually have a schedule in there that shows the change in shares outstanding. That's on Page 16 of that supplement. And if you look at the impact that's related to stock-based compensation for employees, it ends up adding about $1 million, $1.2 million a year in our shares. Now we also have some that lapses off, but by and large, if you assume $1 million a year, that's about right.

headline: Arthur J Gallagher & Co., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: So that's a pretty decent estimate if we're not going to use anything for M&A of what the share growth should be this year, assuming no repurchase.
componenttext: So that's a pretty decent estimate if we're not going to use anything for M&A of what the share growth should be this year, assuming no repurchase.

headline: Arthur J Gallagher & Co., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's right.
componenttext: That's right.

headline: Arthur J Gallagher & Co., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Secondly, just in terms of what your debt addition is going to be and holding that leverage ratio constant. If we look at the midpoint of that $200 million to $300 million, it's at $250 million at a 2.5x times leverage ratio. That implies sort of $1
componenttext: Okay. Secondly, just in terms of what your debt addition is going to be and holding that leverage ratio constant. If we look at the midpoint of that $200 million to $300 million, it's at $250 million at a 2.5x times leverage ratio. That implies sort of $100 million of EBITDAC growth. Is that a fair thought of what you guys are looking for, without being too specific?

headline: Arthur J Gallagher & Co., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, that's right. It might be a little [indiscernible], but that's about right.
componenttext: Yes, that's right. It might be a little [indiscernible], but that's about right.

headline: Arthur J Gallagher & Co., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then, last, if I could just touch on Gallagher Bassett and follow up on what Josh was sort of asking there. You are -- you mentioned that you're investing specifically in Gallagher Bassett, and you mentioned Luminos and other initiatives that yo
componenttext: Okay. And then, last, if I could just touch on Gallagher Bassett and follow up on what Josh was sort of asking there. You are -- you mentioned that you're investing specifically in Gallagher Bassett, and you mentioned Luminos and other initiatives that you have going on. But you also just said the 10% organic growth range. First, do you still think that, that business, in '16 and maybe the foreseeable future, is going to grow kind of that close to double-digits range? And secondly, at that kind of very impressive organic growth, is there still operating leverage in that business? And if not, kind of why won't there be some operating leverage coming through?

headline: Arthur J Gallagher & Co., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, on the organic, or one of the thing about it, when you get into our international operations, there's kind of some stair-step growth that happens with that business. Much of our business in Australia can be in large programs, and so you can see kind
componenttext: Well, on the organic, or one of the thing about it, when you get into our international operations, there's kind of some stair-step growth that happens with that business. Much of our business in Australia can be in large programs, and so you can see kind of flat growth for a year or so, and then also when we pick up a nice big client, it happens. So you get a pop-up in organic. Domestically, I think that we're competing on the -- out there at a terrific range. We think the margins of 17% still allow them to continue to build out their product offering. And the leverage on it is just the fact that this is a still highly intensive people business. And when you get claims, you got to put adjustors on -- behind the desk in order to pay those claims. So we're comfortable with 17% growth, high single-digit type -- 8% to 17% margin, high single-digit organic growth. That's kind of where we feel the business is right now.

headline: Arthur J Gallagher & Co., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: And by the way, I'd comment, I believe that 17% is significantly best in class.
componenttext: And by the way, I'd comment, I believe that 17% is significantly best in class.

headline: Arthur J Gallagher & Co., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, great. And just if I could sneak one more in on there. Just in terms of the way that we think about the business, is a softer rate environment actually a benefit to Gallagher Bassett in some capacity because some of your smaller clients might be loo
componenttext: Okay, great. And just if I could sneak one more in on there. Just in terms of the way that we think about the business, is a softer rate environment actually a benefit to Gallagher Bassett in some capacity because some of your smaller clients might be looking to strip out costs and looking for ways to not have to have those claims adjustors on their own payroll? Or does it net out with something? Where maybe that's not quite the right way to think about it?

headline: Arthur J Gallagher & Co., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, that's not the right way to think about it. What we -- a hard market is a great growth market for Gallagher Bassett because it pushes more clients into the alternative market. They will self-insure. When markets soften, clients will purchase insurance
componenttext: No, that's not the right way to think about it. What we -- a hard market is a great growth market for Gallagher Bassett because it pushes more clients into the alternative market. They will self-insure. When markets soften, clients will purchase insurance at lower levels of retentions and sometimes, that's a headwind for GB.

headline: Arthur J Gallagher & Co., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: By and large, the reason why a client would use Gallagher Bassett is because the claim outcomes on their loss experience are better. That's the [indiscernible]. Anything you think about it, what's the behavior of a client, for a carrier to outsource a cer
componenttext: By and large, the reason why a client would use Gallagher Bassett is because the claim outcomes on their loss experience are better. That's the [indiscernible]. Anything you think about it, what's the behavior of a client, for a carrier to outsource a certain vertical of claim management within -- we do work for carriers, too, is that when they see the claim outcomes that Gallagher Bassett demonstrate, we're paying almost $10 billion of claims through Gallagher Bassett. We have tremendous expertise and we can demonstrate our claim outcomes are better.

headline: Arthur J Gallagher & Co., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from the line of Sarah DeWitt with JPMorgan.
componenttext: And our next question comes from the line of Sarah DeWitt with JPMorgan.

headline: Arthur J Gallagher & Co., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: On the Brokerage organic growth guidance of 2.5% to 3.5% next year, if we look out a bit longer term over the next couple of years, is that a reasonable range to anticipate? Or do you think it could get better? Or do you think it could get worse?
componenttext: On the Brokerage organic growth guidance of 2.5% to 3.5% next year, if we look out a bit longer term over the next couple of years, is that a reasonable range to anticipate? Or do you think it could get better? Or do you think it could get worse?

headline: Arthur J Gallagher & Co., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sarah, I have no clue. If the market goes in the tank -- I've been through 4 cycles. If the market goes in the tank, like it did in [indiscernible] , our organic's going to suffer. If the market tightens, and let's face it, there's some controversy out th
componenttext: Sarah, I have no clue. If the market goes in the tank -- I've been through 4 cycles. If the market goes in the tank, like it did in [indiscernible] , our organic's going to suffer. If the market tightens, and let's face it, there's some controversy out there right now. You've got a little bit of firming going on in places like Australia and New Zealand, got a little bit of controversy with some of our larger trading partners that are having some management issues, and there's some renewed discipline around that. If you get a harder market, 2001 and 2002, significant double-digit organic. So the market makes a huge difference. How we do in new business makes a huge difference. if we keep our retentions, that's a huge -- that makes a -- that plays a huge role, I have no idea.

headline: Arthur J Gallagher & Co., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then I'd also just be curious on your view on the P&C market. How do you think that plays out over the next couple of years? Does it get more competitive? Or are we going to start to see some tightening with the -- some dislocation at large play
componenttext: Okay. And then I'd also just be curious on your view on the P&C market. How do you think that plays out over the next couple of years? Does it get more competitive? Or are we going to start to see some tightening with the -- some dislocation at large players and M&A?

headline: Arthur J Gallagher & Co., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I'll tell you, I've said this many times. I've been very -- I've been pleased and interested to find that over the last 5 years, I would say the PC market globally, and also very much in the United States, is really -- by and large been flat. I mean
componenttext: Well, I'll tell you, I've said this many times. I've been very -- I've been pleased and interested to find that over the last 5 years, I would say the PC market globally, and also very much in the United States, is really -- by and large been flat. I mean, if you go back and look at the charts, starting in about 1970, this market was violently cyclical. You'd have times when rates were going up 30% and 40% and times when rates were falling 15% to 25%. Through the '90s, it was -- it seemed never-ending. Companies kept going broke and prices kept get getting cut. You get through 2001, you have a violent hard market. That softened substantially in '05, '06. But literally, since about '07, maybe '08, this marketplace has been pretty flat. And I would consider the present environment, which is about 4% off on general business to 10% off on large property schedules, essentially, with the exception of that property, 4% off is pretty close to flat when you're used to what I've seen cyclically. So I do predict that management of these carriers today has -- have better information. They absolutely understand loss cost inflation, and they're going to fight hard not to have a deterioration in their returns. So my view is that I think they'll find a way to get that back closer to flat because they need to make money in underwriting to have any kind of return.

headline: Arthur J Gallagher & Co., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Kai Pan with Morgan Stanley.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Kai Pan with Morgan Stanley.

headline: Arthur J Gallagher & Co., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: So first question probably for Pat. In the past, you commented on -- in the stable pricing environment that your ideal for your producer to gain new business, why the retention rate had been stable. But now, with the pricing coming down to mid-single-digi
componenttext: So first question probably for Pat. In the past, you commented on -- in the stable pricing environment that your ideal for your producer to gain new business, why the retention rate had been stable. But now, with the pricing coming down to mid-single-digit level, do you think the buyers' buying behavior -- shopping behavior change that will make it -- would impact your producers, either on the retention side or getting new business?

headline: Arthur J Gallagher & Co., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, I think that it probably helps us with new business. We've got a little bit more of a story to talk about. But again, I would comment that anywhere around 4% to 5% off is a pretty stable market. If I'm doing a good job for a client and I'm sitting dow
componenttext: No, I think that it probably helps us with new business. We've got a little bit more of a story to talk about. But again, I would comment that anywhere around 4% to 5% off is a pretty stable market. If I'm doing a good job for a client and I'm sitting down, talking to them about their renewal and I say, "Look, I think that this carrier has been a good partner for a long time, they've paid their claims, et cetera," and they're willing to come in at 2 points off, I -- my suggestion, as an adviser, is to renew it. You'll renew 90-plus percent of those accounts. So competition is fierce all the time in the business, but if -- in a market like this, I think our story is all about capabilities and about service. It really is about doing a great job on service, doing a great job for the client on the transaction and being a trusted adviser.

headline: Arthur J Gallagher & Co., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's great. Then -- and finally, a larger-picture question is really looking at a -- on the personal side. Basically, you see the direct distribution actually taking share in the marketplace. I just wondered what's your view on the direct distribution i
componenttext: That's great. Then -- and finally, a larger-picture question is really looking at a -- on the personal side. Basically, you see the direct distribution actually taking share in the marketplace. I just wondered what's your view on the direct distribution in the commercial line, especially in the small and middle market commercial distribution, because you heard Berkshire Hathaway started sort of online distribution on the commercial lines. I just wonder what's your -- think the -- both on the challenges side as well as the opportunity side for you guys.

headline: Arthur J Gallagher & Co., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think there's tremendous opportunities in there, some challenges on the small business side. I think a lot of that will be traded electronically. Once you get up to having some real assets, you want a trusted adviser that sits in front of you. That's no
componenttext: I think there's tremendous opportunities in there, some challenges on the small business side. I think a lot of that will be traded electronically. Once you get up to having some real assets, you want a trusted adviser that sits in front of you. That's not changing.

headline: Arthur J Gallagher & Co., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016

componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Dan Farrell with Piper Jaffray.

headline: Arthur J Gallagher & Co., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016

componenttext: Doug, just a quick numbers question. Do you -- and I apologize if I missed this in your comments, do you happen to have the operating cash flow number for fourth quarter? It would seem that cash ended relatively high, so I'm assuming it was up.

headline: Arthur J Gallagher & Co., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: I don't have it here in front of me, but we did show good, strong cash flows in the fourth quarter. If you look at this year, I think, since June -- since September 30 -- I think we're up $120 million in cash compared to where we were at September 30, and
componenttext: I don't have it here in front of me, but we did show good, strong cash flows in the fourth quarter. If you look at this year, I think, since June -- since September 30 -- I think we're up $120 million in cash compared to where we were at September 30, and maybe $180 million more than what we had at the end of 2014. I said that I -- in our balance sheet right now, there's about $275 million of truly free cash in it. So yes, there was strong operating cash flow in the fourth quarter.

headline: Arthur J Gallagher & Co., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: So then, if I look at your balance sheet cash, your conservative assumption of what you'll generate in free cash flow and then your debt raise, that you're looking to potentially do, it would seem that you could not only do the amount of acquisitions that
componenttext: So then, if I look at your balance sheet cash, your conservative assumption of what you'll generate in free cash flow and then your debt raise, that you're looking to potentially do, it would seem that you could not only do the amount of acquisitions that you did last year, but probably exceed that if you saw the opportunity. Is that a fair statement? Or is there anything else that I'm missing there?

headline: Arthur J Gallagher & Co., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, we could exceed the amounts that we did this last year. If we could use all the free cash in our balance sheet, and if we can borrow at 2.5x, the new EBITDAC that we get and our new cash flow, we can do more than what we did last year.
componenttext: Yes, we could exceed the amounts that we did this last year. If we could use all the free cash in our balance sheet, and if we can borrow at 2.5x, the new EBITDAC that we get and our new cash flow, we can do more than what we did last year.

headline: Arthur J Gallagher & Co., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then one other thing. Is there anything with regard to this debt raise, that you're thinking about a little longer term, that positions you for some of the upcoming debt maturities? I know you have one coming up in 2017. Could that -- is it in t
componenttext: Okay. And then one other thing. Is there anything with regard to this debt raise, that you're thinking about a little longer term, that positions you for some of the upcoming debt maturities? I know you have one coming up in 2017. Could that -- is it in the back of your mind, is that part of providing some flexibility potentially around that?

headline: Arthur J Gallagher & Co., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I said that in my comments early, that there -- we have that $300 million tranche that comes due in 2017. We'll look at those -- how things look here in the second quarter, and it might make sense that we pull that -- pull some down. It really makes
componenttext: Yes, I said that in my comments early, that there -- we have that $300 million tranche that comes due in 2017. We'll look at those -- how things look here in the second quarter, and it might make sense that we pull that -- pull some down. It really makes no sense to prepay that, just because of the defeasance cost on that. But it could be one of those things where we pull a little bit down. We may use our line next year to refinance some of that to a lower interest rate, but it is all of the things that we're taking a look at right now.

headline: Arthur J Gallagher & Co., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Our next question comes from the line of Mark Hughes with SunTrust.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Our next question comes from the line of Mark Hughes with SunTrust.

headline: Arthur J Gallagher & Co., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sorry if you got into a little more detail on this previously, but I think you had said your benefits business, you look for more organic in 2016, and I think you had highlighted -- or cited the increase in complexity from ACA. What's more complex this ye
componenttext: Sorry if you got into a little more detail on this previously, but I think you had said your benefits business, you look for more organic in 2016, and I think you had highlighted -- or cited the increase in complexity from ACA. What's more complex this year than last year? And how much more growth do you think you'll get in 2016?

headline: Arthur J Gallagher & Co., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think what's more complex is that the rules just keep being changed and rewritten. You've seen -- just an example, someone brought up the Cadillac tax that everybody was expecting to get started in 2016 has been pushed back a couple of years. That -- th
componenttext: I think what's more complex is that the rules just keep being changed and rewritten. You've seen -- just an example, someone brought up the Cadillac tax that everybody was expecting to get started in 2016 has been pushed back a couple of years. That -- those things just make a -- for a whole nother round of discussions with your clients. You're preparing them, you don't know the answer. If the self-funded part of the individual's cost is calculated into the calculation for Cadillac tax or isn't, that makes a huge difference in what our clients will or won't fund or where they're going to put their employees. And all of a sudden, that changes. So there's stuff that goes on like that, literally, every week. We've got 23, 24 people in our compliance department and the head of that writes an e-mail to all of us, about once every week to 2 weeks, and it's 4 pages long of new updates on what the rules are. So it's -- those complexities just drive a lot more activity for us, and we hope to bill it.

headline: Arthur J Gallagher & Co., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: First of all, our largest location still remains the United States, and my view on the economy in the United States is -- and I'm no economist. But when I talk to our mid-market retail PC and benefit employers, I would not say they're elated but they're h
componenttext: First of all, our largest location still remains the United States, and my view on the economy in the United States is -- and I'm no economist. But when I talk to our mid-market retail PC and benefit employers, I would not say they're elated but they're hiring. Not -- the foot isn't off the break but they are hiring, payrolls are up, unemployment is down. The strengthening dollar certainly doesn't help exports, but it certainly does signify that we've got a pretty darn strong economy in the United States. When I look at Canada, anything that's exposed to energy or natural resources is down, but beyond that and beyond the knock-on effect, Canada seems to be pretty okay. New Zealand is strong. Australia is a bit weak, again, based on the economic impact of energy and natural resources, but not drastically so. And again, we're not exposed to those industries. So I kind of look around and go, where we're playing, we tend to be in a pretty good spot, and the United States seems like it's okay.

headline: Arthur J Gallagher & Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good morning, and welcome to the Arthur J. Gallagher & Co. First Quarter 2016 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] Today's call is being recorded. If you have any objections, you may disconnect at this time. Some of the comments made during
componenttext:
Good morning, and welcome to the Arthur J. Gallagher & Co. First Quarter 2016 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] Today's call is being recorded. If you have any objections, you may disconnect at this time. 
Some of the comments made during this conference call, including answers given in response to questions, may constitute forward-looking statements within the meaning of the securities laws. These forward-looking statements are subject to certain risks and uncertainties that will be discussed on this call and which are also described in the company's reports filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission. Actual results may differ materially from those discussed today.
It is now my pleasure to introduce J. Patrick Gallagher, Chairman, President and CEO of Arthur J. Gallagher & Co. Mr. Gallagher, you may begin.

headline: Arthur J Gallagher & Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Donna. Good morning, everyone. Thank you for joining us for our first quarter 2016 earnings call. With me this morning is Doug Howell, our Chief Financial Officer; as well as the heads of our operating divisions. There are 4 key components to
componenttext:
Thank you, Donna. Good morning, everyone. Thank you for joining us for our first quarter 2016 earnings call. With me this morning is Doug Howell, our Chief Financial Officer; as well as the heads of our operating divisions. 
There are 4 key components to creating long-term value for Gallagher shareholders. Number one, we need to grow organically. Number two, we need to growth through mergers and acquisitions. Three, we improve our quality and our productivity every quarter. And number 4, we have to work hard to maintain a very unique culture. 
We excelled on each and every one of those this quarter. All in, we grew 4.8% organically in our combined Brokerage and Risk Management operations. We had another 6% of growth through net acquisitions for total adjusted revenue growth of 11%. Our quality was recently recognized by J.D. Power and Associates as ranking the highest in customer satisfaction among brokers in the large commercial insurance space. We became more productive with adjusted EBITDAC growth of 15% and we expanded our adjusted margins by nearly 4 percentage points. And our culture was recognized by the Ethisphere Institute as one of the world's most ethical companies for the fifth straight year. Simply put, an outstanding quarter on each component of our strategy. 
So let me spend a little more time on growth, both organic and acquisitions, and what we are seeing in terms of insurance pricing. Doug will then go into greater detail on margins, clean energy and capital management. 
First, in our Brokerage segment, let me talk about organic revenue growth. All in, organic was 4.8%. Excluding contingents, which are seasonally strongest in the first quarter, organic was 4.2%. This is similar to the first quarter of 2015 and up about 1 point relative to the fourth quarter of 2015. About half of this improvement is attributable to stronger new business and about half was due to less drag from rate and exposure. 
Focusing now on our domestic brokerage operations, which include our retail PC Brokerage, retail employee benefits consulting and our wholesale brokerage operations. These units account for about 2/3 of our Brokerage segment revenue. 
Domestically, organic revenue growth was about 4.5%. Of that, retail PC was over 5%; benefits at 4%; and wholesale at a little over 2%. Wholesale is feeling some impact from weaker property rates. 
Commercial PC rates are still down, but they are a manageable headwind and our exposure units are growing a bit. In our employee benefits consulting business, a tight multigenerational labor market combined with rising cost of health care, especially pharmacy costs, along with increased regulations for employers such as the ACA, are creating more new business opportunities. 
In the first quarter, the renewal impact from rate and exposure units has about 0.5 percentage negative impact on our organic growth domestically. So no real change from the past few quarters. I just came back from the conference in San Diego, and the tone from carriers seem to be similar to what we have been hearing for the past 3 quarters, some continued weakness in property. But otherwise, pretty consistent conditions. 
Moving to our international Brokerage operations, that's principally our PC operations in Australia, Canada, New Zealand and the U.K., which combined, represent about 1/3 of our Brokerage segment revenues. Organic revenue growth was about 5% within our international operations. U.K. retail posted about 3% organic and a relatively flat rate and exposure environment. London and Bermuda specially posted about 5% organic in a difficult rate and exposure environment. Australia and New Zealand had a little negative tiding. Otherwise, organic was flat, also in a difficult rate and exposure environment but we're starting to see pricing bottom out in Australia and New Zealand. And Canada posted 6% organic in a flat rate and moderately down economic environment. 
So when you look at our larger international mergers that we did in 2014, they're all doing very well. Integration is done in Australia and New Zealand, nearly done in Canada and should be mostly done in the U.K. by the end of the year. 
Let me turn to merger and acquisition growth. Over the past 20 months, we return to our almost exclusive focus on smaller tuck-in mergers. Today's competitive environment for mergers is similar to last 2 to 3 years, and a lot like most of the early 2000s for that matter. But what we're maintaining our pricing discipline, with weighted average valuations at about 7x EBITDAC for the 8 mergers we did here in the first quarter. We can pay these valuations because the merger partners that choose us see the long-term value in joining Gallagher. They see our vast capabilities, they see our proven track record, they embody our culture and they see themselves being more successful as part of us. 
As I do every quarter, I would like to thank all of our new partners for joining us and extend a very warm welcome to our growing family. 
So to wrap up our Brokerage segment, we posted first quarter results of 4%, 4.8% total organic growth. Total adjusted revenue growth was 12%, adjusted EBITDAC is up 16%, and our adjusted margins expanded by 79 basis points, a really, really strong quarter for our Brokerage segment. 
Let me move to our Risk Management segment, which is primarily Gallagher Bassett Services. Risk Management started the year with a good first quarter. Adjusted organic revenue growth was 4.7%. Adjusted EBITDAC grew 9%, and adjusted margins improved by 103 basis points to 17.6%. Gallagher Bassett continues to deliver consistent, attractive top and bottom line results for shareholders. GB's domestic plans management business delivered 6% organic growth in the first quarter, while international operations were closer to flat, excluding last year's run off fees. At 17.6% EBITDAC margin, we outpaced our margin target of 17%, while continuing to make investments that will drive future growth. 
I spent some time at the Gallagher Bassett booth and I was able to see firsthand how we are positioning ourselves in the marketplace. We have an amazing offering to provide clients. GB, in my opinion, is simply the best. Some of the recent innovations include Waypoint, our suite of decision support tools based on cutting-edge machine learning technology; Luminos, our acclaimed Risk Management information system; and our new GBGO, a mobile application to enhance communication and engagement with injured workers. All these innovations will continue to improve claim outcomes for clients and bring additional revenue to Gallagher Bassett. 
And I don't want to forget to mention our clean energy efforts, another solid quarter still on track to post 15% growth in annual after-tax earnings relative to 2015. So it's a great start to the year. I'm glad to have the first quarter in the books and we really are hitting on all cylinders. Over to you, Doug.

headline: Arthur J Gallagher & Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Pat, and good morning, everyone. Like I said, it's nice to have a terrific first quarter under our belt. I'll make some comments on margins, corporate and clean energy, cash and capital management, and then highlight a couple of things in our inve
componenttext:
Thanks, Pat, and good morning, everyone. Like I said, it's nice to have a terrific first quarter under our belt. I'll make some comments on margins, corporate and clean energy, cash and capital management, and then highlight a couple of things in our investor supplement and CFO commentary documents that we posted on our IR website. 
Okay, first, to margins. Brokerage was up 79 basis points and Risk Management was up 103 basis points, really, really excellent work by the team. What then broke the Brokerage segment, adjusted margin expansion was about equal between our domestic and international operation. Domestic was up 75 basis points. International was up 90 basis points. And recall, our domestic units are running the annualized margins in the high 20s, so to expand here in the first quarter shows excellent discipline. 
Internationally, our Canadian, New Zealand and London and Bermuda specialty units are also posting margins nicely in the 20s. Yet we do have some opportunity to further improve margins in our Australia and U.K. retail units over the next 18 to 24 months. 
In terms of integration, the U.K. team is doing excellent work, and we remain on track to be nearly finished with integration by the end of this year. Integration costs for the first quarter right on our forecast, and we still expect 2016 integration charges to be about half the 2015 level. 
As for Risk Management segment, we exceeded our 17% margin target during the quarter and we still think 17% is a good margin to expect for the next 3 quarters. 
Moving to the Corporate segment. We landed a bit above the high end of the range we provided during our last earnings release, mostly due to clean energy. Most of that was timing. When you look at Page 4 of the CFO commentary document, you'll see the timing between the quarters, yet our full year is effectively unchanged from what we previously provided. So for the year, we are still estimating between $109 million and $124 million of net earnings from our clean energy investments. 
Okay, let's move to cash and capital management. Our first quarter is seasonally our smallest cash generation quarter, yet at the end of the first quarter, we had about $250 million of free cash on our balance sheet. We are working on freeing up about half of it as part of our integration efforts in the U.K. and the other half is in Australia, New Zealand and Canada that we'll use for M&A, merger and acquisition opportunities, in those geographies. 
We also announced a few weeks ago that we renewed and upsized our line of credit facility to $800 million, and we anticipate closing a $275 million debt private placement in early June. 
Our debt-to-EBITDA ratio in March 31 was about 2.6x on a covenant basis, and we're targeting a similar level at the end of 2016. We believe free cash -- we believe between free cash and debt, we can fund our M&A program in 2016, similar to the levels we completed in 2015 with no net shares used. And just to clarify, when I say no net shares used, there will be tax-free reorg mergers that require us to use stock, but we intend to offset that through buybacks, just like we did in the first quarter. 
All right, couple of items on housekeeping. First, please don't forget that our first quarter is seasonally our smallest in the Brokerage segment. Please use the document in our web -- IR website called Supplemental Quarterly Financial Information. We give you 5 years of both reported and adjusted results on a quarterly basis. From that historical information, you can easily see our seasonality. 
Second, we also provide a CFO commentary document on our website that has a lot of forward-looking information that should help you build your models. You'll see that items for the first quarter are in line with the forecast we gave you during our last earnings call. Some looking forward you'll see on that document. Fx headwinds are mostly behind us, integration is tapering off. And this is also now where we're providing all of the guidance related to our clean energy investments that used to be in our earnings release.
So a terrific quarter on all measures, and in the end, we're really well positioned for the remainder of the year. Back to you, Pat.

headline: Arthur J Gallagher & Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Doug. Let's look at our first quarter performance that really was excellent, and I believe we continue to execute on our global strategy. We believe that a key component to our execution is maintaining our culture and we work hard to protect an
componenttext: Thank you, Doug. Let's look at our first quarter performance that really was excellent, and I believe we continue to execute on our global strategy. We believe that a key component to our execution is maintaining our culture and we work hard to protect and promote it. Very proud to be recognized as one of the world's most ethical companies by the Institute for the fifth straight year. This is a testament to who we are as an organization and to the caliber of our colleagues we have at this great company. As we continue to grow and become more global, we are dedicated to keeping our Gallagher culture thriving and strong. Donna, we're ready for questions.

componenttext: I'll tell you, Crystal, we get up every morning and we work really hard on getting the word out that we are the best, we believe, in taking care of clients insurance needs. I think we have an awful lot to offer our customers, and we got a lot of people out on the Street telling people they should be doing business with us.

componenttext: I think the best thing to do as well contingents are significantly skewed towards the first quarter. It encourage you to use the supplement that we have in the website that shows you the trends and supplementals and contingents in the next 3 quarters. And when you're building your models, do some side picks off of that, but you can't extrapolate just off the first quarter, you got to look at this is seasonality that comes with those. But overall, the carriers are recognizing the value that we provide in the process. And so I think that we've got an upward trend in those that might outpace the trend in our base commissions and fees.

componenttext: That's Australia, right. and then in terms of the economic conditions down there. Obviously, Australia has suffered a little bit from lack of exports to China. And then also, there was a rate cutting going on there. So they kind of had 3 headwinds. I believe all 3 of those are turning. I believe there's stability in the marketplace on the rating side. I think economic growth is starting to come back in Australia. I think the sales force is alive and well. We launched a couple of new products down there that are really good in the small business space. So the trend in that we were seeing negative organic growth last year, each quarter and this quarter, we're pushing more towards the positive territory. So really good work by the team down there.

Whether or not they actually closed in the second quarter or third or fourth, every single deal has its own life -- it's all lifespan but we've got a very solid pipeline.

Do you expect any competitive threat from that? I'm just curious thoughts are on that.

headline: Arthur J Gallagher & Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: We're really happy with our position in the U.K. If you remember, just 2 or 3 years ago, we didn't really have a presence in U.K. at all. Today, we're one of the 5 largest players in the market that, that group has come together very well. Rebranding has
componenttext: We're really happy with our position in the U.K. If you remember, just 2 or 3 years ago, we didn't really have a presence in U.K. at all. Today, we're one of the 5 largest players in the market that, that group has come together very well. Rebranding has been done, it's all Gallagher now. You'll recall, it was and Heath. And so we're Arthur Gallagher across about 70 outlets through the U.K. and yes, it's a competitive marketplace just like the United States, Canada, Australia and New Zealand. But we think we compete pretty well.

headline: Arthur J Gallagher & Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016

componenttext: I think it's a nice affirmation of what we saw too that there's good opportunity in the retail space in the U.K. and I think there's a lot of opportunities there that there still some private equity owned firms there that are going to have to do something as time comes up, and I think people realizing better to be with a strategic than an independent or a private equity owned. So we're seeing terrific opportunities there.

componenttext: The marketplace I think is  probably  a little more stable than I thought it was going to be coming into the end of the year. October, November last year, we saw probably a little bit softer market that we're seeing today.  Property is soft, no question about it, especially on the cat side. But probably a little bit more stable market. And I think our closing ratio is up just a bit. We've got a very solid pipeline of new business opportunities and our team is doing very, very well in new business.

headline: Arthur J Gallagher & Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think also, to add to that, the second quarter is our highest property quarter for us. As you look at your models, I don't know if I would necessarily assumed that it will be the same over the next 3 quarters. You might want to caution yourself a little
componenttext: I think also, to add to that, the second quarter is our highest property quarter for us. As you look at your models, I don't know if I would necessarily assumed that it will be the same over the next 3 quarters. You might want to caution yourself a little bit on the second quarter because of the property rates. But also, I think just since November and December, this is a stable environment and I think our clients are having the opportunity to really see the value that we bring. In a stable environment, we outshine a lot of our other smaller competitors, in particular, so when Pat is talking about our hit ratio being better, that's what we're seeing there.

headline: Arthur J Gallagher & Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016

componenttext: Okay. And in terms of Risk Management segment, the organic growth slowed from 4Q. Was there anything specific? And on top of it, the margin expansion was still strong with 100 basis points. So even with the mix in single-digit organic growth in that segment, you can post a strong margin for the rest of the year?

headline: Arthur J Gallagher & Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. To answer your question backward, yes, when mid-single digits, we believe that there's an opportunity to still get our 17% margin targets in each of the next 3 quarters. In terms, of which is expansion over the last year. In terms of what's happening
componenttext: Yes. To answer your question backward, yes, when mid-single digits, we believe that there's an opportunity to still get our 17% margin targets in each of the next 3 quarters. In terms, of which is expansion over the last year. In terms of what's happening on the organic side, if you go back and look at our supplemental over time, there have been some periods where Gallagher Bassett's growth has been in the 5% or 6% range, and then it jumps up to the 10%, 12% range. And the reason why is that as we look at some larger accounts, they typically will in January 1 or July 1 and there are some times where they -- we get them in the pipeline, that's in 2015, helping that they on January 1, but switching over to us can take some time. So we see more new business in July 1 this year, then let's say, maybe in the past we're incepted on January 1. So it's a little bit of a step function type business. Some of these are pretty large accounts. We're seeing a 6% growth in the U.S. Australia is largely flat at this point, but again, there's some good programs that are coming up for proposal over the next couple of years down there.

headline: Arthur J Gallagher & Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016

componenttext: I think that what you're looking at is the headcount on the Brokerage side dropped about 45 heads. This is since the last period. Yes, was 11 acquisitions that might have added 100 or 150. So we're  probably net backwards, largely as a result of our integration efforts. Our productivity initiatives, most of that, we didn't have lay offs, most of that is just through natural exits that happened in the business. But it just shows that we're getting more productive everyday.

headline: Arthur J Gallagher & Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Right, right. Okay. And the clean energy segments, are you seeing volume or just consumption, rather, from coal plants. Is it being affected the low than others stress in the industry, there's bankruptcies, what's the outlook there?
componenttext: Right, right. Okay. And the clean energy segments, are you seeing volume or just consumption, rather, from coal plants. Is it being affected the low than others stress in the industry, there's bankruptcies, what's the outlook there?

headline: Arthur J Gallagher & Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Let me tell you, there's a 3 answers in that question. First, when it comes to the bankruptcies, most of those were in the coal mines go bankrupt, it's usually a holding bankruptcy but the are still operating because they have contracts that they have to
componenttext: Let me tell you, there's a 3 answers in that question. First, when it comes to the bankruptcies, most of those were in the coal mines go bankrupt, it's usually a holding bankruptcy but the are still operating because they have contracts that they have to continue to deliver coal on. And a lot of these utilities have had required to take contracts. So the coal is still moving even to the holding company might be bankrupt anything there's been 5 of them in the last years as they restructure and make themselves more efficient. Second of all, the power plants, as you recall, and when we put our clean energy plants in another power plant, we put them earlier in the dispatch curve, so when we do our plans, these are plans that are more likely to run unless they are less efficient plants that only get dispatched during high peak loads. We are at the mercy of whether. We did have a little bit of a warmer winter that did impact us a little bit. But we still see that we're on track. This program runs through 2021, so long-term displacement of coal to other fuels. It takes a long time to displace some plant. This program goes to just really for another 5 years. And the amount that's displacement that happened over the last 8 years probably is not likely to replete displays to natural gas in the plants that they could, and they really can't move these plans to natural gas that we're operating on efficiently and effectively over the next 5 years. So in summary, I was going to say that I think that we're still well positioned. i still see us having 15% growth in our net earnings this year. we still have other plants that we're working on putting in place that should continue to expand our earnings as you look into the future. So overall, I would say it's a steady state business.

headline: Arthur J Gallagher & Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: And just a macro question. Pat, you're good in talk about the environment and what implications of big companies mean. Was there like an AIG retrenching and indicating that volume is not an objective and underwriting is. And they're going to write less bu
componenttext: And just a macro question. Pat, you're good in talk about the environment and what implications of big companies mean. Was there like an AIG retrenching and indicating that volume is not an objective and underwriting is. And they're going to write less business today. and with going through a big merger, we've got 3 of the very big players in some state of transition. Does that have any positive implication to the environment, maybe a reason why you're a little bit more optimistic about organic for the year or is it all just execution versus macro?

headline: Arthur J Gallagher & Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think, Bob, for us, it is more execution than it is macro. Those are big trading partners for us. In each instance, we've got deep, very meaningful relationships with each of them. Each have their own issues that they're dealing, with but our trading re
componenttext: I think, Bob, for us, it is more execution than it is macro. Those are big trading partners for us. In each instance, we've got deep, very meaningful relationships with each of them. Each have their own issues that they're dealing, with but our trading relationship is very strong and continues to grow with all 3 of them. So it's really not those 3 driving the market. I think really, we know that 90% of the time, when we compete, we compete with a player who's smaller than we are. In our 32 in, the United States, our 32 areas of focus our verticals are very strong. We know those businesses and we think we're probably tougher than anybody in any of those. And our new business is very strong.

headline: Arthur J Gallagher & Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016

headline: Arthur J Gallagher & Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I think -- what I've been impressed with over the last 5 years is we've had ups and downs in various lines of coverage. They've gone soft or hard, depending on what those lines of coverage need. But over the last 5 years, we've seen more discipline o
componenttext: Yes. I think -- what I've been impressed with over the last 5 years is we've had ups and downs in various lines of coverage. They've gone soft or hard, depending on what those lines of coverage need. But over the last 5 years, we've seen more discipline on the underwriting side than I have in my 40-year career. And I think that remains. I think property, catastrophe property clients deserve a decrease, the wind hasn't blown, so there should be no shock to anybody that kept properties off. When you take a look at workers' compensation, depending on the geography, the state, what have you, what it needs to go up, goes up a bit, when it needs to come down, it comes down a bit. same sort of things so what we're seeing is many cycles within the lines of coverage based on what really needs to happen to those lines. And I think that's a level of discipline that the industry has enjoyed for 5 years that I've seen before. So I think it's probably some of that, Bob. Those 3 companies have issues that they're dealing with. But by enlarge, they're trading on The Street, they're doing very well.

componenttext: No. It say pricing is relatively stable. The, at any account, you can go into an of our offices and go to a sales meeting, and you're going to hear a story of getting a 25% decrease. I mean, it's not -- you can have an account that gets knocked down big time. But by enlarge, when you look across the entire platform, it's pretty stable situation with the exception of the property business and to some of the degree, transportation.

componenttext: Doug, just to talk about moderate quick. It was stronger in the quarter in terms of tax utilization. I'm assuming is just because of the stronger earnings that you had in what is sort of a seasonally weaker earnings quarter for you. First, is that the correct way to think about it? And then secondly, and I apologize for asking this is a long-dated question. But do you guys have a sort of a plan for post-chem-mod tax credits in 2021, 2023 time frame of what you may want to do to recover that, that strategy?

headline: Arthur J Gallagher & Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: First question, yes, it was. Because we had a stronger first quarter that, that caused us to recognize a little bit more when you had more organic growth, you have more earnings and therefore, you recognize a little more tax credits, so that's the first o
componenttext: First question, yes, it was. Because we had a stronger first quarter that, that caused us to recognize a little bit more when you had more organic growth, you have more earnings and therefore, you recognize a little more tax credits, so that's the first one. Longer term, i think even we talked about the end of this program to generate credits being expiring in 2021, our plan is to hit the end of 2021 with a long glide path of having a balance sheet with a substantial amount of credits in it that can continue to reduce our tax rate well into the 2020s. So even though generation phase may be over, in 2021, the actually utilization of credits should go on. I think right now, we have about $375 million that's in our balance sheet right now. We're using about $100 million a year. I'd like to have a 5 or 7-year balance sheet at a time we hit that point. So I think that -- no, what do we have as opportunities after the we thought at the end of section 29, which was the precursor to section 45 credits that we were done. There's something else that the government does in order to foster tax credits. because the government really understands that better energy is a good policy. And therefore, they want to commercial enterprises to go out and develop new technologies to better the environment. So I think there could be another program after 2021 but we've got 5 years to work on that. In terms of our cash generation, look at this as well into the 20s.

Just from natural attrition and this is I believe we naturally getting better every day.

headline: Arthur J Gallagher & Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good morning, and welcome to the Arthur J. Gallagher & Co.'s First Quarter 2016 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] Today's call is being recorded. If you have any objections, you may disconnect at this time.Some of the comments made durin
componenttext:
Good morning, and welcome to the Arthur J. Gallagher & Co.'s First Quarter 2016 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] Today's call is being recorded. If you have any objections, you may disconnect at this time.
Some of the comments made during this conference call, including answers given in response to questions, may constitute forward-looking statements within the meaning of the security laws. These forward-looking statements are subject to risks and uncertainties that will be discussed on this call and which are also described in the company's reports filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission. Actual results may differ materially from those discussed today.
It is now my pleasure to introduce J. Patrick Gallagher, Chairman, President and CEO of Arthur J. Gallagher & Co. Mr. Gallagher, you may begin.

headline: Arthur J Gallagher & Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Donna. Good morning, everyone. Thank you for joining us for our first quarter 2016 earnings call. With me this morning is Doug Howell, our Chief Financial Officer; as well as the heads of our operating divisions. There are 4 key components to
componenttext:
Thank you, Donna. Good morning, everyone. Thank you for joining us for our first quarter 2016 earnings call. With me this morning is Doug Howell, our Chief Financial Officer; as well as the heads of our operating divisions. 
There are 4 key components to creating long-term value for Gallagher's shareholders. Number one, we need to grow organically. Number two, we need to grow through mergers and acquisitions. Three, we improve our quality and our productivity every quarter. And number four, we have to work hard to maintain a very unique culture.
We excelled on each and every one of those this quarter. All in, we grew 4.8% organically in our combined Brokerage and Risk Management operations. We had another 6% of growth through net acquisitions for total adjusted revenue growth of 11%. Our quality was recently recognized by J.D. Power and Associates as ranking the highest in customer satisfaction among brokers in the large commercial insurance space. We became more productive with adjusted EBITDAC growth of 15% and we expanded our adjusted margins by nearly 4 percentage points. And our culture was recognized by the Ethisphere Institute as one of the world's most ethical companies for the fifth straight year. Simply put, an outstanding quarter on each component of our strategy. 
So let me spend a little more time on growth, both organic and acquisitions, and what we are seeing in terms of insurance pricing. Doug will then go into greater detail on margins, clean energy and capital management. 
First, in our Brokerage segment, let me talk about organic revenue growth. All in, organic was 4.8%. Excluding contingents, which are seasonally strongest in the first quarter, organic was 4.2%. This is similar to the first quarter of 2015 and up about a point relative to the fourth quarter of 2015. About half of this improvement is attributable to stronger new business and about half was due to less drag from rate and exposure. 
Focusing now on our domestic brokerage operations, which include our retail PC brokerage, retail employee benefits consulting and our wholesale brokerage operations. These units account for about 2/3 of our Brokerage segment revenue. 
Domestically, organic revenue growth was about 4.5%. Of that, retail PC was over 5%; benefits at 4%; and wholesale at a little over 2%. Wholesale is feeling some impact from weaker property rates.
Commercial PC rates are still down, but they are a manageable headwind and our exposure units are growing a bit. In our employee benefits consulting business, a tight multigenerational labor market, combined with rising cost of health care, especially pharmacy costs, along with increased regulations for employers such as the ACA, are creating more new business opportunities. 
In the first quarter, the renewal impact from rate and exposure units had about 0.5 percentage negative impact on our organic growth domestically. So no real change from the past few quarters. I just came back from the RIMS Conference in San Diego, and the tone from carriers seem to be similar to what we have been hearing for the past 3 quarters, some continued weakness in property, but otherwise, pretty consistent conditions.
Moving to our international brokerage operations, that's principally our PC operations in Australia, Canada, New Zealand and the U.K., which combined, represent about 1/3 of our Brokerage segment revenues. Organic revenue growth was about 5% within our international operations. U.K. retail posted about 3% organic and a relatively flat rate and exposure environment. London and Bermuda, especially, posted about 5% organic in a difficult rate and exposure environment. Australia and New Zealand had a little negative tiding. Otherwise, organic was flat, also in a difficult rate and exposure environment, but we're starting to see pricing bottom out in Australia and New Zealand. And Canada posted 6% organic in a flat rate and moderately down economic environment.
So when you look at our larger international mergers that we did in 2014, they're all doing very well. Integration is done in Australia and New Zealand, nearly done in Canada and should be mostly done in the U.K. by the end of the year. 
Let me turn to merger and acquisition growth. Over the past 20 months, we return to our almost exclusive focus on smaller tuck-in mergers. Today's competitive environment for mergers is similar to the last 2 to 3 years, and a lot like most of the early 2000s, for that matter. But we're maintaining our pricing discipline, with weighted average valuations at about 7x EBITDAC for the 8 mergers we did here in the first quarter. We can pay these valuations because the merger partners that choose us see the long-term value in joining Gallagher. They see our vast capabilities, they see our proven track record, they embody our culture and they see themselves being more successful as part of us. 
As I do every quarter, I would like to thank all of our new partners for joining us and extend a very warm welcome to our growing family. 
So to wrap up our Brokerage segment, we posted first quarter results of 4%, 4.8% total organic growth. Total adjusted revenue growth was 12%, adjusted EBITDAC is up 16%, and our adjusted margins expanded by 79 basis points, a really, really strong quarter for our Brokerage segment.
Let me move to our Risk Management segment, which is primarily Gallagher Bassett Services. Risk Management started the year with a good first quarter. Adjusted organic revenue growth was 4.7%. Adjusted EBITDAC grew 9% and adjusted margins improved by 103 basis points to 17.6%. Gallagher Bassett continues to deliver consistent, attractive top and bottom line results for shareholders. GB's domestic claims management business delivered 6% organic growth in the first quarter, while international operations were closer to flat, excluding last year's run-off fees. At 17.6% EBITDAC margin, we outpaced our margin target of 17%, while continuing to make investments that will drive future growth.
I spent some time at the Gallagher Bassett booth at RIMS, and I was able to see firsthand how we are positioning ourselves in the marketplace. We have an amazing offering to provide clients. GB, in my opinion, is simply the best. Some of the recent innovations include Waypoint, our suite of decision support tools based on cutting-edge machine learning technology; Luminos, our acclaimed Risk Management information system; and our new GBGO, a mobile application to enhance communication and engagement with injured workers. All these innovations will continue to improve claim outcomes for clients and bring additional revenue to Gallagher Bassett. 
And I don't want to forget to mention our clean energy efforts, another solid quarter still on track to post 15% growth in annual after-tax earnings relative to 2015. So it's a great start to the year. I'm glad to have the first quarter in the books and we really are hitting on all cylinders. Over to you, Doug.

headline: Arthur J Gallagher & Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Pat, and good morning, everyone. Like he said, it's nice to have a terrific first quarter under our belt. I'll make some comments on margins, corporate and clean energy, cash and capital management, and then highlight a couple of things in our inv
componenttext:
Thanks, Pat, and good morning, everyone. Like he said, it's nice to have a terrific first quarter under our belt. I'll make some comments on margins, corporate and clean energy, cash and capital management, and then highlight a couple of things in our investor supplement and CFO commentary documents that we posted on our IR website. 
Okay, first, to margins. Brokerage was up 79 basis points and Risk Management was up 103 basis points, really, really excellent work by the team. Within the Brokerage segment, adjusted margin expansion was about equal between our domestic and international operation. Domestic was up 75 basis points, International was up 90 basis points. And recall, our domestic units are running annualized margins in the high 20s, so to expand here in the first quarter shows excellent discipline. 
Internationally, our Canadian, New Zealand and London and Bermuda specialty units are also posting margins nicely in the 20s. Yet we do have some opportunity to further improve margins in our Australia and U.K. retail units over the next 18 to 24 months.
In terms of integration, the U.K. team is doing excellent work, and we remain on track to be nearly finished with the integration by the end of this year. Integration costs for the first quarter were right on our forecast, and we still expect 2016 integration charges to be about half the 2015 level.
As for Risk Management segment, we exceeded our 17% margin target during the quarter and we still think 17% is a good margin to expect for the next 3 quarters.
Moving to the Corporate segment. We landed a bit above the high end of the range we provided during our last earnings release, mostly due to clean energy. Most of that was timing. When you look at Page 4 of the CFO commentary document, you'll see the timing between the quarters that our full year is effectively unchanged from what we've previously provided. So for the year, we are still estimating between $109 million and $124 million of net earnings from our clean energy investments.
Okay, to cash -- let's move to cash and capital management. Our first quarter is seasonally our smallest cash generation quarter, yet at the end of the first quarter, we had about $250 million of free cash on our balance sheet. We are working on freeing up about half of it as part of our integration efforts in the U.K. and the other half is in Australia, New Zealand and Canada that we'll use for M&A, merger and acquisition opportunities, in those geographies. 
We also announced a few weeks ago that we renewed and upsized our line of credit facility to $800 million, and we anticipate closing a $275 million debt private placement in early June. 
Our debt-to-EBITDA ratio on March 31 was about 2.6x on a covenant basis, and we're targeting a similar level at the end of 2016. We believe free cash and -- we believe between free cash and debt, we can fund our M&A program in 2016, similar to the levels we completed in 2015, with no net shares used. And just to clarify, when I say no net shares used, there will be tax-free reorg mergers that require us to use stock, but we intend to offset that through buybacks, just like we did in the first quarter. 
All right, a couple of items on housekeeping. First, please don't forget that our first quarter is seasonally our smallest in the Brokerage segment. Please use the document in our web -- IR website called Supplemental Quarterly Financial Information. We give you 5 years of both reported and adjusted results on a quarterly basis. From that historical information, you can easily see our seasonality.
Second, we also provide a CFO commentary document on our website that has a lot of forward-looking information that should help you build your models. You'll see that items for the first quarter are in line with the forecast we gave you during our last earnings call. 
Some soundbites looking forward that you'll see on that document. FX headwinds are mostly behind us, integration is tapering off, and this is also now where we're providing all of the guidance related to our clean energy investments that used to be in our earnings release.
So a terrific quarter on all measures and we're -- and in the end, we're really well positioned for the remainder of the year. Back to you, Pat.

headline: Arthur J Gallagher & Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Doug. Let's look at our first quarter performance that really was excellent, and I believe we continue to execute on our global strategy. We believe that a key component to our execution is maintaining our culture and we work hard to protect an
componenttext:
Thank you, Doug. Let's look at our first quarter performance that really was excellent, and I believe we continue to execute on our global strategy. We believe that a key component to our execution is maintaining our culture and we work hard to protect and promote it. We're very proud to be recognized as one of the world's most ethical companies by the Ethisphere Institute for the fifth straight year. This is a testament to who we are as an organization and to the caliber of colleagues we have at this great company. As we continue to grow and become more global, we're dedicated to keeping our Gallagher culture thriving and strong. 
Donna, we're ready for questions.

headline: Arthur J Gallagher & Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
