headline: Arthur J Gallagher & Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good morning, and welcome to the Arthur J. Gallagher & Co.'s Second Quarter 2016 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] Today's call is being recorded. If you have any objections, you may disconnect at this time.Some of the comments made duri
componenttext:
Good morning, and welcome to the Arthur J. Gallagher & Co.'s Second Quarter 2016 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] Today's call is being recorded. If you have any objections, you may disconnect at this time.
Some of the comments made during the conference call, include forward -- including answers given in response to questions, may constitute forward-looking statements within the meaning of the securities laws. These forward-looking statements are subject to certain risks and uncertainties that will be discussed on this call and which are also described in the company's reports filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission. Actual results may differ materially from those discussed today.
In addition, for a consolation for the non-GAAP measures discussed in this call as well as any other information regarding of these measures, please refer to the most recent earnings release and any other materials in the Investor Relations section of the company's website.
It is now my pleasure to introduce J. Patrick Gallagher, Chairman, President and CEO of Arthur J. Gallagher & Co. Mr. Gallagher, you may begin

headline: Arthur J Gallagher & Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Donna. Good morning, everyone. Thank you for joining us for our second quarter 2016 earnings call. With me this morning is Doug Howell, our Chief Financial Officer; as well as the heads of our operating divisions.Today, we are going to touch
componenttext:
Thank you, Donna. Good morning, everyone. Thank you for joining us for our second quarter 2016 earnings call. With me this morning is Doug Howell, our Chief Financial Officer; as well as the heads of our operating divisions.
Today, we are going to touch on 4 key components of our strategy to drive shareholder growth: Organic growth; merger growth; improving our quality and productivity, which Doug will spend most of his time on; and fourth, maintaining our unique culture. We have excelled on all 4 year to date.
First, let me talk about organic growth. In our Brokerage segment, after a terrific first quarter of 4.8% organic growth, we posted 2.2%, but that was marked by the loss of a large account that we discussed at our June investor meeting. Excluding the large account, we would have been closer to 2.5%. So for the first half, Brokerage organic was 3.6%, which in retrospect is darn good based on how it felt coming to the year, especially in this environment.
Looking towards the second half of year, I see our organic summer between our second quarter year to date numbers so I see an improvement going forward. Let me
break down our organic around the world. I'm extremely pleased every single division posted positive organic growth in the quarter. Our sales culture is alive and well. Domestically, in the United States, we saw about 3% organic growth. Late in exposure had little over a point of negative impact on its domestic PC renewal results in the second quarter. Most of that was property, which for us, is proportionally higher in our second quarter.
Domestic casualty lines pricing remains similar to last year, where we are seeing a slight downward pressure and we are seeing a modest growth in exposure units overall. This remains an environment where our production teams can grow and outperform.
Our domestic employee benefit consulting business also posted about 3% organic and we're seeing a tremendous amount of new business opportunities. Our teams are showing new prospects are vast array of services, tools and insights that they need to navigate a tight multigenerational labor market, rising health-care costs and increasing regulatory complexities related to the ACA. Our smaller competitors are falling behind each and everyday. This business typically grows more in the second half of the year and it seems to me that, that will be the case again this year.
Let me move to our international brokerage operations. Since our last call, I spent a significant up Australia, Canada, New Zealand and the U.K. These teams are doing great. In fact, they're on a roll. After just 24 months of being part of the Gallagher family, I'm really pleased with how well we are working together, how our sales plans are becoming integrated and how our culture is thriving. Altogether, ex the 1 large account, our international operations posted about 2% organic growth in the second quarter, even with rates and exposures that are softer internationally than we seek here domestically. I'm pleased that our teams are growing through those headwinds and the results are solid. As a side note, it was really interesting being in the U.K. and Europe during Brexit. Remember, we don't have much business at all for mainland Europe, and insurance is not flowing in and out London for over 300 years, long before the EU is formed. So other than a possible recession hitting the U.K. and the other EU countries, and your guest but that is about as good as mine, I don't see it as a worse of event for us in the near term. Longer-term, I think we and the industry will successfully navigate any potential changes to the European insurance landscape.
Next, let me move to merger and acquisition growth. Over the past 2 years, our focus on smaller tuck-in mergers. The average size for the 13 acquisitions this quarter was $3 million of revenue and an average of 7x EBITDAC. So we're still finding with a good opportunities at fair prices and the comparative merger environment. Year-to-date, 21 acquisitions, which should add about $70 million of annualized revenue. And we see a stronger second half of the year for our acquisitions, our pipeline is outstanding. There are a lot of really talented individual sales and consulting professionals out there. They have excellent relationships with their clients, they have strong sales skills and they have a very strong entrepreneurial bend, they create value by joining Gallagher with their full access to our capabilities, expertise and resources.
I said for 30 years, pick your partners that have a culture similar to Gallagher and look out. One plus 1 together does make 3, 4 and 5. I'd like to thank all of our new partners for joining us, and I extend a very warm welcome to our growing Gallagher family professionals.
So to wrap up my comments on the Brokerage segment, halfway through the year, we posted 10% total revenue growth, of which 3.6% is organic. Adjusted EBITDAC growth of 13%, adjusted EBITDAC margin expansion of 60 basis points, integration costs are starting to wind down now and we have an excellent M&A pipeline at fair multiples. Truly excellent results for the first half.
Next, I'd like to move to our Risk Management segment, which is primarily Gallagher Bassett. Risk Management had a more challenging organic quarter, but I'm really pleased that we proactively manage expenses and exceeded our 17% margin target. Second quarter organic was challenged for 3 reasons. First, as we discussed at our Investor Day, we are seeing a bit of a wall in new business inception dates. Second, we express fewer new claims in the final few much of the quarter within the U.S. And third, we recently learned that we are not likely to earn a lot of performance bonus award from our participation in our Australian work over program where we are 1 of 5 provide us. For the fiscal year ended June 30, the program paid performance fees using 30 different criteria and several the metrics had a big stretch. Unfortunately, we fell short. And you'll see in the organic table on Page 6 of the earnings release that we're nothing near in the second quarter in 2016. We believe the other providers fell short too, but let me be clear, I'm disappointed. Going forward, we will return to positive organic growth in the third and fourth quarter. Our client value proposition of delivering superior claim outcomes is stronger than ever. In fact, we have recently we did a big program in Australia at 2 nice new business wins, 1 in Australia, 1 in the U.K., and our domestic new business pipeline is solid.
Let me move to clean energy. Once again, we had a great quarter. The Corporate segment earnings came in above the midpoint of the guidance range we previous provided. We're well on our way to delivering nearly 15% growth in annual after-tax earnings.
Lastly, on our culture. Over the past 3 months, as I said, I have visited the U.K, Canada, Australia and New Zealand. I can tell you that our unique Gallagher culture is thriving and strong across our entire global footprint. This includes the over 300 promising college students globally learning about the greatest business on Earth in our internship program. We're just wrapping up the 51st year of the Gallagher summer intern program. We believe the 2-month program is an important investment in our future as we like growing our own.
So we have delivered an excellent first half of the year, the fundamentals of our business remains strong and we think the second half will even be a bit stronger. Over to you Doug.

headline: Arthur J Gallagher & Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: All right. Thanks, Pat, and good morning, everyone, Today, I'll do some earnings release housekeeping, spend some time in our quality productivity and margins, I'll hit on integration, highlight some clean energy items and then wrap up with some comments
componenttext:
All right. Thanks, Pat, and good morning, everyone, Today, I'll do some earnings release housekeeping, spend some time in our quality productivity and margins, I'll hit on integration, highlight some clean energy items and then wrap up with some comments on cash and capital management. Okay, to the housekeeping. You'll see that you made changes to our earnings real ease. We did so because in May, the SEC published new guidance on the presentation of non-GAAP measures and we believe we've now gone the additional mile in the spirit of new guidance. It makes the table a little busy but the punchline here is that we have not removed any of our previous disclosures as we strive to remain as transparent as possible. Also, please recall that many of my more forward-looking statements today can be found on the document called CFO commentary that we have posted in our investor website.
All right, let me turn to margins, which are a nice indicator, in my opinion, of our quality and productivity. Brokerage adjusted EBITDAC margins are up 57 basis points and Risk Management margin came in at above our 17% adjusted margin target. Year-to-date, our margins have expanded in both Brokerage by 60 basis points and Risk Management by 33 basis points. That's really terrific work by the team out there. Within the Brokerage segment, margin expansion came mostly from our international operations. We call that we believe there's an opportunity to expand margins in our Australia and U.K. retail businesses over the next couple of years. And we made good progress on that -- this last quarter asked our margin improvement initiatives have kicked in. Let me give you a couple of examples. First, we moved all of our transaction accounting out of London into Glasgow I want it to be clean it up in Glasgow, we then shipped the work into our offshore centers of [indiscernible] which is really following the blueprint that we built here in the USA over the last 10 years, which allows us to as we bring new entities on to move faster than ever before. Second is another example in the U.K. Our retail team standard escort service related processes such as endorsement, coding and renewals across our 50-plus branches. And in Australia, we've started consolidating our SME business from 25-plus branches into a few specialized centers that will focus on just a small customers. All this all work has driven down our back and middle of us cost as we can capitalize on our scale and [ph] three, what's even more exciting is we've dramatically improved the quality of our services and our customer experience. Everyday, our folks that work in the middle and back office get up to be better, faster and wiser on how we spend money.
Let me comment specifically also on integration. And recall that we did 5 large deals in late 2013 and early 2014, and we're nearly finished integration. I was in the U.K. a few weeks ago and the efforts to wrap up are impressive. And I was in Canada in May, and by the end of this year, we will migrate nearly all of the 6 or 7 business units onto a the same agency management system we use here in the USA. Second quarter integration costs were right on our forecast of $0.05 a share. About half of last year's amount. And you'll see on the CFO commentary sheet that we're anticipating about $0.06 to $0.07 total in the last half of 2016 in integration cost, which is down dramatically from the $0.21 we spent in the last half of 2015. So our efforts are well on track to be down by early 2017.
Let me turn to the Risk Management segment, Gallagher Bassett. Over the last several years, we have been improving our service offering to deliver better claim outcomes. Much of the back-office improvement is very similar to what we have done in the Brokerage segment. But in addition, we have improved the tools on our issues such as automating manual and high-volume processes that are really necessary to do a great job but frankly, can bog our folks down. We've also shifted nearly 1,000 associates into work-from-home locations and we developed some specialized centers to focus on comp works specialized case management. These efforts have allowed us to improve our margins in the Risk Management segment over the last couple of years and showed a lot of us the post margins for the year in the neighborhood of 17.5%, which is up from our previous target of 17%.
Shifting to the Corporate segment. We landed a [indiscernible] above the midpoint of our guidance that we provided during our investor meeting in June. Most of this was due to better clean energy earnings because our plans ran ahead of plan in June due to hot weather that hit various parts of the country. We're still forecasting between $110 million to $120 million of net earnings for the year.
First off was a little stronger for the full year should be about where we estimated 6 months ago. It's also important to note that by the end of the year, we will have over $400 million of credits on our balance sheet, effectively, that's a $400 million receivable from the government that will help us reduce our cash taxes paid for many years. As for cash, we've got about $150 million of available cash on our balance sheet and we're making really good progress in our U.K. bank account consolidation efforts to unlock available cash that we talked about before. I think that we're down about 30% in the number of open bank accounts since the beginning of the year.
As for stock. We use no net shares for M&A this quarter and we actually bought some shares back during the Brexit market selloff. We will use those shares for future tax exchange mergers coming up this year. So when you look back, we haven't used any net shares to do M&A in over a year, and I think we can fund deals with cash and debt through year end.
So those are my comments. I think it was an excellent first half of the year. Back to you Pat.

headline: Arthur J Gallagher & Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Doug. Donna, we'll take some questions and answers now.
componenttext: Thank you, Doug. Donna, we'll take some questions and answers now.

headline: Arthur J Gallagher & Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Our first question is coming from Elyse Greenspan of Wells Fargo.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Our first question is coming from Elyse Greenspan of Wells Fargo.

headline: Arthur J Gallagher & Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: I was hoping to spend a little bit, get a little bit more color on your organic growth outlook that you provided for the second half of the year, that kind of in a range, I guess of 2.5% to 3.5% or so given the Q2 and half-year warm levels. How do you see
componenttext: I was hoping to spend a little bit, get a little bit more color on your organic growth outlook that you provided for the second half of the year, that kind of in a range, I guess of 2.5% to 3.5% or so given the Q2 and half-year warm levels. How do you see that kind of shaking out domestic and internationally? And then if you kind of, if organic growth stays at that, comes at in and that level, do you think that we could see kind of the same degree of margin improvement in the Brokerage business that we saw in the first half of the year and the second half?

headline: Arthur J Gallagher & Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, first of all, when we post the organic growth we posted overcoming a large lost account which -- a good thing about large accounts is they're great when you write them and they can make a results lumpy especially when you lose them, so that's on a p
componenttext: Well, first of all, when we post the organic growth we posted overcoming a large lost account which -- a good thing about large accounts is they're great when you write them and they can make a results lumpy especially when you lose them, so that's on a positive note. I think going forward, we don't have any of those that I know that are under attack right now. So I think our return normal 2.5% to 3.5% organic is insight. As it relates the margin improvement, where we see that opportunity is again as Doug mentioned in his comments, Australia and the U.K. And a little caution I have there is that those markets are a bit softer than what we're seeing domestically.

headline: Arthur J Gallagher & Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: In terms of margin, where do we see that? I think in that range, we've always said it's tough to expand margins if organic isn't above 3%. For above 3%, we might get a little bit of margin expansion. And if we're below, I think we'll be able to hold margi
componenttext: In terms of margin, where do we see that? I think in that range, we've always said it's tough to expand margins if organic isn't above 3%. For above 3%, we might get a little bit of margin expansion. And if we're below, I think we'll be able to hold margin in.

headline: Arthur J Gallagher & Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: And in Australia and New Zealand, you said it's a bit softer, but what you saw in the second quarter, would you say that, that represented kind of sequential improvement from the first quarter?
componenttext: And in Australia and New Zealand, you said it's a bit softer, but what you saw in the second quarter, would you say that, that represented kind of sequential improvement from the first quarter?

headline: Arthur J Gallagher & Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. And very nice improvement form 2015 so those teams have really gelled nicely and developing strong sales cultures. I've always had a very, very strong sales culture in New Zealand, Australia is coming on great and the U.K. and Canada as well.
componenttext: Yes. And very nice improvement form 2015 so those teams have really gelled nicely and developing strong sales cultures. I've always had a very, very strong sales culture in New Zealand, Australia is coming on great and the U.K. and Canada as well.

headline: Arthur J Gallagher & Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: What was the wholesale organic growth in the second quarter?
componenttext: What was the wholesale organic growth in the second quarter?

headline: Arthur J Gallagher & Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: In the mid-2s domestically. Property is a headwind for our wholesale business in the second quarter.
componenttext: In the mid-2s domestically. Property is a headwind for our wholesale business in the second quarter.

headline: Arthur J Gallagher & Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then in terms of -- I appreciate the disclosure guys provide on the share count. As you guys start to think about deal flow and expectations for 2017, how do you think about kind of managing the share count once we get beyond the end of 2016?
componenttext: Okay. And then in terms of -- I appreciate the disclosure guys provide on the share count. As you guys start to think about deal flow and expectations for 2017, how do you think about kind of managing the share count once we get beyond the end of 2016?

headline: Arthur J Gallagher & Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: First and foremost, we got a terrific deal pipeline, let's not forget that, and doing deals at less than 7x year-to-date, it really shows that we can still did some great merger partners at a fair price. Looking next year, I think our cash is better by fa
componenttext: First and foremost, we got a terrific deal pipeline, let's not forget that, and doing deals at less than 7x year-to-date, it really shows that we can still did some great merger partners at a fair price. Looking next year, I think our cash is better by far next year compared to this year. Integration will be basically done so we won't have the drags on that. We spent a lot of money on CapEx this year that I don't see that spending next year. So I see next year has a much better cash year than even this year. So what do we need to use shares in M&A in 2017, not at current paces. I don't see that happening.

headline: Arthur J Gallagher & Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question is coming from Kai Pan from Morgan Stanley.
componenttext: Our next question is coming from Kai Pan from Morgan Stanley.

headline: Arthur J Gallagher & Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is Chai going on for Kai Pan. I just wanted to go back to margins again. So broker margins expanded and you mentioned it was savings in BR and real estate was also part of it. I just wanted to get some color, if you expect margins to improve in inter
componenttext: This is Chai going on for Kai Pan. I just wanted to go back to margins again. So broker margins expanded and you mentioned it was savings in BR and real estate was also part of it. I just wanted to get some color, if you expect margins to improve in international operations and lower integration costs, can still expand in a sub-3% environment?

headline: Arthur J Gallagher & Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think there's 2 different things. I think overall, if you look at across the whole group, 3% organic growth is kind of the tipping point of margin expansion. But when you look at what were the way to get better in the U.K. retail space and down in Austr
componenttext: I think there's 2 different things. I think overall, if you look at across the whole group, 3% organic growth is kind of the tipping point of margin expansion. But when you look at what were the way to get better in the U.K. retail space and down in Australia in the retail space, there's some opportunities there. It's going to take us another year to 18 months to kind of harvest some of those but everyday, those folks are doing a great job. What I really am pleased about is not only they're expanding their individual margins. And remember, these are businesses that are still in the 20% margin rates so we're not talking about businesses that aren't making money, they're making terrific money. They're doing this in the same time that they're training their folks, they're adopting the Gallagher playbook when it comes to our sales culture. So they're working through just getting better in the back and then office at the same time, they're spending money it in order to get better at selling. So there's margin opportunity there but really, these are still businesses that are in the 20% margin, plus-20% margin range.

headline: Arthur J Gallagher & Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it. And the second question I have is in the CFO commentary, you mentioned higher FX headwinds in the second half. Is that coming from Brexit and anything else that is -- that could potentially impact the Brexit? I know you guys mentioned this revenue
componenttext: Got it. And the second question I have is in the CFO commentary, you mentioned higher FX headwinds in the second half. Is that coming from Brexit and anything else that is -- that could potentially impact the Brexit? I know you guys mentioned this revenue impact, but any plans?

headline: Arthur J Gallagher & Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Listen, on the outside, point of the CFO commentary, what we say is, we've adjusted -- we see a little bit more headwind on the revenue line from the decreased pound that sold off during the Brexit. What we really don't see that, we haven't changed our gu
componenttext: Listen, on the outside, point of the CFO commentary, what we say is, we've adjusted -- we see a little bit more headwind on the revenue line from the decreased pound that sold off during the Brexit. What we really don't see that, we haven't changed our guidance on the impact of EPS. If you recall, Gallagher like many other global brokers, have a lot of dollar-denominated revenues in the U.K. that is serviced with pound to denominated expenses so there's a little bit of a natural operating hedge there that mitigates some of the impact of the decrease pound. So it's more of a revenue headline story than it is an EPS, story. Unfortunately, for us, too, is that we have so many M&A opportunities around the world that we don't need to repatriate our cash into the U.S. to have good uses for it. So even if there is a sell off on the pound, there's some good opportunities for nice tuck-in mergers in the U.K. that we'll use our cash for.

headline: Arthur J Gallagher & Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: And that drives well into my final question. In terms of the second half pipeline for M&A. Now that the international acquisitions have integrated well, what do you see, in terms of potential, for international tuck-in acquisitions, in terms of your overa
componenttext: And that drives well into my final question. In terms of the second half pipeline for M&A. Now that the international acquisitions have integrated well, what do you see, in terms of potential, for international tuck-in acquisitions, in terms of your overall second half pipeline? Is it a greater share? What are the valuation multiples you're seeing there?

headline: Arthur J Gallagher & Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well first of all, the platforms are performing exactly as we'd hope, so the pipeline is built nicely in Australia, New Zealand, Canada and the U.K. for tuck-in acquisitions. And by tuck-in acquisitions, I mean acquisitions other $10 million in revenue, p
componenttext: Well first of all, the platforms are performing exactly as we'd hope, so the pipeline is built nicely in Australia, New Zealand, Canada and the U.K. for tuck-in acquisitions. And by tuck-in acquisitions, I mean acquisitions other $10 million in revenue, people that fit our culture and at multiples that we think are fair. So while there's competition and continuing growth in competition in the M&A space especially from private equity, we're finding that the culture sells well, the pipeline is deep and the opportunities do expands, continue to grow, every single quarter.

headline: Arthur J Gallagher & Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Are the multiples different in international market than in the U.S?
componenttext: Are the multiples different in international market than in the U.S?

headline: Arthur J Gallagher & Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: They're a little higher in Canada, probably the same in the U.K. and maybe slightly lower in New Zealand and Australia.
componenttext: They're a little higher in Canada, probably the same in the U.K. and maybe slightly lower in New Zealand and Australia.

headline: Arthur J Gallagher & Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question is coming from Josh Shanker from Deutsche Bank.
componenttext: Our next question is coming from Josh Shanker from Deutsche Bank.

headline: Arthur J Gallagher & Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: It seems like a little bit, you might have gone on my favorite hobbyhorse. It's almost like you're doing a share repurchase program, you intend maybe issue some share in the future, but you think your stock was cheap. You talk about -- is that a new menta
componenttext: It seems like a little bit, you might have gone on my favorite hobbyhorse. It's almost like you're doing a share repurchase program, you intend maybe issue some share in the future, but you think your stock was cheap. You talk about -- is that a new mentality for you to be preemptively buying back stock?

headline: Arthur J Gallagher & Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: No. We've said all along for the last -- over a decade that we've 3 uses for our stock and for our cash. The first is, we're going to buy brokers, that's what you're going to do. The second is we're paying a very nice dividend to our shareholders. And thi
componenttext: No. We've said all along for the last -- over a decade that we've 3 uses for our stock and for our cash. The first is, we're going to buy brokers, that's what you're going to do. The second is we're paying a very nice dividend to our shareholders. And thirdly, if there's extra cash, we use that to buy stock back. That's not a change in philosophy over more than a decade.

headline: Arthur J Gallagher & Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: [indiscernible] Josh, know what we're trying to do, if we put out shares for tax-free exchanges, so there's a way for merger partners to exchange your stock to our stock, it creates a tax advantage for them. We'll use shares and acquisition -- shares when
componenttext: [indiscernible] Josh, know what we're trying to do, if we put out shares for tax-free exchanges, so there's a way for merger partners to exchange your stock to our stock, it creates a tax advantage for them. We'll use shares and acquisition -- shares when we do the acquisition and then we'll turn around and buy a like amount in the market to keep the number of shares outstanding flat. In the second quarter, we had some opportunities to maybe pre-buy some of that stock and we saw the selloff after Brexit so we picked up those shares and we'll probably use of shares as we start closing some tax rate changes in the third and fourth quarter.

headline: Arthur J Gallagher & Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: It makes total sense. Do you have a mental philosophy around what would be the trigger for you to do some prebuying. I mean, look, your stock -- you're storing up a lot of tax credits for the future with queen coal, even though you can't use them today, y
componenttext: It makes total sense. Do you have a mental philosophy around what would be the trigger for you to do some prebuying. I mean, look, your stock -- you're storing up a lot of tax credits for the future with queen coal, even though you can't use them today, you'll know you're using the future. If you were to buy back stock right now it's because the stock is cheap, you know you're making acquisitions in the future. So what's the trigger that you would pre-buy stock?

headline: Arthur J Gallagher & Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think you have to look at the debt ratio on that. As I think if we want to have a nice comfortable to that ratio. And so for us to buy back the stock would mean we'd have to lever up on debt and then use that to buy shares in the way of the tax cre
componenttext: Yes, I think you have to look at the debt ratio on that. As I think if we want to have a nice comfortable to that ratio. And so for us to buy back the stock would mean we'd have to lever up on debt and then use that to buy shares in the way of the tax credits to monetize into our financial statements from the balance sheet into our debt. That something -- we can look at that, but it's not something that is on our plan right now.

headline: Arthur J Gallagher & Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. [indiscernible] I listened to your commentary about why the negative growth in Gallagher Bassett for the quarter? Going forward, is this an anomaly? Should we expect low -- the negative growth is that a common thing and we should probably resume a l
componenttext: Okay. [indiscernible] I listened to your commentary about why the negative growth in Gallagher Bassett for the quarter? Going forward, is this an anomaly? Should we expect low -- the negative growth is that a common thing and we should probably resume a low single-digit growth for the foreseeable future?

headline: Arthur J Gallagher & Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: I don't think we've had a negative quarter at Gallagher Bassett, in my memory.
componenttext: I don't think we've had a negative quarter at Gallagher Bassett, in my memory.

headline: Arthur J Gallagher & Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Me too, I'm with you.
componenttext: Me too, I'm with you.

headline: Arthur J Gallagher & Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: So for my chair, Josh, yes, you'll see us return to organic this quarter.
componenttext: So for my chair, Josh, yes, you'll see us return to organic this quarter.

headline: Arthur J Gallagher & Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question is coming from Adam Klauber from William Blair.
componenttext: Our next question is coming from Adam Klauber from William Blair.

headline: Arthur J Gallagher & Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016

componenttext: So I missed on the early comments, I'm sorry of these are repeats. But how's the wholesale business doing now compared to say, 6, 9 months ago.

componenttextpreview: Our wholesale business is awesome, it's just awesome. It's one -- to me, it's a corporate gem.
componenttext: Our wholesale business is awesome, it's just awesome. It's one -- to me, it's a corporate gem.

headline: Arthur J Gallagher & Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Adam, remember, and again, we said property can be a little weak in the second quarter with the property market right now but wholesale sales was nicely in the opportunities when it comes organic growth this quarter. So it's is performing well even in the
componenttext: Adam, remember, and again, we said property can be a little weak in the second quarter with the property market right now but wholesale sales was nicely in the opportunities when it comes organic growth this quarter. So it's is performing well even in the kind of a seasonal property quarter they have.

headline: Arthur J Gallagher & Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: I want to get back at my earlier comments, Adam. First of all, we started [indiscernible] from scratch about 15 years ago, from dead scratch to noble start-up. Today, with the largest MGA in the United States, we're one of the strongest open market Broker
componenttext: I want to get back at my earlier comments, Adam. First of all, we started [indiscernible] from scratch about 15 years ago, from dead scratch to noble start-up. Today, with the largest MGA in the United States, we're one of the strongest open market Brokerage operations. When we started that we hoped that our own domestic PC branches would utilize our PS, but we've also started as a true wholesaler, open to our competitors throughout the United States. That captured 50% of our go-forward wholesale business out of our retail branch network in the United States, and that's because they performed.

headline: Arthur J Gallagher & Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then on the benefit Brokerage side. How are commission levels this year versus last year?
componenttext: Okay. And then on the benefit Brokerage side. How are commission levels this year versus last year?

componenttext: Yes, we see -- it's interesting because June was kind of the month that we -- it looked like a bit of out of pattern number of new horizons. headline: Arthur J Gallagher & Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: I have to tell you, I give a lot of credit to the management teams of our major insurance companies. It's softer, as I said earlier, in New Zealand and Australia, Canada and U.K, especially in our specialty business in London. Those markets are soft. But
componenttext: I have to tell you, I give a lot of credit to the management teams of our major insurance companies. It's softer, as I said earlier, in New Zealand and Australia, Canada and U.K, especially in our specialty business in London. Those markets are soft. But here in the United States, we're coming up 5, 6 years of what I would go flat. When rates are down 1%, 2% or up 1%, 2%, in my expense, that's a flat market. In a typical hard market, rates are jumping 15%, 25%, 30%, 40%, 50%. In a typical soft market, they drop in 12%, 15%, could be 16%, 17%. We're 5 or 6 years now where that band is 1.5% to 2% up to 1.5% to 2% down. And I know that's driven by the lack of investment returns in the investment market, but it's pretty darn good discipline by the underwriting community, and we saw that again in the quarter. Soft on the property side and I've said this in past quarters, I think our clients deserve that softness. They will pay a price with the wind blows and it hasn't for a number of years. And so the property market is soft but casually, rate and exposure is controverted less than 1% negative to our results this quarter domestically, that's pretty good.

headline: Arthur J Gallagher & Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016

componenttext: By the way, that's a great environment, that's a great environment for our clients and it's also a great environment for our producers. When rates are dropping 15% to 20%, anybody can throw a court out there and touch it offguard with a number that's so low that you lose your clients. Today, it's all around our creative can you be and how helpful can you be to your client in helping them deal with their Risk Management costs.

componenttext: Yes. Listen, let me just say it this way. I think that first of all, on integration. Integration, we spent over $100 million in 2015, then we're running somewhere in that $50 million range right now, half, maybe less than that. So you'll free up $200 million next year just in those 2 numbers alone. So that's -- I don't see a lot of big real estate moves. So that's a nice pot of money to have.

headline: Arthur J Gallagher & Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good morning, and welcome to the Arthur J. Gallagher & Co.'s Second Quarter 2016 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] Today's call is being recorded. If you have any objections, you may disconnect at this time.Some of the comments made duri
componenttext:
Good morning, and welcome to the Arthur J. Gallagher & Co.'s Second Quarter 2016 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] Today's call is being recorded. If you have any objections, you may disconnect at this time.
Some of the comments made during the conference call, include forward -- or including answers given in response to questions, may constitute forward-looking statements within the meaning of the securities laws. These forward-looking statements are subject to certain risks and uncertainties that will be discussed on this call and which are also described in the company's reports filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission. Actual results may differ materially from those discussed today. 
In addition, for a consolation for the non-GAAP measures discussed in this call as well as any other information regarding of these measures, please refer to the most recent earnings release and any other materials in the Investor Relations section of the company's website.
It is now my pleasure to introduce J. Patrick Gallagher, Chairman, President and CEO of Arthur J. Gallagher & Co. Mr. Gallagher, you may begin

headline: Arthur J Gallagher & Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Donna. Good morning, everyone. Thank you for joining us for our second quarter 2016 earnings call. With me this morning is Doug Howell, our Chief Financial Officer, as well as the heads of our operating divisions.Today, we are going to touch
componenttext:
Thank you, Donna. Good morning, everyone. Thank you for joining us for our second quarter 2016 earnings call. With me this morning is Doug Howell, our Chief Financial Officer, as well as the heads of our operating divisions.
Today, we are going to touch on 4 key components of our strategy to drive shareholder growth: organic growth; merger growth; improving our quality and productivity, which Doug will spend most of his time on; and fourth, maintaining our unique culture. We have excelled on all 4 year to date.
First, let me talk about organic growth. In our Brokerage segment, after a terrific first quarter of 4.8% organic growth, we posted 2.2%, but that was marked by the loss of a large account that we discussed in our June investor meeting. Excluding the large account, we would have been closer to 2.5%. So for the first half, brokerage organic was 3.6%, which in retrospect is darn good based on how it felt coming to the year, especially in this environment.
Looking towards the second half of year, I see our organic somewhere between our second quarter year-to-date numbers, so I see an improvement going forward. Let me breakdown our organic around the world. I'm extremely pleased every single division posted positive organic growth in the quarter. Our sales culture is alive and well. Domestically, in the United States, we saw about 3% organic growth. Rate and exposure had little over a point of negative impact on our domestic PC renewal results in the second quarter. Most of that was property which, for us, is proportionally higher in our second quarter.
Domestic casualty lines pricing remains similar to last year, where we're seeing a slight downward pressure and we are seeing a modest growth in exposure units overall. This remains an environment where our production teams can grow and outperform. Our domestic employee benefit consulting business also posted about 3% organic and is seeing a tremendous amount of new business opportunities. Our teams are showing new prospects are vast array of services, tools and insights that they need to navigate a tight multigenerational labor market, rising health care costs and increasing regulatory complexities related to the ACA. Our smaller competitors are falling behind each and every day. This business typically grows more in the second half of the year and it seems to me that that will be the case again this year.
Let me move to our international brokerage operations. Since our last call, I spent a significant amount of time in Australia, Canada, New Zealand and the U.K. These teams are doing great. In fact, they're on a roll. After just 24 months of being part of the Gallagher family, I'm really pleased with how well we are working together, how our sales plans are becoming integrated and how our culture is thriving. Altogether, ex the one large account, our international operations posted about 2% organic growth in the second quarter, even with rates and exposures that are softer internationally than we see here domestically. I'm pleased that our teams are growing through those headwinds and the results are solid. 
As a side note, it was really interesting being in the U.K. and Europe during Brexit. Remember, we don't have much business at all for mainland Europe, and insurance is not flowing in and out London for over 300 years, long before the EU is formed. So other than a possible recession hitting the U.K. and the other EU countries, and your guest about that is about as good as mine, I don't see it as a worrisome event for us in the near term. Longer term, I think we and the industry will successfully navigate any potential changes to the European insurance landscape.
Next, let me move to merger and acquisition growth. Over the past 2 years, we've returned to our focus on smaller tuck-in mergers. The average size for the 13 acquisitions this quarter was $3 million of revenue and an average of 7x EBITDAC. So we're still finding really good opportunities at fair prices in the competitive merger environment. Year to date, 21 acquisitions, which should add about $70 million of annualized revenue, and we see a stronger second half for the year for acquisitions. Our pipeline is outstanding. 
There are a lot of really talented independent family-owned sales and consulting professionals out there. They have excellent relationships with their clients, they have strong sales skills and they have a very strong entrepreneurial bent. They create value by joining Gallagher where they have full access to our capabilities, expertise and resources. I've said for 30 years, pick your partners that have a culture similar to Gallagher and look out. 1 plus 1 together does make 3, 4 and 5. I'd like to thank all of our new partners for joining us and I extend a very warm welcome to our growing Gallagher family of professionals.
So to wrap up my comments on the Brokerage segment, halfway through the year, we posted 10% total revenue growth, of which 3.6% is organic. Adjusted EBITDAC growth of 13%, adjusted EBITDAC margin expansion of 60 basis points, integration costs are starting to wind down and we have an excellent M&A pipeline at fair multiples. Truly excellent results for the first half.
Next, I'd like to move to our Risk Management segment, which is primarily Gallagher Bassett. Risk Management had a more challenging organic quarter, but I'm really pleased that we proactively manage expenses and exceeded our 17% margin target. Second quarter organic was challenged for 3 reasons. First, as we discussed at our Investor Day, we are seeing a bit of a lull in new business inception dates. Second, we experience fewer new claims in the final 2 months of the quarter within the U.S. And third, we recently learned that we are not likely to earn a large performance bonus award from our participation in an Australian work cover program, where we are 1 of 5 providers. For the fiscal year ended June 30, the program paid performance fees using 20 different criteria and several the metrics had a big stretch. Unfortunately, we fell short. And you'll see in the organic table on Page 6 of the earnings release that we are nothing here in the second quarter in 2016. We believe the other providers fell short too, but let me be clear, I'm disappointed. Going forward, we will return to positive organic growth in the third and fourth quarter. Our client value proposition of delivering superior claim outcomes is stronger than ever. In fact, we have recently renewed a big program in Australia and had 2 nice new business wins, one in Australia and one in the U.K., and our domestic new business pipeline is solid.
Let me move to clean energy. Once again, we had a great quarter. The Corporate segment earnings came in above the midpoint of the guidance range we previous provided. We're well on our way to delivering nearly 15% growth in annual after-tax earnings.
Lastly, on our culture. Over the past 3 months, as I said, I have visited the U.K, Canada, Australia and New Zealand. I can tell you that our unique Gallagher culture is thriving and strong across our entire global footprint. This includes the over 300 promising college students globally learning about the greatest business on Earth in our internship program. We're just wrapping up the 51st year of the Gallagher summer intern program. We believe the 2-month program is an important investment in our future as we like growing our own.
So we have delivered an excellent first half of the year, the fundamentals of our business remains strong and we think the second half will even be a bit stronger. Over to you Doug.

headline: Arthur J Gallagher & Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: All right. Thanks, Pat, and good morning, everyone, Today, I'll do some earnings release housekeeping, spend some time on our quality productivity and margins, I'll hit on integration, highlight some clean energy items and then wrap up with some comments
componenttext:
All right. Thanks, Pat, and good morning, everyone, Today, I'll do some earnings release housekeeping, spend some time on our quality productivity and margins, I'll hit on integration, highlight some clean energy items and then wrap up with some comments on cash and capital management. Okay. To the housekeeping, you'll see that we made changes to our earnings release. We did so because in May, the SEC published new guidance on the presentation of non-GAAP measures, and we believe we've now gone the additional mile in the spirit of new guidance. It makes the table a little busy, but the punchline here is that we have not removed any of our previous disclosures as we strive to remain as transparent as possible. Also, please recall that many of my more forward-looking statements today can be found on the document called CFO commentary that we post on our Investor Relations website.
All right. Let me turn to margins, which are a nice indicator, in my opinion, of our quality and productivity. Brokerage adjusted EBITDAC margins are up 57 basis points and Risk Management margin came in at above our 17% adjusted margin target. Year to date, our margins have expanded in both Brokerage by 60 basis points and Risk Management by 33 basis points. That's really terrific work by the team out there. 
Within the Brokerage segment, margin expansion came mostly from our international operations. Recall that, we believe, there is an opportunity to expand margins in our Australia and U.K. retail businesses over the next couple of years. And we made good progress on that this last quarter, as our margin improvement initiatives have kicked in. Let me give you a couple of examples. First, we've moved all of our transactional accounting out of London into Glasgow. Once we cleaned it up in Glasgow, we then shipped the work into our offshore centers of excellence, which is really following the blueprint that we built here in the USA over the last 10 years, which allows us -- as we bring new entities on to move faster than ever before. 
Second is another example in the U.K., our retail team standardized core service related processes such as endorsements, quoting and renewals across our 50-plus branches. And in Australia, we've started consolidating our SME business from 25-plus branches into a few specialized centers that will focus on just small customers. 
All of these all work has driven down our back and middle office costs as we can capitalize on our scale, and to me, what's even more exciting is we've dramatically improved the quality of our services and our customer experience. Every day, our folks that work in the middle and back office get up to be better, faster and wiser on how we spend money.
Let me comment specifically also on integration. Recall that we did 5 large deals in late 2013 and early 2014, and we're nearly finished with the integration. I was in the U.K. a few weeks ago and the efforts to wrap this up are impressive. And I was in Canada in May, and by the end of this year, we will migrate nearly all of the 6 or 7 business units on to the same agency management system we use here in the USA. 
Second quarter integration costs were right on our forecast of $0.05 a share, about half of last year's amount. And you'll see on the CFO commentary sheet that we are anticipating about $0.06 to $0.07 total in the last half of 2016 in integration cost, which is down dramatically from the $0.21 we spent in the last half of 2015. So our efforts are well on track to be down by early 2017.
Let me turn to the Risk Management segment, Gallagher Bassett. Over the last several years, we've been improving our service offering to deliver better claim outcomes. Much of the back office improvement is very similar to what we have done in the Brokerage segment. But in addition, we have improved the tools our adjusters use, such as automating manual and high-volume processes that are really necessary to do a great job, but frankly, can bog our folks down. We've also shifted nearly 1,000 associates into work-from-home locations and we developed some specialized centers to focus on complex, specialized case management. These efforts have allowed us to improve our margins in the Risk Management segment over the last couple of years and should allow us to post margins for the year in the neighborhood of 17.5%, which is up from our previous target of 17%.
Shifting to the Corporate segment. We landed a $0.01 or so above the midpoint of our guidance that we provided during our investor meeting in June. Most of this was due to better clean energy earnings because our plants ran ahead of plan in June due to hot weather that hit the various parts of the country. We're still forecasting between $110 million to $120 million of net earnings for the year. First half was a little stronger, but the full year should be about where we estimated 6 months ago. 
It's also important to note that by the end of the year, we will have over $400 million of credits on our balance sheet, effectively, that's a $400 million receivable from the government that will help us reduce our cash taxes paid for many years. As for cash, we've got about $150 million of available cash on our balance sheet and we're making really good progress in our U.K. bank account consolidation efforts to unlock available cash that we talked about before. I think that we're down about 30% in the number of open bank accounts since the beginning of the year.
As for stock, we use no net shares for M&A this quarter and we actually bought some shares back during the Brexit market selloff. We'll use those shares on some future tax rate exchange mergers coming up this year. So when you look back, we haven't used any net shares to do M&A in over a year, and I think we can fund deals with cash and debt through year-end.
So those are my comments. I think it was an excellent first half of the year. Back to you Pat.

headline: Arthur J Gallagher & Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016

componenttext: Thank you, Doug. Donna, we'll take some questions and answers now.

headline: Arthur J Gallagher & Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016

componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Our first question is coming from Elyse Greenspan of Wells Fargo.

headline: Arthur J Gallagher & Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: I was hoping to spend a little bit, get a little bit more color on your organic growth outlook that you provided for the second half of the year, the kind of in the range, I guess, of 2.5% to 3.5% or so given the Q2 and half year 1 levels. How do you see
componenttext: I was hoping to spend a little bit, get a little bit more color on your organic growth outlook that you provided for the second half of the year, the kind of in the range, I guess, of 2.5% to 3.5% or so given the Q2 and half year 1 levels. How do you see that kind of shaking out domestic and internationally? And then if you kind of -- if da organic growth stays at that path, comes in at that level, do you think that we could see kind of the same degree of margin improvement in the Brokerage business that we saw in the first half of the year and the second half?

headline: Arthur J Gallagher & Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, first of all, when we post the organic growth that we posted overcoming a large lost account which -- the good thing about large accounts is they're great when you write them and they could make your results lumpy, especially when you lose them, so
componenttext: Well, first of all, when we post the organic growth that we posted overcoming a large lost account which -- the good thing about large accounts is they're great when you write them and they could make your results lumpy, especially when you lose them, so that's on a positive note. I think going forward, we don't have any of those that I know that are under attack right now. So I think a return to a normal 2.5% to 3.5% organic is in sight as it relates to margin improvement, where we see that opportunity is, again, as Doug mentioned in his comments, Australia and the U.K. And the little caution I have there is that those markets are a bit softer than what we're seeing domestically.

headline: Arthur J Gallagher & Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. In terms of margin, where do we see that? I think in that range, we've always said it's tough to expand margins if organic isn't above 3%. For above 3%, we might get a little bit of margin expansion. If we're below, I think we'll be able to hold marg
componenttext: Yes. In terms of margin, where do we see that? I think in that range, we've always said it's tough to expand margins if organic isn't above 3%. For above 3%, we might get a little bit of margin expansion. If we're below, I think we'll be able to hold margin in.

headline: Arthur J Gallagher & Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: And in Australia and New Zealand, you said it's still a bit softer, but what you saw in the second quarter, would you say that, that represented kind of sequential improvement from the first quarter?
componenttext: And in Australia and New Zealand, you said it's still a bit softer, but what you saw in the second quarter, would you say that, that represented kind of sequential improvement from the first quarter?

componenttext: Yes. And very nice improvement from 2015. So those teams have really gelled incredible nicely and developing strong sales cultures. We've always had a very, very strong sales culture in New Zealand, Australia is coming on great, and the U.K. and Canada as well.

componenttext: What was the wholesale organic growth in the second quarter?

componenttext: In the mid-2s domestically. Remember, property is a headwind for our wholesale business in the second quarter.

headline: Arthur J Gallagher & Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then in terms of -- I appreciate the disclosure you guys provide on the share count. As you guys start to think about deal flow and expectations for 2017, how do you think about kind of managing the share count once we get beyond the end of 2016
componenttext: Okay. And then in terms of -- I appreciate the disclosure you guys provide on the share count. As you guys start to think about deal flow and expectations for 2017, how do you think about kind of managing the share count once we get beyond the end of 2016?

headline: Arthur J Gallagher & Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, listen. First and foremost, we have a terrific deal pipeline, let's not forget that. And doing deals at less than 7x year to date, it really shows that we can still get some great merger partners at a fair price. Looking next year, I think our cash
componenttext: Well, listen. First and foremost, we have a terrific deal pipeline, let's not forget that. And doing deals at less than 7x year to date, it really shows that we can still get some great merger partners at a fair price. Looking next year, I think our cash is better, by far, next year compared to this year. Integration will be basically done so we won't have big drags on that. We spent a lot of money on CapEx this year that I don't see us spending next year. So I see next year as a much better cash year than even this year. So when we need to use shares in M&A in 2017, not at current paces, I don't see that happening.

headline: Arthur J Gallagher & Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question is coming from Kai Pan from Morgan Stanley.
componenttext: Our next question is coming from Kai Pan from Morgan Stanley.

headline: Arthur J Gallagher & Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is Chai Gohil for Kai Pan. I just wanted to go back to margins again. So Brokerage margins expanded, and you mentioned it was savings in BI and real estate was also part of it, I just wanted to get some color if you expect margins to improve in the i
componenttext: This is Chai Gohil for Kai Pan. I just wanted to go back to margins again. So Brokerage margins expanded, and you mentioned it was savings in BI and real estate was also part of it, I just wanted to get some color if you expect margins to improve in the international operations and lower integration costs. Can it still expand in a sub-3% environment?

headline: Arthur J Gallagher & Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think those are 2 different things. I think, overall, if you just look across the whole group, 3% organic growth is kind of the tipping point of margin expansion. But when you look at what we're doing to get better in the U.K. retail space and down in A
componenttext: I think those are 2 different things. I think, overall, if you just look across the whole group, 3% organic growth is kind of the tipping point of margin expansion. But when you look at what we're doing to get better in the U.K. retail space and down in Australia in the retail space, there is some opportunities there. It's going to take us another year to 18 months to kind of harvest some of those. But every day, those folks are doing a great job, and what I really am pleased about is not only they're expanding their individual margins. And remember, these are businesses that are still in the 20% margin range so we're not talking about businesses that aren't making money, they're making terrific money. They're doing this the same time that they're training their folks. They're adopting the Gallagher playbook when it comes to our sales culture, so they're working through just getting better in the back and mid office at the same time they're spending money in order to get better at selling. So there is margin opportunity there. But remember, these are still businesses that are in the 20% margin, plus-20% margin range.

headline: Arthur J Gallagher & Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it. And the second question I have is in the CFO commentary, you mentioned higher FX headwinds in the second half. Is that coming from Brexit and anything else that is -- that could potentially impact from Brexit? I know you guys mentioned less revenu
componenttext: Got it. And the second question I have is in the CFO commentary, you mentioned higher FX headwinds in the second half. Is that coming from Brexit and anything else that is -- that could potentially impact from Brexit? I know you guys mentioned less revenue impact, but any doubts?

headline: Arthur J Gallagher & Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Listen, on FX -- good point on the CFO commentary, what we said is we've adjusted -- we see a little bit more headwind on the revenue line from the decreased pound that sold off during the Brexit. But we really don't see that, we haven't changed our guida
componenttext: Listen, on FX -- good point on the CFO commentary, what we said is we've adjusted -- we see a little bit more headwind on the revenue line from the decreased pound that sold off during the Brexit. But we really don't see that, we haven't changed our guidance on the impact of EPS. If you recall, Gallagher like many other global brokers, have a lot of dollar-denominated revenues in the U.K. that is serviced with pound-denominated expenses, so there is a little bit of a natural operating hedge there that mitigates some of the impact of the decreasing pound. So it's more of a revenue headline story than it is an EPS story. Unfortunately, for us, too, is that we have so many M&A opportunities around the world that we don't need to repatriate our cash into the U.S. to have good uses for it. So even if there is a sell off on the pound, there are some good opportunities for nice tuck-in mergers in the U.K. that we'll use our cash for.

headline: Arthur J Gallagher & Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: And that drives well into my final question, in terms of the second half pipeline for M&A. Now that the international acquisitions have integrated well, what do you see in terms of potential for international tuck-in acquisitions, in terms of your overall
componenttext: And that drives well into my final question, in terms of the second half pipeline for M&A. Now that the international acquisitions have integrated well, what do you see in terms of potential for international tuck-in acquisitions, in terms of your overall second half pipeline? Is it a greater share? What are the valuation multiples you are seeing there?

headline: Arthur J Gallagher & Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, first of all, the platforms are performing exactly as we'd hope. So the pipeline is built nicely in Australia, New Zealand, Canada and the U.K. for tuck-in acquisitions. And by tuck-in acquisitions, I mean acquisitions other $10 million in revenue,
componenttext: Well, first of all, the platforms are performing exactly as we'd hope. So the pipeline is built nicely in Australia, New Zealand, Canada and the U.K. for tuck-in acquisitions. And by tuck-in acquisitions, I mean acquisitions other $10 million in revenue, people that fit our culture and -- at multiples that we think are fair. So while there is competition and continuing growth in competition in the M&A space, especially from private equity, we're finding that the culture sells well, the pipeline is deep and the opportunities do expands, continue to grow, every single quarter.

headline: Arthur J Gallagher & Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Are the multiples different in international market than in the U.S?
componenttext: Are the multiples different in international market than in the U.S?

headline: Arthur J Gallagher & Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. They're a little higher in Canada, probably the same in the U.K. and maybe slightly lower in New Zealand and Australia.[ph][ph][ph][ph]
componenttext:
Yes. They're a little higher in Canada, probably the same in the U.K. and maybe slightly lower in New Zealand and Australia.
[ph][ph][ph][ph]

headline: Arthur J Gallagher & Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question is coming from Josh Shanker from Deutsche Bank.
componenttext: Our next question is coming from Josh Shanker from Deutsche Bank.

headline: Arthur J Gallagher & Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: It seems like a little bit, you might have gone on my favorite hobbyhorse. It's almost like you're doing a share repurchase program. You intend maybe issue some shares in the future, but you think your stock was cheap. Can we talk about -- is that a new m
componenttext: It seems like a little bit, you might have gone on my favorite hobbyhorse. It's almost like you're doing a share repurchase program. You intend maybe issue some shares in the future, but you think your stock was cheap. Can we talk about -- is that a new mentality for you to be preemptively buying back stock?

headline: Arthur J Gallagher & Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: No. We've said all along for the last -- over a decade, that we've got 3 uses for our stock -- or for our cash. The first is, we're going to buy brokers, that's what you're going to do. The second is we're paying a very nice dividend to our shareholders.
componenttext: No. We've said all along for the last -- over a decade, that we've got 3 uses for our stock -- or for our cash. The first is, we're going to buy brokers, that's what you're going to do. The second is we're paying a very nice dividend to our shareholders. And thirdly, if there's extra cash, we use that to buy stock back. That's not a change in philosophy over more than a decade.

headline: Arthur J Gallagher & Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: In those days though, Josh, remember what we're trying to do, if we put out shares for tax-free exchanges, so there's a way for merger partners to exchange their stock for our stock, it creates a tax advantage for them. We'll use shares when we do the acq
componenttext: In those days though, Josh, remember what we're trying to do, if we put out shares for tax-free exchanges, so there's a way for merger partners to exchange their stock for our stock, it creates a tax advantage for them. We'll use shares when we do the acquisition and then we'll turn around and buy a like amount in the market to keep the number of shares outstanding flat. In the second quarter, we had some opportunities to maybe prebuy some of that stock and we saw the selloff that -- right after Brexit, so we picked up those shares and we'll probably use of shares as we start closing some tax rate changes in the third and the fourth quarter.

headline: Arthur J Gallagher & Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: That makes total sense. Do you have a mental philosophy around what would be the trigger for you to do some prebuying. I mean, look, your stock -- you're storing up a lot of tax credits for the future with clean coal. Even though you can't use them today,
componenttext: That makes total sense. Do you have a mental philosophy around what would be the trigger for you to do some prebuying. I mean, look, your stock -- you're storing up a lot of tax credits for the future with clean coal. Even though you can't use them today, you know you'll use them in the future. If you were to buy back stock right now because you think the stock is cheap, you know you're making acquisitions in the future. So what's the trigger that you would prebuy stock?

headline: Arthur J Gallagher & Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I think you have to look at the debt ratio on that because I think that we want to have a nice comfortable, safe debt ratio. And so for us to buy back the stock would mean we'd have to lever up on debt and then use that to buy shares and waiting for
componenttext: Yes. I think you have to look at the debt ratio on that because I think that we want to have a nice comfortable, safe debt ratio. And so for us to buy back the stock would mean we'd have to lever up on debt and then use that to buy shares and waiting for the tax credits to monetize into our financial statements from the balance sheet into our debt. That's something -- we can look at that, but it's not something that's on our plan right now.

headline: Arthur J Gallagher & Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then I listened to your commentary about why the negative growth in Gallagher Bassett for the quarter. Going forward, is this an anomaly? Should we expect low -- that negative growth is that a common thing and we should probably resume a low sin
componenttext: Okay. And then I listened to your commentary about why the negative growth in Gallagher Bassett for the quarter. Going forward, is this an anomaly? Should we expect low -- that negative growth is that a common thing and we should probably resume a low single-digit growth for the foreseeable future?

headline: Arthur J Gallagher & Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: I don't think we've had a negative quarter at Gallagher Bassett, in my memory.
componenttext: I don't think we've had a negative quarter at Gallagher Bassett, in my memory.

headline: Arthur J Gallagher & Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Me too, I'm with you.
componenttext: Me too, I'm with you.

headline: Arthur J Gallagher & Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So from my chair, Josh, yes, you'll see us return to organic this quarter.
componenttext: Yes. So from my chair, Josh, yes, you'll see us return to organic this quarter.

componenttext: I would say, Adam, remember -- and again, we said the property can be a little weak in the second quarter for the -- with the property market right now, but the wholesale still was nicely in the upper 2s when it comes to organic growth this quarter. So it's is performing well even in the kind of a seasonal property quarter they have.

headline: Arthur J Gallagher & Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Holding back at my earlier comments, Adam. First of all, we started this thing from scratch about 15 years ago, from dead scratch to noble start-up. Today, we're the largest MGA in the United States. We're one of the strongest open market Brokerage operat
componenttext: Holding back at my earlier comments, Adam. First of all, we started this thing from scratch about 15 years ago, from dead scratch to noble start-up. Today, we're the largest MGA in the United States. We're one of the strongest open market Brokerage operations. When we started it we had hoped that our own domestic PC branches would utilize RPS, but we've also started this a true wholesaler, open to our competitors throughout the United States. That captured 50% of our go-forward wholesale business out of our retail branch network in the United States and that's because they performed.

headline: Arthur J Gallagher & Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then on the benefit brokerage side. How are commission levels this year versus last year?
componenttext: Okay. And then on the benefit brokerage side. How are commission levels this year versus last year?

headline: Arthur J Gallagher & Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: The commission levels on the small accounts are a struggle. I mean, I think that the -- we see that with the mandated loss ratios in the smaller area, they're squeezed. But remember, our benefits business is a consulting business. Yes, we get commissions,
componenttext: The commission levels on the small accounts are a struggle. I mean, I think that the -- we see that with the mandated loss ratios in the smaller area, they're squeezed. But remember, our benefits business is a consulting business. Yes, we get commissions, but it's negotiated as the fee. So if we're not receiving commissions on an account and we need a fee to do the work, we charge it as a fee. And we're very, very successful at getting the remuneration we deserve in that business.

headline: Arthur J Gallagher & Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: So the benefit brokerage business, has that growing more or less than the average retail business?
componenttext: So the benefit brokerage business, has that growing more or less than the average retail business?
