headline: Arthur J Gallagher & Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: I was hoping to spend a little bit -- get a little bit more color on your organic growth outlook that you provided for the second half of the year, that kind of -- in the range, I guess, of 2.5% to 3.5% or so given the Q2 and half year 1 [ph] levels. How
componenttext: I was hoping to spend a little bit -- get a little bit more color on your organic growth outlook that you provided for the second half of the year, that kind of -- in the range, I guess, of 2.5% to 3.5% or so given the Q2 and half year 1 [ph] levels. How do you see that kind of shaking out domestic and internationally? And then if you kind of -- if the organic growth stays at that -- comes in at that level, do you think that we could see kind of the same degree of margin improvement in the Brokerage business that we saw in the first half of the year, in the second half?

headline: Arthur J Gallagher & Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, first of all, when we post the organic growth that we posted overcoming a large lost account which -- the good thing about large accounts is they're great when you write them and they can make your results lumpy, especially when you lose them, so th
componenttext: Well, first of all, when we post the organic growth that we posted overcoming a large lost account which -- the good thing about large accounts is they're great when you write them and they can make your results lumpy, especially when you lose them, so that's on a positive note. I think going forward, we don't have any of those that I know that are under attack right now. So I think a return to a more normal 2.5% to 3.5% organic is in sight. As it relates to margin improvement, where we see that opportunity is, again, as Doug had mentioned in his comments, Australia and the U.K. And the little caution I have there is that those markets are a bit softer than what we're seeing domestically.

headline: Arthur J Gallagher & Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. In terms of margin, where do we see that? I think in that range; we've always said it's tough to expand margins if organic isn't above 3%. If we're above 3%, we might get a little bit of margin expansion. If we're below, I think we'd be able to hold
componenttext: Yes. In terms of margin, where do we see that? I think in that range; we've always said it's tough to expand margins if organic isn't above 3%. If we're above 3%, we might get a little bit of margin expansion. If we're below, I think we'd be able to hold margin in.

headline: Arthur J Gallagher & Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: And in Australia and New Zealand, you said it's still a bit softer, but what you saw in the second quarter, would you say that, that represented kind of sequential improvement from the first quarter?
componenttext: And in Australia and New Zealand, you said it's still a bit softer, but what you saw in the second quarter, would you say that, that represented kind of sequential improvement from the first quarter?

componenttext: Yes. And very nice improvement from 2015. So those teams have really gelled incredible nicely and developing strong sales cultures. We've always had a very, very strong sales culture in New Zealand, Australia is coming on great, and the U.K. and Canada as well.

headline: Arthur J Gallagher & Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016

componenttext: Okay. And then in terms of -- I appreciate the disclosure you guys provide on the share count. As you guys start to think about deal flow and expectations for 2017, how do you think about kind of managing the share count once we get beyond the end of 2016?

headline: Arthur J Gallagher & Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, listen, first and foremost, we've got a terrific deal pipeline, let's not forget that. And doing deals at less than 7x year to date, it really shows that we can still get some great merger partners at a fair price. Looking next year, I think our cas
componenttext: Well, listen, first and foremost, we've got a terrific deal pipeline, let's not forget that. And doing deals at less than 7x year to date, it really shows that we can still get some great merger partners at a fair price. Looking next year, I think our cash is better, by far, next year compared to this year. Integration will be basically done so we won't have big drags on that. We spent a lot of money on CapEx this year that I don't see us spending next year. So I see next year as a much better cash year than even this year. So will we need to use shares in M&A in 2017? Not at current paces, I don't see that as happening.

headline: Arthur J Gallagher & Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question is coming from Kai Pan from Morgan Stanley.
componenttext: Our next question is coming from Kai Pan from Morgan Stanley.

headline: Arthur J Gallagher & Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is Chai Gohil for Kai Pan. I just wanted to go back to margins again. So Brokerage margins expanded, and you mentioned it was savings in BI and real estate was also part of it. I just wanted to get some color. If you expect margins to improve in the
componenttext: This is Chai Gohil for Kai Pan. I just wanted to go back to margins again. So Brokerage margins expanded, and you mentioned it was savings in BI and real estate was also part of it. I just wanted to get some color. If you expect margins to improve in the international operations and lower integration costs, can it still expand in a sub-3% environment?

headline: Arthur J Gallagher & Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think those are 2 different things. I think, overall, if you just look across the whole group, 3% organic growth is kind of the tipping point of margin expansion. But when you look at what we're doing to get better in the U.K. retail space and down in A
componenttext: I think those are 2 different things. I think, overall, if you just look across the whole group, 3% organic growth is kind of the tipping point of margin expansion. But when you look at what we're doing to get better in the U.K. retail space and down in Australia in the retail space, there are some opportunities there. It's going to take us another year to 18 months to kind of harvest some of those. But every day, those folks are doing a great job, and what I really am pleased about is not only are they expanding their individual margins -- and remember, these are businesses that are still in the 20% margin range, so we're not talking about businesses that aren't making money, they're making terrific money. They're doing this at the same time that they're training their folks. They're adopting the Gallagher playbook when it comes to our sales culture, so they're working through just getting better in the back and mid office. At the same time, they're spending money in order to get better at selling. So there is margin opportunity there. But remember, these are still businesses that are in the 20% margin -- plus-20% margin range.

headline: Arthur J Gallagher & Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it. And the second question I have is in the CFO commentary, you mentioned higher FX headwinds in the second half. Is that coming from Brexit and anything else that is -- that could potentially impact from Brexit? I know you guys mentioned less revenu
componenttext: Got it. And the second question I have is in the CFO commentary, you mentioned higher FX headwinds in the second half. Is that coming from Brexit and anything else that is -- that could potentially impact from Brexit? I know you guys mentioned less revenue impact, but anything else?

headline: Arthur J Gallagher & Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Listen, on FX -- good point on the CFO commentary, what we said is we've adjusted -- we see a little bit more headwind on the revenue line from the decreased pound that sold off during the Brexit. But we really don't see that, we haven't changed our guida
componenttext: Listen, on FX -- good point on the CFO commentary, what we said is we've adjusted -- we see a little bit more headwind on the revenue line from the decreased pound that sold off during the Brexit. But we really don't see that, we haven't changed our guidance on the impact of EPS. If you recall, Gallagher like many other global brokers, have a lot of dollar-denominated revenues in the U.K. that is serviced with pound-denominated expenses, so there is a little bit of a natural operating hedge there that mitigates some of the impact of the decreasing pound. So it's more of a revenue headline story than it is an EPS story. And fortunately, for us, too, is that we have so many M&A opportunities around the world that we don't need to repatriate our cash into the U.S. to have good uses for it. So even if there is a sell off on the pound, there are some good opportunities for nice tuck-in mergers in the U.K. that we'll use our cash for.

headline: Arthur J Gallagher & Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: And that drives well into my final question, in terms of the second half pipeline for M&A. Now that the international acquisitions have integrated well, what do you see in terms of potential for international tuck-in acquisitions, in terms of your overall
componenttext: And that drives well into my final question, in terms of the second half pipeline for M&A. Now that the international acquisitions have integrated well, what do you see in terms of potential for international tuck-in acquisitions, in terms of your overall second half pipeline? Is it a greater share? What are the valuation multiples you are seeing there?

headline: Arthur J Gallagher & Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, first of all, the platforms are performing exactly as we had hoped. So the pipeline is built nicely in Australia, New Zealand, Canada and the U.K. for tuck-in acquisitions. And by tuck-in acquisitions, I mean acquisitions under $10 million in revenu
componenttext: Well, first of all, the platforms are performing exactly as we had hoped. So the pipeline is built nicely in Australia, New Zealand, Canada and the U.K. for tuck-in acquisitions. And by tuck-in acquisitions, I mean acquisitions under $10 million in revenue, people that fit our culture and at multiples that we think are fair. So while there's competition and continuing growth in competition in the M&A space, especially from private equity, we're finding that the culture sells well, the pipeline is deep and the opportunities do expand, continue to grow, every single quarter.

headline: Arthur J Gallagher & Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Aren't the multiples different in international market than in the U.S?
componenttext: Aren't the multiples different in international market than in the U.S?

headline: Arthur J Gallagher & Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. They're a little higher in Canada, probably the same in the U.K. and maybe slightly lower in New Zealand and Australia.
componenttext: Yes. They're a little higher in Canada, probably the same in the U.K. and maybe slightly lower in New Zealand and Australia.

headline: Arthur J Gallagher & Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question is coming from Josh Shanker of Deutsche Bank.
componenttext: Our next question is coming from Josh Shanker of Deutsche Bank.

headline: Arthur J Gallagher & Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: It seems like a little bit, you might have gotten on my favorite hobbyhorse. It's almost like you're doing a share repurchase program. You intend maybe to issue some shares in the future, but you think your stock was cheap. Can we talk about -- is that a
componenttext: It seems like a little bit, you might have gotten on my favorite hobbyhorse. It's almost like you're doing a share repurchase program. You intend maybe to issue some shares in the future, but you think your stock was cheap. Can we talk about -- is that a new mentality for you to be preemptively buying back stock?

headline: Arthur J Gallagher & Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: No. We've said all along for the last -- over a decade, that we've got 3 uses for our stock -- or for our cash. The first is, we're going to buy brokers, that's what we're going to do. The second is we're paying a very nice dividend to our shareholders. A
componenttext: No. We've said all along for the last -- over a decade, that we've got 3 uses for our stock -- or for our cash. The first is, we're going to buy brokers, that's what we're going to do. The second is we're paying a very nice dividend to our shareholders. And thirdly, if there's extra cash, we use that to buy stock back. That's not a change in philosophy over more than a decade.

headline: Arthur J Gallagher & Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: In this case, though, Josh, remember what we're trying to do. If we put out shares for tax-free exchanges, there's a way for merger partners to exchange their stock for our stock, it creates a tax advantage for them. We'll use shares when we do the acquis
componenttext: In this case, though, Josh, remember what we're trying to do. If we put out shares for tax-free exchanges, there's a way for merger partners to exchange their stock for our stock, it creates a tax advantage for them. We'll use shares when we do the acquisition and then we'll turn around and buy a like amount in the market to keep the number of shares outstanding flat. In the second quarter, we had some opportunities to maybe pre-buy some of that stock when we saw the selloff after Brexit, so we picked up those shares and we'll probably use of shares as we start closing some tax-free exchanges in the third and the fourth quarter.

headline: Arthur J Gallagher & Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: That makes total sense. Do you have a mental philosophy around what would be the trigger for you to do some pre-buying? I mean, look, your stock -- you're storing up a lot of tax credits for the future with clean coal. Even though you can't use them today
componenttext: That makes total sense. Do you have a mental philosophy around what would be the trigger for you to do some pre-buying? I mean, look, your stock -- you're storing up a lot of tax credits for the future with clean coal. Even though you can't use them today, you know you'll use them in the future. If you were to buy back stock right now, because you think the stock is cheap, you know you're making acquisitions in the future. So what's the trigger that you would pre-buy stock?

headline: Arthur J Gallagher & Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I think you have to look at the debt ratio on that as I think that we want to have a nice comfortable, safe debt ratio. And so for us to buy back the stock would mean we'd have to lever up on debt and then use that to buy shares and waiting for the t
componenttext: Yes. I think you have to look at the debt ratio on that as I think that we want to have a nice comfortable, safe debt ratio. And so for us to buy back the stock would mean we'd have to lever up on debt and then use that to buy shares and waiting for the tax credits to monetize into our financial statements from the balance sheet into our debt. That's something -- we can look at that, but it's not something that's on our plan right now.

componenttext: [indiscernible] back at my earlier comments, Adam. First of all, we started this thing from scratch about 15 years ago, from dead scratch, de novo start-up. They've captured 50% of our go-forward wholesale business out of our retail branch network in the United States and that's because they perform.

componenttextpreview: The commission levels on the small accounts are a struggle. I mean, I think that the -- we see that with the mandated loss ratios in the smaller area, that they're squeezed. But remember, our benefits business is a consulting business. Yes, we get commiss
componenttext: The commission levels on the small accounts are a struggle. I mean, I think that the -- we see that with the mandated loss ratios in the smaller area, that they're squeezed. But remember, our benefits business is a consulting business. Yes, we get commissions, but it's negotiated as a fee. So if we're not receiving commissions on an account and we need a fee to do the work, we charge it as a fee. And we're very, very successful at getting the remuneration we deserve in that business.

componenttext: It grew the same this quarter. In the front-end of the comments, we said it grew about 3% this quarter which is the same as our domestic retail. componenttext: Also, I'll point out that an awful lot of activity on the M&A side there, Adam. The ACA is extremely complicated and the brokers that have really nice accounts, 500 lives to 1,000 lives, right in our sweet spot, are lining up to join our enterprise for all kinds of reasons, a lot of which is just the ACA is too difficult to deal with.

headline: Arthur J Gallagher & Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Primarily workers' compensation in the United States, which probably is a good -- you can't sit and complain about slower claim growth, right? I mean, for our customers, that's a good thing. It can be an indicator that the economy is slowing a bit because
componenttext: Primarily workers' compensation in the United States, which probably is a good -- you can't sit and complain about slower claim growth, right? I mean, for our customers, that's a good thing. It can be an indicator that the economy is slowing a bit because, typically, when you're putting on more shifts, there are -- there is more claim activity, but this is not unusual. From time to time, Gallagher Bassett will see loss control works better, clients are working very hard to cut the number of claims and we're helping them do that.

headline: Arthur J Gallagher & Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. We've seen -- it's interesting because June was kind of the month that we -- it looked like a little bit of out of pattern number of new horizons and we went back and [indiscernible]. There are some times where just, once every 22 months or something
componenttext: Yes. We've seen -- it's interesting because June was kind of the month that we -- it looked like a little bit of out of pattern number of new horizons and we went back and [indiscernible]. There are some times where just, once every 22 months or something, you get a slow month. And so I wouldn't consider it a trend necessarily, but it is something we'll keep an eye out. And then as July comes in and August comes in and we're together again we do an investor event in September, we'll update you on it. But we've had these patterns before where just some months, the claims just don't show up.

headline: Arthur J Gallagher & Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016

componenttext: And then, Pat, I wonder if you could prognosticate the casualty pricing kind of flat to down, how much longer do you think it remains flat here?

headline: Arthur J Gallagher & Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: I got to tell you, Mark, I give a lot of credit to the management teams of our major insurance companies. It's softer, as I said earlier, in New Zealand and Australia, Canada and the U.K, especially in our specialty business in London. Those markets are s
componenttext: I got to tell you, Mark, I give a lot of credit to the management teams of our major insurance companies. It's softer, as I said earlier, in New Zealand and Australia, Canada and the U.K, especially in our specialty business in London. Those markets are soft. But here in the United States, we're coming up 5, 6 years of what I would call flat. When rates are down 1%, 2% or up 1%, 2%, in my experience, that's a flat market. In a typical hard market, rates are jumping 15%, 25%, 30%, 40%, 50%. In a typical soft market, they're dropping 12%, 15%, could be 16%, 17%. We're 5 or 6 years now where that band is 1.5% to 2% up to 1.5% to 2% down. And I know that is driven by the lack of investment returns in the investment market, but it's pretty darn good discipline by the underwriting community and we saw that again in the quarter. Soft on the property side, and I've said this in past quarters, I think our clients deserve that softness. They will pay a price when the wind blows, and it hasn't for a number of years. And so the property market is soft, but casualty -- rate and exposure has contributed less than 1% negative to our results this quarter domestically, that's pretty good. By the way, that's a great environment. That's a great environment for our clients and it's also a great environment for our producers. When rates are dropping 15% to 20%, anybody can throw a quote out there and catch you off guard with a number that's so low that you lose your client. Today, it's all around how creative can you be and how helpful can you be to your client in helping them deal with their Risk Management costs.

componenttext: No. I think what's happening in comp, which is interesting, is the medical costs are escalating at a level faster than the indemnity side. So what you've got is kind of a shift. Severity is remaining about the same. Return to work is really, really critical, but it's all about the medical costs including pharma, that is something that everybody is concerned about.

headline: Arthur J Gallagher & Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016

componenttext: No, no, no. We've seen it on the ground. We've seen it -- and I'm not going to mention any specific carriers by name at all. But no, we're seeing disruption. The good news is, there's plenty of market. So where there's disruption, we're able to move business. But there are major companies that are undergoing underwriting reviews and they're making the moves that they believe. And again, I give them credit. I think we're looking at domestic U.S. pretty darn disciplined senior management.

componenttextpreview: Yes. Listen, let me just say it this way. I think that, first of all, on the integration, for our integration teams out there that are listening, I know you've got a lot of hard work left, but financially, it's not going to cost us that much between now a
componenttext: Yes. Listen, let me just say it this way. I think that, first of all, on the integration, for our integration teams out there that are listening, I know you've got a lot of hard work left, but financially, it's not going to cost us that much between now and the end of the year. So I'd like to say it's all done, but maybe towards -- maybe in our January call, we'll declare that. When it comes to CapEx, the spending that we've done on the home office build, and recall that we have an opportunity for a lot of tax credits to come through on that, that will improve future cash flow on it, that's about $125 million to $150 million this year that we won't have next year. Integration, we spent well over $100 million in 2015 and we're running somewhere in that $50 million range right now -- half, maybe less than that. So you'll free up $200 million next year just in those 2 numbers alone. So that's -- I don't see a lot of big real estate moves. We moved a big piece of our real estate in the U.K. this year. We won't have those costs, and that was probably in that $150 million of building costs, so there was $125 million in the U.S. and $25 million in the U.K. So I just don't see a lot of those big cash needs coming in 2017. So that's a nice pot of money to have.

headline: Arthur J Gallagher & Co., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good morning, and welcome to Arthur J. Gallagher & Co.'s Third Quarter 2016 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions]Today's call is being recorded. If you have any objections, you may disconnect at this time. Some of the comments made during th
componenttext:
Good morning, and welcome to Arthur J. Gallagher & Co.'s Third Quarter 2016 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions]
Today's call is being recorded. If you have any objections, you may disconnect at this time. Some of the comments made during this conference call, including answers given in response to questions, may constitute forward-looking statements within the meanings of the securities laws. These forward-looking statements are subject to the risks -- certain risks and uncertainties that will be discussed on this call and which are also described in the company's reports filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission. 
Actual results may differ materially from those discussed today. In addition, for reconciliation of the non-GAAP measures discussed on this call as well as other information regarding the use of these measures, please refer to the most recent earnings release and the other materials in the Investor Relations section of the company's website. 
It is now my pleasure to introduce J. Patrick Gallagher, Chairman, President and CEO of Arthur J. Gallagher & Co. Mr. Gallagher, you may begin.

headline: Arthur J Gallagher & Co., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I appreciate you joining us on our third quarter 2016 earnings call. Before I get down to some serious business, I have to start the call by saying go Cubs. With me this morning is Doug Howell, our Chief Financial Officer; as well as the heads of our oper
componenttext:
I appreciate you joining us on our third quarter 2016 earnings call. Before I get down to some serious business, I have to start the call by saying go Cubs. With me this morning is Doug Howell, our Chief Financial Officer; as well as the heads of our operating divisions. 
As I do every quarter, today, we're going to touch on the 4 key components of our strategy to drive shareholder value. Those 4 are, one, organic growth; two, growing our business through mergers and acquisitions; three, improving our quality and productivity; and fourth, maintaining a very unique Gallagher culture. 
The team executed on all 4 of these pillars this past quarter and on a year-to-date basis. 
First, let me start with organic growth. In our Brokerage segment, we posted all inorganic of 3.4%, up nicely over second quarter and right in line with our year-to-date organic of 3.6%. 
I recently returned from the Council of Insurance Agents and Brokers' Annual Meeting, where I met with more than 20 insurance carriers. Based on my conversations with carriers and consistent with our own experience in data, we continue to see the domestic pricing environment as stable. In fact, rate and exposure only had a little over 1 point of negative impact on our domestic property/casualty renewal results in the third quarter. 
I also spent time with our leadership teams in the U.K., Canada, Australia and New Zealand over the past few weeks, and pricing outside the U.S. remains broadly soft. So I see environment for us that could lead to organic growth in the fourth quarter similar to what we saw through the first 9 months of this year. Clearly, that depends on our new and lost business in the fourth quarter. And you may recall, we did have a very large new business month in December of 2015. 
Let me break down our organic around the world. I'm extremely pleased that every single division around the world posted organic growth in the quarter. Our sales culture is truly alive and well. 
Domestically, we saw about 4% organic growth. Within our retail P&C, operation up 3%; wholesale was up 1%; and benefits up nicely, over 5%. We did experience some incremental pressure within our wholesale unit, driven by continued weak property pricing in the quarter, with domestic casualty lines pricing remained similar to last year. 
Exposure units are showing some growth, offsetting some of the rate pressure. Property/casualty insurance market remains in a level where our production teams can grow organically and outperform. 
Our employee benefit consulting operation continues to see great new business opportunities. This business could typically grow us more in the second half of the year, and it did nicely here in the third quarter, and organic growth looks promising for the fourth quarter, too. 
In August, we released results of our annual Benefits Strategy & Benchmarking Survey, one of the large of its kind, with over 3,000 U.S. employers participating. This type of thought leadership and research is a great value to our clients and invaluable, and we are showing new prospects our best capabilities and insights. 
Let me move to our international brokerage operations. As I discussed in our July earnings call and our September 23 Investor Day, all of our operations globally are working together, with integrated sales plans and are living and breathing our unique Gallagher culture. This quarter, we saw 2% organic from our U.K. and Canadian teams and similar organic growth from our teams in New Zealand and Australia. This is simply excellent work as these international teams continue to grow through a rate and exposure headwind that is different than we are seeing here domestically. 
Next, let me move to merger and acquisition growth. The average size for the 7 acquisitions this quarter is $4 million of revenue at an average of 7.6x EBITDAC, putting our year-to-date multiple at 7x. Third quarter acquisition activity was a little slower than normal, but our pipeline remains very robust. 
We have approximately $90 million of revenue associated with agreed-upon term sheets and another $140 million of revenues with term sheets issued being prepared. While not all of these transactions will close, I do think we'll catch up to a more normal pace of transactions here in the fourth quarter. Our pipeline is as strong as ever and full of small, independent entrepreneurs with strong sales skills and excellent client relationships. 
Looking forward towards 2017, we will continue to focus on smaller tuck-in mergers, where we believe we can create value by giving these professionals full access to our capabilities, expertise and resources. 
I want to stop and thank all of our new partners for joining us and extend a very warm-up welcome to our growing Gallagher family of professionals. 
So how did we do through the first 3 quarters in our Brokerage segment? Over 9% total adjusted revenue growth, of which 3.6% is organic; adjusted EBITDAC growth of 11%; adjusted EBITDAC margin expansion of 47 basis points, and we continue to have an excellent merger and acquisition pipeline at fair multiples. 
I couldn't be more pleased with our 9 months' result in the Brokerage segment. 
Next, I'd like to move to our Risk Management segment, which is primarily Gallagher Bassett Services. Risk Management had a nice rebound from the second quarter, with organic back-end-positive territory. The turnaround from the second quarter is due to a smaller impact from performance bonus income and more normal patterns of the business. Client retention rates remain strong, and client satisfaction, both in the U.S. and internationally, continues to enhance GB's reputation and standing, with new sales results surpassing prior year. Going forward, for the Risk Management segment, we believe we can deliver positive organic in the fourth quarter and even better organic in 2017 as recent new business wins in Australia and the U.K. come online. 
Our value proposition of delivering superior claim outcomes for clients will continue to be a differentiator of this business versus our competitors. Further, Gallagher Bassett is an excellent [indiscernible] to our brokerage operations as it is another business that helps our clients manage and mitigate their total cost of risk. 
Moving now to clean energy. Once again, we had an excellent quarter, and we are 3 quarters into delivering nearly 15% growth in annual after-tax earnings. 
Lastly, let me speak a bit on culture. I hope you had a chance to attend or to listen to our September Investor Day. Tom Tropp, our Chief Ethics and Sustainability Officer, discussed how our unique Gallagher culture drives shareholder value. I truly hope you could take away from Tom's discussion how our culture directly contributes to our organic growth, how it distinguishes us from others in a highly competitive merger environment and how it is the basis for our people coming together as a team to service clients consistently focused on doing the right thing. 
After the meeting, we were asked why culture wasn't in Tom's title. As a simple answer to that, the Gallagher culture is every single person's responsibility, and our culture continues to flourish. 
Okay. Another great quarter and an excellent first 9 months. Over to you, Doug.

headline: Arthur J Gallagher & Co., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: All right. Thanks, Pat, and good morning, everyone. [indiscernible] like that another excellent quarter by the team. Today, I have 5 items. We'll do a refresher on modeling revenues, some comments on margins. We'll do an update on winding down our integra
componenttext:
All right. Thanks, Pat, and good morning, everyone. [indiscernible] like that another excellent quarter by the team. Today, I have 5 items. We'll do a refresher on modeling revenues, some comments on margins. We'll do an update on winding down our integration efforts. I'll move to -- and then I'll move to clean energy results, and I'll end with some comments on cash and capital management. 
Okay. Let's go to modeling revenues. I suggest using the CFO commentary document that we posted on our IR website as follows: starting on Page 2 of the CFO commentary. Adjust fourth quarter 2015 revenues for the impact of foreign currency exchange that we currently estimate at about $29 million. Remember, start by adjusting fourth quarter '15, not '16. Then apply your organic pick to that number. Next, layer in rollover M&A revenues from mergers that we completed in the first 9 months of this year. Page 5 of the CFO commentary shows that we estimate about $28 million rolling in, in the fourth quarter. 
And then, finally, make a pick -- make your own pick for new M&A revenue that might come from mergers we've closed here the fourth quarter. But please remember to assume a mid-quarter closing date. 
Following these steps should help you from over- or undershooting on revenues and avoid the related EPS impact. 
Okay, moving to margins. Adjusted brokerage EBITDAC margin expanded 20 basis points in the quarter. We continue to get some margin uplift from our international operations, but overall margin expansion was a bit muted because we have some adverse domestic medical plan experience in the quarter, cost us about 20 basis points. It's unfortunate but does happen from time to time. 
Looking towards the fourth quarter, if we hit 3% organic, and I'm not saying we will or we won't, we could hold margins flat with last year's fourth quarter or even squeak out a little expansion. 
As for the Risk Management segment, margin of 16.8% was right in line with our expectations that we shared with you at our investor meeting in September. This is really great work by the team. 
With a return to low single-digit organic in the fourth quarter, we seen margins in the lower 17% range. 
Next, let's move to integration. We're nearly finished. We're about done combining the 4 large acquisitions we did in the U.K. You can see it in the numbers. 
Third quarter integration costs were $0.04 this year versus $0.10 last year. And in the CFO commentary document, you'll see our fourth quarter estimates are -- for integration are at about $0.03, also down from $0.10 in the fourth quarter 2015. 
I'll be back in London in a couple of weeks and I look forward to congratulating the team for a really, really terrific effort over this last year. 
And also, I should -- deserves mentioning, too. Our Canadian merger is also substantially complete with their integration efforts. So it's really nice work to those folks up in Canada, too. 
Moving next to clean energy. We heard Pat say that we had another excellent third quarter, and we remain on track to deliver about 15% earnings growth over last year. Warmer weather helped us beat our forecast in the third quarter, but production might me a little lower in the fourth quarter because we haven't seen much cold weather yet. 
For example, you'll see that there's still a lot of green in the ivy at Wrigley tonight. And don't forget that our production has not only reduced our current year taxes, but we have also generated $430 million of credit that are sitting in our balance sheet. Effectively, that's a $430 million receivable from the government that will help us reduce our cash taxes paid for many, many years. We believe this has meaningful value for the shareholders. 
We also have about $230 million of available cash on our balance sheet. And as I've commented on before, we're making really good progress our bank account consolidation efforts that help us unlock available cash. 
So looking forward, you heard Pat say that our M&A pipeline is strong. We've got nice cash and nice cash flows developing. So I think that we can fund our activity for the remainder -- our M&A activity for the remainder of this year with cash and debt. 
As for 2017, I see even stronger cash flows, given integration will be behind us, and we won't have real estate moves that we have this year either. So we should be well positioned in 2017 to continue funding M&A with free cash and debt. 
So over my comments and another quarter and an excellent first 9 months of the year. Back to you, Pat.

headline: Arthur J Gallagher & Co., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. And I've said this many times. Personally, I was not in favor for our country to -- I was not a proponent of ObamaCare. But for our company, it's been the greatest thing in the world. So it's helped our merger and acquisition activity, and it's a ve
componenttext: Sure. And I've said this many times. Personally, I was not in favor for our country to -- I was not a proponent of ObamaCare. But for our company, it's been the greatest thing in the world. So it's helped our merger and acquisition activity, and it's a very, very complicated act. And what that does is create an awful lot of consulting effort for us. Our clients need a lot of help. The exchange is one of the things that we help our clients take a look at is they decide how they're going to treat the employee base. We look really at what we're doing from a consulting standpoint as a view of the total rewards that a client is going to use to maintain the employment of their best people. Really, when you come down to it, every business is all about people. And so you have to look at the entire list of benefits that you're going to provide and then figure out how you're going to actually work to help insurance into that. So exchange is popular. We've got probably about 15% of our clients out there taking a serious look at our exchange. And the rest are going to treat their insurance in a more traditional manner.

componenttext: Well, domestically, we seeing a pretty stable market, which has been a stable market now for about 5 years, which is pretty unusual in my career. And I think it's a very good thing for our clients. The past is hard and soft market cycle that we went through for the last nearly 4 years, that doesn't benefits plans at all. So today, we've got a stable market domestically, a softer market internationally. So what I see is continued international 1% to 2% organic and hopefully closer to 4% to 5% domestically.

I know in the past you pointed to me end of '17. Could that be pushed forward if these deals do not materialize?

headline: Arthur J Gallagher & Co., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, let me be clear about this. First of all, we see 3 uses of our cash. And we've said this literally for more than the last decade. The first is we're going to buy brokers. Secondly, we're paying dividends, and third, we're going to do is buy our stock
componenttext: Yes, let me be clear about this. First of all, we see 3 uses of our cash. And we've said this literally for more than the last decade. The first is we're going to buy brokers. Secondly, we're paying dividends, and third, we're going to do is buy our stock back. If, in fact, for whatever reason, the acquisition activity slows down, and we're going to maintain our pricing discipline around our acquisition activity, been here before. 20 years ago, the banks push prices all the way through the roof, and we had a bit of slowdown in acquisition and activity while they were doing that. They got their belly full, private equity will eventually as well. But if we have excess cash, we will buy as stock back.

headline: Arthur J Gallagher & Co., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016

componenttext: That's for the multiple. If you look at it year-to-date, we're still about 7x. It's a little higher than 7 6. I don't see us -- there's multiple pressure out there or pricing pressure out there,, but I think that there's a lot of sellers out there that see us bringing substantial capabilities to them that are willing to saw it at a fair price. So those are the ones that we're going to after. Nice entrepreneurial tuck-in, folks that are willing to tick a fair price. And understand that together, we could be better.

componenttext: Okay, great. And then one other question, I noticed the revenue hit from currency could go up in the fourth quarter, although the EPS impact did not change. How do you think about, I guess, the hit between revenue and expenses? And what kind of currency hit we might see on earnings given where exchange rates are today as we start to think about 2017?

headline: Arthur J Gallagher & Co., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. The uptick from our September 23 guidance is because of the further strengthening of the dollar versus the pound. We do have a little bit of natural hedge in the U.K. because we have dollar-denominated revenues and pound-denominated expenses that ser
componenttext: Yes. The uptick from our September 23 guidance is because of the further strengthening of the dollar versus the pound. We do have a little bit of natural hedge in the U.K. because we have dollar-denominated revenues and pound-denominated expenses that service those revenues. So that's why we end up with a de minimis amount of impact on our EPS. And I see, right now, I don't know if the pound going lower or not, but I would say that, that trend will continue then that you would have an impact on revenues but not that much impact on EPS.

componenttext: This is Chai Gohil, on for Kai. First question on contingent and supplement. They have grown about 10% to 20% year-to-date. So could you talk a little bit about what's driving that?

headline: Arthur J Gallagher & Co., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think there's a couple of things. I think it's a great quick question. If you listen to our September 23 IR Day, I got on the high horse a little bit about supplementals and contingents versus base contingent -- base commissions and fees. I think t
componenttext: Yes, I think there's a couple of things. I think it's a great quick question. If you listen to our September 23 IR Day, I got on the high horse a little bit about supplementals and contingents versus base contingent -- base commissions and fees. I think that you should evaluate us using all-in organic or at least combine the base and supplementals because contingents can be a little bit volatile. Like I said in September, it's important for everybody to understand in 1 year, we may place a piece of -- place of policy with a carrier that have a strong base commissions and doesn't pay much in supplementals. The next year, that policy might be better for the customer to be placed with another carrier that pays higher supplementals at a lower base or maybe that carry would pay contingent step. We are completely in different in how that gets classified in our financial statements. As long as we're being compensated appropriately and with full transparency to our clients. We've got to do the right thing for our clients first, and we can't worry about where that gets posted in our financial statement. So we have had strong growth in supplementals and contingents. And I think that's basically the carrier's reference on that rather than paying base commissions at this point.

componenttext: The contingents and supplementals are a higher margin for us. How much have they affected us year-to-date? They might have helped margins. I got to pull up the number here and look at it. Maybe 15 basis point, something like that, of our 47 basis point margin expansion year-to-date, maybe 1/3 of that came from contingents.

componenttext: Just curious about, Pat, we've had 4 months post Brexit both. Now we've got the ability how we've seen the world is changing. Curious what you think this does to your U.K. operation, Lloyd's as a center of gravity? And is there going to be a movement to Ireland a little bit in the margin for you and the world?

headline: Arthur J Gallagher & Co., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, I don't think so. I think from an insurance perspective, I think it's going to be pretty much of a nonevent. Now that's early days. And obviously, we're monitoring all that. And I think the people in the city of London are very concerned with what thi
componenttext: No, I don't think so. I think from an insurance perspective, I think it's going to be pretty much of a nonevent. Now that's early days. And obviously, we're monitoring all that. And I think the people in the city of London are very concerned with what this means to the financial world. But from an insurance perspective, the expertise is in London. People have traded in that with that expertise for 300 years, and I don't see it moving.

componenttext: Yes, as I said, I don't see -- I really don't see in a reason for anyone to decide that they have to move. That's going to differ by people in different industries. But when it comes to insurance, the Lloyd's and London insurance community was incredibly strong before the EU and incredibly strong afterwards.

componenttext: So I don't have to remind you of little more -- a little less than a year ago, you had made comments that got people concerned about 2016 [ph]. It's been a great 2016 [ph] for Gallagher. Let's talk about 2017 now. Compared to how felt about the year ahead last year, how are you feeling right now? And I'm not asking for guidance. componenttext: Yes, I'm very bullish on 2017. And you're exactly right, Josh. You read my sentence well. Finishing up last year, I was little bit concerned. And we ended up having an incredible new business quarter in the fourth quarter last year. I'm really proud of the team. And I see the pipeline. We use Salesforce.com. I can look into that pipeline. Virtually, all our niches are strong. The business -- the new business opportunities are strong now. We've got to close them, we've got to close it out. But I think 2017 will be another record year.

componenttextpreview: Very good. And a couple months ago, I asked you about health care exchanges, and you said that you were broadening your offering or you may be discussion with a couple health care exchange that currently you don't use. Can you talk about that broadening l
componenttext: Very good. And a couple months ago, I asked you about health care exchanges, and you said that you were broadening your offering or you may be discussion with a couple health care exchange that currently you don't use. Can you talk about that broadening looks like? And maybe get some details on what your plans might be?

headline: Arthur J Gallagher & Co., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Yes, I appreciate the question very much. I'm really proud of our benefits team for how we position ourselves. I think we took a lot of heat 2 to 3 years ago about not investing heavily in the technology to create our own exchange. And what we said t
componenttext: Yes. Yes, I appreciate the question very much. I'm really proud of our benefits team for how we position ourselves. I think we took a lot of heat 2 to 3 years ago about not investing heavily in the technology to create our own exchange. And what we said to the investment community and to our clients at that time is that we're consultants. We're going to use exchanges where they're appropriate for our clients, and we're going to have 1 to 2 to maybe even more exchanges than that as appropriate for opportunities for clients to deal with their exposures. And we're going to remain consultants. We're not going to be products sales firm. And I think that's really worked out well for us. And as reviewed in the market as helping clients sort through all their opportunities. We have a very nice partnership with liaison, and we also have other exchanges that we're working with. And whatever is the most appropriate method of handling the clients exposures and health insurance, we're going to bring that to the table. And I think that's the right position for a consultant.

componenttext: I'll take those backwards. The answer to your -- to the second question are the standard care inching in, the answer is yes. That puts pressure on us as a wholesaler. Retailers are given [indiscernible] in place to own business if they don't need a wholesaler. So that's a headwind. You also have the headwind of the property rates. And I don't think that view is going to make different to property rates whatsoever. So we're going to continue face softness there. And the reason it's growing is because we're just really good at what we do and we're getting a lot more business both from our own retailers as well as people in the field.

componenttext: Yes, good question. I think that there's 2 headwinds against our cash flow this year. The integration costs were still there. If you recall, we did some substantial moves in the U.K. as we consolidated operations there. And we're doing some big moves here in the U.S. as we move into a different Chicago-based building. So those costs are forced against cash flow this year. They will be there next year. So next year, we should have substantially more capacity than what you're seeing on the surface this year. I think M&A opportunities, there's tons of them there. And we are -- again, we just want to make sure we're picking the right partners to join us. But like Pat said, there's $250 [ph] million worth of deal sitting on the plate right now for the fourth quarter that we can see having some really nice success with those coming first part of the year.

headline: Arthur J Gallagher & Co., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016

componenttext: Traditionally, our first quarter is the smallest. So we could see a little low there. But also, it depends on how the election goes, you could have [indiscernible] moves against capital gain treatment on sale of businesses. So if that's the case, you could get a little bit of a rush to the door by the end of this year or certainly before the legislature gets working next -- when they reconvene in January. So I think there's good opportunities. There's still fair pricing out there. Immense market, people are seeing our capabilities. So if we have a little low right now, I wouldn't worry about it long term.

Just curious on a more overall basis, as opposed to the quarter, you're seeing fresher compensation both from like external in terms of the competitive dynamic, people interested in your people, other things, is there expectation that there might be compensation pressure going into 2017?

headline: Arthur J Gallagher & Co., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, that's a great question. If you recall back in our September 23 IR meeting day, I said that the rates is typically given in the latter half of the year. So some of that's hitting us right now here in the third and the fourth quarter. And then also we
componenttext: Yes, that's a great question. If you recall back in our September 23 IR meeting day, I said that the rates is typically given in the latter half of the year. So some of that's hitting us right now here in the third and the fourth quarter. And then also we had benefit expense that we had adverse development on our benefit program. And really, July and August, we didn't see that in September again. So that's pressure. Is there overall pressure in the marketplace? Yes. I think skill positions are expensive. They're going up in some of the IT security areas and others. there's always competition from really brokerage talent, too [indiscernible]. There's a little bit wage inflation. We have an opportunity to continue to push work into our centers of excellence in primarily in India and the Philippines. And so we have an opportunity to maybe reduce the impact of the domestic wage inflation by continuing to move offshore to our folks over there. So we have an opportunity to control, but there's an little bit of inflation out there in the marketplace.

headline: Arthur J Gallagher & Co., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016

componenttext: And finally, I recall a quarter -- a couple of quarters back that you mentioned that some on the international acquisitions that there was a plethora of bank accounts and trapped capital that you and your team were having to work through to aggregate and free up, if you will. componenttext: Yes. Good progress is being made on that. We're down over 30% in our accounts. We've gotten a list of about another 60 accounts for another maybe 10% that are -- is going to be wound out by the end of the year, and then I think most of that by the mid part of next year should be done. Part of that is bringing that excess cash internationally that's coming from that exercise. So we're making terrific progress. In Glasgow, where we do a lot of that work in September and the teams really got a good eye to get that done by the mid part of '17.

headline: Arthur J Gallagher & Co., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I do. I'll just make a quick comment. Thank you again for being with us today this morning. As we've done all year and in the past, our focus remains on executing on each component of our value-creation strategy. We're going to grow organically. We'r
componenttext:
Yes, I do. I'll just make a quick comment. Thank you again for being with us today this morning. As we've done all year and in the past, our focus remains on executing on each component of our value-creation strategy. We're going to grow organically. We're going to grow to acquiring the best brokers. We will improve our quality and our productivity. And we're going to continue to invest in our culture. 
I'm pleased with the first 3 quarters of 2016 and I'm excited about wrapping up 2016 and delivering a fantastic year next year, 2017. 
Thank you, everyone, for being with us this morning. We appreciate it.

headline: Arthur J Gallagher & Co., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good morning, and welcome to Arthur J. Gallagher & Co.'s Third Quarter 2016 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions]Today's call is being recorded. If you have any objections, you may disconnect at this time. Some of the comments made during th
componenttext:
Good morning, and welcome to Arthur J. Gallagher & Co.'s Third Quarter 2016 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions]
Today's call is being recorded. If you have any objections, you may disconnect at this time. Some of the comments made during this conference call, including answers given in response to questions, may constitute forward-looking statements within the meanings of the securities laws. These forward-looking statements are subject to the risks -- certain risks and uncertainties that will be discussed on this call and which are also described in the company's reports filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission. 
Actual results may differ materially from those discussed today. In addition, for reconciliation of the non-GAAP measures discussed on this call as well as other information regarding the use of these measures, please refer to the most recent earnings release and the other materials in the Investor Relations section of the company's website. 
It is now my pleasure to introduce J. Patrick Gallagher, Chairman, President and CEO of Arthur J. Gallagher & Co. Mr. Gallagher, you may begin.

headline: Arthur J Gallagher & Co., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I appreciate you joining us on our third quarter 2016 earnings call. Before I get down to some serious business, I have to start the call by saying go Cubs. With me this morning is Doug Howell, our Chief Financial Officer; as well as the heads of our oper
componenttext:
I appreciate you joining us on our third quarter 2016 earnings call. Before I get down to some serious business, I have to start the call by saying go Cubs. With me this morning is Doug Howell, our Chief Financial Officer; as well as the heads of our operating divisions. 
As I do every quarter, today, we're going to touch on the 4 key components of our strategy to drive shareholder value. Those 4 are, one, organic growth; two, growing our business through mergers and acquisitions; three, improving our quality and productivity; and fourth, maintaining a very unique Gallagher culture. 
The team executed on all 4 of these pillars this past quarter and on a year-to-date basis. 
First, let me start with organic growth. In our Brokerage segment, we posted all inorganic of 3.4%, up nicely over second quarter and right in line with our year-to-date organic of 3.6%. 
I recently returned from the Council of Insurance Agents and Brokers' Annual Meeting, where I met with more than 20 insurance carriers. Based on my conversations with carriers and consistent with our own experience in data, we continue to see the domestic pricing environment as stable. In fact, rate and exposure only had a little over 1 point of negative impact on our domestic property/casualty renewal results in the third quarter. 
I also spent time with our leadership teams in the U.K., Canada, Australia and New Zealand over the past few weeks, and pricing outside the U.S. remains broadly soft. So I see environment for us that could lead to organic growth in the fourth quarter similar to what we saw through the first 9 months of this year. Clearly, that depends on our new and lost business in the fourth quarter. And you may recall, we did have a very large new business month in December of 2015. 
Let me break down our organic around the world. I'm extremely pleased that every single division around the world posted organic growth in the quarter. Our sales culture is truly alive and well. 
Domestically, we saw about 4% organic growth. Within our retail P&C, operation up 3%; wholesale was up 1%; and benefits up nicely, over 5%. We did experience some incremental pressure within our wholesale unit, driven by continued weak property pricing in the quarter, with domestic casualty lines pricing remained similar to last year. 
Exposure units are showing some growth, offsetting some of the rate pressure. Property/casualty insurance market remains in a level where our production teams can grow organically and outperform. 
Our employee benefit consulting operation continues to see great new business opportunities. This business could typically grow us more in the second half of the year, and it did nicely here in the third quarter, and organic growth looks promising for the fourth quarter, too. 
In August, we released results of our annual Benefits Strategy & Benchmarking Survey, one of the large of its kind, with over 3,000 U.S. employers participating. This type of thought leadership and research is a great value to our clients and invaluable, and we are showing new prospects our best capabilities and insights. 
Let me move to our international brokerage operations. As I discussed in our July earnings call and our September 23 Investor Day, all of our operations globally are working together, with integrated sales plans and are living and breathing our unique Gallagher culture. This quarter, we saw 2% organic from our U.K. and Canadian teams and similar organic growth from our teams in New Zealand and Australia. This is simply excellent work as these international teams continue to grow through a rate and exposure headwind that is different than we are seeing here domestically. 
Next, let me move to merger and acquisition growth. The average size for the 7 acquisitions this quarter is $4 million of revenue at an average of 7.6x EBITDAC, putting our year-to-date multiple at 7x. Third quarter acquisition activity was a little slower than normal, but our pipeline remains very robust. 
We have approximately $90 million of revenue associated with agreed-upon term sheets and another $140 million of revenues with term sheets issued being prepared. While not all of these transactions will close, I do think we'll catch up to a more normal pace of transactions here in the fourth quarter. Our pipeline is as strong as ever and full of small, independent entrepreneurs with strong sales skills and excellent client relationships. 
Looking forward towards 2017, we will continue to focus on smaller tuck-in mergers, where we believe we can create value by giving these professionals full access to our capabilities, expertise and resources. 
I want to stop and thank all of our new partners for joining us and extend a very warm-up welcome to our growing Gallagher family of professionals. 
So how did we do through the first 3 quarters in our Brokerage segment? Over 9% total adjusted revenue growth, of which 3.6% is organic; adjusted EBITDAC growth of 11%; adjusted EBITDAC margin expansion of 47 basis points, and we continue to have an excellent merger and acquisition pipeline at fair multiples. 
I couldn't be more pleased with our 9 months' result in the Brokerage segment. 
Next, I'd like to move to our Risk Management segment, which is primarily Gallagher Bassett Services. Risk Management had a nice rebound from the second quarter, with organic back-end-positive territory. The turnaround from the second quarter is due to a smaller impact from performance bonus income and more normal patterns of the business. Client retention rates remain strong, and client satisfaction, both in the U.S. and internationally, continues to enhance GB's reputation and standing, with new sales results surpassing prior year. Going forward, for the Risk Management segment, we believe we can deliver positive organic in the fourth quarter and even better organic in 2017 as recent new business wins in Australia and the U.K. come online. 
Our value proposition of delivering superior claim outcomes for clients will continue to be a differentiator of this business versus our competitors. Further, Gallagher Bassett is an excellent [indiscernible] to our brokerage operations as it is another business that helps our clients manage and mitigate their total cost of risk. 
Moving now to clean energy. Once again, we had an excellent quarter, and we are 3 quarters into delivering nearly 15% growth in annual after-tax earnings. 
Lastly, let me speak a bit on culture. I hope you had a chance to attend or to listen to our September Investor Day. Tom Tropp, our Chief Ethics and Sustainability Officer, discussed how our unique Gallagher culture drives shareholder value. I truly hope you could take away from Tom's discussion how our culture directly contributes to our organic growth, how it distinguishes us from others in a highly competitive merger environment and how it is the basis for our people coming together as a team to service clients consistently focused on doing the right thing. 
After the meeting, we were asked why culture wasn't in Tom's title. As a simple answer to that, the Gallagher culture is every single person's responsibility, and our culture continues to flourish. 
Okay. Another great quarter and an excellent first 9 months. Over to you, Doug.

headline: Arthur J Gallagher & Co., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: All right. Thanks, Pat, and good morning, everyone. [indiscernible] like that another excellent quarter by the team. Today, I have 5 items. We'll do a refresher on modeling revenues, some comments on margins. We'll do an update on winding down our integra
componenttext:
All right. Thanks, Pat, and good morning, everyone. [indiscernible] like that another excellent quarter by the team. Today, I have 5 items. We'll do a refresher on modeling revenues, some comments on margins. We'll do an update on winding down our integration efforts. I'll move to -- and then I'll move to clean energy results, and I'll end with some comments on cash and capital management. 
Okay. Let's go to modeling revenues. I suggest using the CFO commentary document that we posted on our IR website as follows: starting on Page 2 of the CFO commentary. Adjust fourth quarter 2015 revenues for the impact of foreign currency exchange that we currently estimate at about $29 million. Remember, start by adjusting fourth quarter '15, not '16. Then apply your organic pick to that number. Next, layer in rollover M&A revenues from mergers that we completed in the first 9 months of this year. Page 5 of the CFO commentary shows that we estimate about $28 million rolling in, in the fourth quarter. 
And then, finally, make a pick -- make your own pick for new M&A revenue that might come from mergers we've closed here the fourth quarter. But please remember to assume a mid-quarter closing date. 
Following these steps should help you from over- or undershooting on revenues and avoid the related EPS impact. 
Okay, moving to margins. Adjusted brokerage EBITDAC margin expanded 20 basis points in the quarter. We continue to get some margin uplift from our international operations, but overall margin expansion was a bit muted because we have some adverse domestic medical plan experience in the quarter, cost us about 20 basis points. It's unfortunate but does happen from time to time. 
Looking towards the fourth quarter, if we hit 3% organic, and I'm not saying we will or we won't, we could hold margins flat with last year's fourth quarter or even squeak out a little expansion. 
As for the Risk Management segment, margin of 16.8% was right in line with our expectations that we shared with you at our investor meeting in September. This is really great work by the team. 
With a return to low single-digit organic in the fourth quarter, we seen margins in the lower 17% range. 
Next, let's move to integration. We're nearly finished. We're about done combining the 4 large acquisitions we did in the U.K. You can see it in the numbers. 
Third quarter integration costs were $0.04 this year versus $0.10 last year. And in the CFO commentary document, you'll see our fourth quarter estimates are -- for integration are at about $0.03, also down from $0.10 in the fourth quarter 2015. 
I'll be back in London in a couple of weeks and I look forward to congratulating the team for a really, really terrific effort over this last year. 
And also, I should -- deserves mentioning, too. Our Canadian merger is also substantially complete with their integration efforts. So it's really nice work to those folks up in Canada, too. 
Moving next to clean energy. We heard Pat say that we had another excellent third quarter, and we remain on track to deliver about 15% earnings growth over last year. Warmer weather helped us beat our forecast in the third quarter, but production might me a little lower in the fourth quarter because we haven't seen much cold weather yet. 
For example, you'll see that there's still a lot of green in the ivy at Wrigley tonight. And don't forget that our production has not only reduced our current year taxes, but we have also generated $430 million of credit that are sitting in our balance sheet. Effectively, that's a $430 million receivable from the government that will help us reduce our cash taxes paid for many, many years. We believe this has meaningful value for the shareholders. 
We also have about $230 million of available cash on our balance sheet. And as I've commented on before, we're making really good progress our bank account consolidation efforts that help us unlock available cash. 
So looking forward, you heard Pat say that our M&A pipeline is strong. We've got nice cash and nice cash flows developing. So I think that we can fund our activity for the remainder -- our M&A activity for the remainder of this year with cash and debt. 
As for 2017, I see even stronger cash flows, given integration will be behind us, and we won't have real estate moves that we have this year either. So we should be well positioned in 2017 to continue funding M&A with free cash and debt. 
So over my comments and another quarter and an excellent first 9 months of the year. Back to you, Pat.

headline: Arthur J Gallagher & Co., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. And I've said this many times. Personally, I was not in favor for our country to -- I was not a proponent of ObamaCare. But for our company, it's been the greatest thing in the world. So it's helped our merger and acquisition activity, and it's a ve
componenttext: Sure. And I've said this many times. Personally, I was not in favor for our country to -- I was not a proponent of ObamaCare. But for our company, it's been the greatest thing in the world. So it's helped our merger and acquisition activity, and it's a very, very complicated act. And what that does is create an awful lot of consulting effort for us. Our clients need a lot of help. The exchange is one of the things that we help our clients take a look at is they decide how they're going to treat the employee base. We look really at what we're doing from a consulting standpoint as a view of the total rewards that a client is going to use to maintain the employment of their best people. Really, when you come down to it, every business is all about people. And so you have to look at the entire list of benefits that you're going to provide and then figure out how you're going to actually work to help insurance into that. So exchange is popular. We've got probably about 15% of our clients out there taking a serious look at our exchange. And the rest are going to treat their insurance in a more traditional manner.

headline: Arthur J Gallagher & Co., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, domestically, we seeing a pretty stable market, which has been a stable market now for about 5 years, which is pretty unusual in my career. And I think it's a very good thing for our clients. The past is hard and soft market cycle that we went throu
componenttext: Well, domestically, we seeing a pretty stable market, which has been a stable market now for about 5 years, which is pretty unusual in my career. And I think it's a very good thing for our clients. The past is hard and soft market cycle that we went through for the last nearly 4 years, that doesn't benefits plans at all. So today, we've got a stable market domestically, a softer market internationally. So what I see is continued international 1% to 2% organic and hopefully closer to 4% to 5% domestically.

And then combined to that, I guess, if a deal flow does -- if these deals do not materialize, would you guys consider repurchasing shares sooner or rather? I know in the past you pointed to me end of '17. Could that be pushed forward if these deals do not materialize?

headline: Arthur J Gallagher & Co., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, let me be clear about this. First of all, we see 3 uses of our cash. And we've said this literally for more than the last decade. The first is we're going to buy brokers. Secondly, we're paying dividends, and third, we're going to do is buy our stock
componenttext: Yes, let me be clear about this. First of all, we see 3 uses of our cash. And we've said this literally for more than the last decade. The first is we're going to buy brokers. Secondly, we're paying dividends, and third, we're going to do is buy our stock back. If, in fact, for whatever reason, the acquisition activity slows down, and we're going to maintain our pricing discipline around our acquisition activity, been here before. 20 years ago, the banks push prices all the way through the roof, and we had a bit of slowdown in acquisition and activity while they were doing that. They got their belly full, private equity will eventually as well. But if we have excess cash, we will buy as stock back.

headline: Arthur J Gallagher & Co., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016

componenttext: That's for the multiple. If you look at it year-to-date, we're still about 7x. It's a little higher than 7 6. I don't see us -- there's multiple pressure out there or pricing pressure out there,, but I think that there's a lot of sellers out there that see us bringing substantial capabilities to them that are willing to saw it at a fair price. So those are the ones that we're going to after. Nice entrepreneurial tuck-in, folks that are willing to tick a fair price. And understand that together, we could be better.

headline: Arthur J Gallagher & Co., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016

componenttext: Okay, great. And then one other question, I noticed the revenue hit from currency could go up in the fourth quarter, although the EPS impact did not change. How do you think about, I guess, the hit between revenue and expenses? And what kind of currency hit we might see on earnings given where exchange rates are today as we start to think about 2017?

headline: Arthur J Gallagher & Co., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. The uptick from our September 23 guidance is because of the further strengthening of the dollar versus the pound. We do have a little bit of natural hedge in the U.K. because we have dollar-denominated revenues and pound-denominated expenses that ser
componenttext: Yes. The uptick from our September 23 guidance is because of the further strengthening of the dollar versus the pound. We do have a little bit of natural hedge in the U.K. because we have dollar-denominated revenues and pound-denominated expenses that service those revenues. So that's why we end up with a de minimis amount of impact on our EPS. And I see, right now, I don't know if the pound going lower or not, but I would say that, that trend will continue then that you would have an impact on revenues but not that much impact on EPS.

headline: Arthur J Gallagher & Co., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016

componenttext: This is Chai Gohil, on for Kai. First question on contingent and supplement. They have grown about 10% to 20% year-to-date. So could you talk a little bit about what's driving that?

headline: Arthur J Gallagher & Co., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think there's a couple of things. I think it's a great quick question. If you listen to our September 23 IR Day, I got on the high horse a little bit about supplementals and contingents versus base contingent -- base commissions and fees. I think t
componenttext: Yes, I think there's a couple of things. I think it's a great quick question. If you listen to our September 23 IR Day, I got on the high horse a little bit about supplementals and contingents versus base contingent -- base commissions and fees. I think that you should evaluate us using all-in organic or at least combine the base and supplementals because contingents can be a little bit volatile. Like I said in September, it's important for everybody to understand in 1 year, we may place a piece of -- place of policy with a carrier that have a strong base commissions and doesn't pay much in supplementals. The next year, that policy might be better for the customer to be placed with another carrier that pays higher supplementals at a lower base or maybe that carry would pay contingent step. We are completely in different in how that gets classified in our financial statements. As long as we're being compensated appropriately and with full transparency to our clients. We've got to do the right thing for our clients first, and we can't worry about where that gets posted in our financial statement. So we have had strong growth in supplementals and contingents. And I think that's basically the carrier's reference on that rather than paying base commissions at this point.

headline: Arthur J Gallagher & Co., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016

componenttext: The contingents and supplementals are a higher margin for us. How much have they affected us year-to-date? They might have helped margins. I got to pull up the number here and look at it. Maybe 15 basis point, something like that, of our 47 basis point margin expansion year-to-date, maybe 1/3 of that came from contingents.

componenttext: Just curious about, Pat, we've had 4 months post Brexit both. Now we've got the ability how we've seen the world is changing. Curious what you think this does to your U.K. operation, Lloyd's as a center of gravity? And is there going to be a movement to Ireland a little bit in the margin for you and the world?

headline: Arthur J Gallagher & Co., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, I don't think so. I think from an insurance perspective, I think it's going to be pretty much of a nonevent. Now that's early days. And obviously, we're monitoring all that. And I think the people in the city of London are very concerned with what thi
componenttext: No, I don't think so. I think from an insurance perspective, I think it's going to be pretty much of a nonevent. Now that's early days. And obviously, we're monitoring all that. And I think the people in the city of London are very concerned with what this means to the financial world. But from an insurance perspective, the expertise is in London. People have traded in that with that expertise for 300 years, and I don't see it moving.

headline: Arthur J Gallagher & Co., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016

componenttext: Yes, as I said, I don't see -- I really don't see in a reason for anyone to decide that they have to move. That's going to differ by people in different industries. But when it comes to insurance, the Lloyd's and London insurance community was incredibly strong before the EU and incredibly strong afterwards.

componenttext: Yes, I'm very bullish on 2017. And you're exactly right, Josh. You read my sentence well. Finishing up last year, I was little bit concerned. And we ended up having an incredible new business quarter in the fourth quarter last year. I'm really proud of the team. And I see the pipeline. We use Salesforce.com. I can look into that pipeline. Virtually, all our niches are strong. The business -- the new business opportunities are strong now. We've got to close them, we've got to close it out. But I think 2017 will be another record year.

headline: Arthur J Gallagher & Co., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
