componenttext: Very good. And a couple months ago, I asked you about health care exchanges, and you said that you were broadening your offering or you may be discussion with a couple health care exchange that currently you don't use. Can you talk about that broadening looks like? And maybe get some details on what your plans might be?

headline: Arthur J Gallagher & Co., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Yes, I appreciate the question very much. I'm really proud of our benefits team for how we position ourselves. I think we took a lot of heat 2 to 3 years ago about not investing heavily in the technology to create our own exchange. And what we said t
componenttext: Yes. Yes, I appreciate the question very much. I'm really proud of our benefits team for how we position ourselves. I think we took a lot of heat 2 to 3 years ago about not investing heavily in the technology to create our own exchange. And what we said to the investment community and to our clients at that time is that we're consultants. We're going to use exchanges where they're appropriate for our clients, and we're going to have 1 to 2 to maybe even more exchanges than that as appropriate for opportunities for clients to deal with their exposures. And we're going to remain consultants. We're not going to be products sales firm. And I think that's really worked out well for us. And as reviewed in the market as helping clients sort through all their opportunities. We have a very nice partnership with liaison, and we also have other exchanges that we're working with. And whatever is the most appropriate method of handling the clients exposures and health insurance, we're going to bring that to the table. And I think that's the right position for a consultant.

componenttext: Wholesale business, in general, is holding up pretty well. Could you tell us what's driving that despite the market getting more competitive? And are the standard cares beginning to inch in more in the last couple of months earlier than they were in the year?

headline: Arthur J Gallagher & Co., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'll take those backwards. The answer to your -- to the second question are the standard care inching in, the answer is yes. That puts pressure on us as a wholesaler. Retailers are given [indiscernible] in place to own business if they don't need a wholes
componenttext: I'll take those backwards. The answer to your -- to the second question are the standard care inching in, the answer is yes. That puts pressure on us as a wholesaler. Retailers are given [indiscernible] in place to own business if they don't need a wholesaler. So that's a headwind. You also have the headwind of the property rates. And I don't think that view is going to make different to property rates whatsoever. So we're going to continue face softness there. And the reason it's growing is because we're just really good at what we do and we're getting a lot more business both from our own retailers as well as people in the field.

headline: Arthur J Gallagher & Co., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. As far as the overall U.S. P&C market, commercial market, seems like the competitive levels is relatively rational. We're seeing rates down flat to maybe 2%, 3% [ph], not too bad. Are you seeing any change in the loss environment? Are they relativel
componenttext: Okay. As far as the overall U.S. P&C market, commercial market, seems like the competitive levels is relatively rational. We're seeing rates down flat to maybe 2%, 3% [ph], not too bad. Are you seeing any change in the loss environment? Are they relatively -- [indiscernible] relatively stable?

componenttext: Yes, I think so. We see total inflation, that continues. I don't see frequency going much. Automobile is a struggle. Every one of our carriers as we met with them is really shaking their heads at what's going on in the auto world. And it's interesting because what they're finding is they research their data is to distract drivers. You got everybody other devices out there crashing into each other.

componenttext: I may have missed this. Somebody asked about it before. But I'm just trying to get through. headline: Arthur J Gallagher & Co., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, good question. I think that there's 2 headwinds against our cash flow this year. The integration costs were still there. If you recall, we did some substantial moves in the U.K. as we consolidated operations there. And we're doing some big moves here
componenttext: Yes, good question. I think that there's 2 headwinds against our cash flow this year. The integration costs were still there. If you recall, we did some substantial moves in the U.K. as we consolidated operations there. And we're doing some big moves here in the U.S. as we move into a different Chicago-based building. So those costs are forced against cash flow this year. They will be there next year. So next year, we should have substantially more capacity than what you're seeing on the surface this year. I think M&A opportunities, there's tons of them there. And we are -- again, we just want to make sure we're picking the right partners to join us. But like Pat said, there's $250 [ph] million worth of deal sitting on the plate right now for the fourth quarter that we can see having some really nice success with those coming first part of the year.

headline: Arthur J Gallagher & Co., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016

componenttext: Traditionally, our first quarter is the smallest. So we could see a little low there. But also, it depends on how the election goes, you could have [indiscernible] moves against capital gain treatment on sale of businesses. So if that's the case, you could get a little bit of a rush to the door by the end of this year or certainly before the legislature gets working next -- when they reconvene in January. So I think there's good opportunities. There's still fair pricing out there. Immense market, people are seeing our capabilities. So if we have a little low right now, I wouldn't worry about it long term.

Just curious on a more overall basis, as opposed to the quarter, you're seeing fresher compensation both from like external in terms of the competitive dynamic, people interested in your people, other things, is there expectation that there might be compensation pressure going into 2017?

headline: Arthur J Gallagher & Co., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, that's a great question. If you recall back in our September 23 IR meeting day, I said that the rates is typically given in the latter half of the year. So some of that's hitting us right now here in the third and the fourth quarter. And then also we
componenttext: Yes, that's a great question. If you recall back in our September 23 IR meeting day, I said that the rates is typically given in the latter half of the year. So some of that's hitting us right now here in the third and the fourth quarter. And then also we had benefit expense that we had adverse development on our benefit program. And really, July and August, we didn't see that in September again. So that's pressure. Is there overall pressure in the marketplace? Yes. I think skill positions are expensive. They're going up in some of the IT security areas and others. there's always competition from really brokerage talent, too [indiscernible]. There's a little bit wage inflation. We have an opportunity to continue to push work into our centers of excellence in primarily in India and the Philippines. And so we have an opportunity to maybe reduce the impact of the domestic wage inflation by continuing to move offshore to our folks over there. So we have an opportunity to control, but there's an little bit of inflation out there in the marketplace.

headline: Arthur J Gallagher & Co., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016

componenttext: And finally, I recall a quarter -- a couple of quarters back that you mentioned that some on the international acquisitions that there was a plethora of bank accounts and trapped capital that you and your team were having to work through to aggregate and free up, if you will. I'm just wondering where that process is and is there still left to go?

headline: Arthur J Gallagher & Co., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Good progress is being made on that. We're down over 30% in our accounts. We've gotten a list of about another 60 accounts for another maybe 10% that are -- is going to be wound out by the end of the year, and then I think most of that by the mid par
componenttext: Yes. Good progress is being made on that. We're down over 30% in our accounts. We've gotten a list of about another 60 accounts for another maybe 10% that are -- is going to be wound out by the end of the year, and then I think most of that by the mid part of next year should be done. Part of that is bringing that excess cash internationally that's coming from that exercise. So we're making terrific progress. In Glasgow, where we do a lot of that work in September and the teams really got a good eye to get that done by the mid part of '17.

headline: Arthur J Gallagher & Co., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I do. I'll just make a quick comment. Thank you again for being with us today this morning. As we've done all year and in the past, our focus remains on executing on each component of our value-creation strategy. We're going to grow organically. We'r
componenttext:
Yes, I do. I'll just make a quick comment. Thank you again for being with us today this morning. As we've done all year and in the past, our focus remains on executing on each component of our value-creation strategy. We're going to grow organically. We're going to grow to acquiring the best brokers. We will improve our quality and our productivity. And we're going to continue to invest in our culture. 
I'm pleased with the first 3 quarters of 2016 and I'm excited about wrapping up 2016 and delivering a fantastic year next year, 2017. 
Thank you, everyone, for being with us this morning. We appreciate it.

headline: Arthur J Gallagher & Co., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good morning, and welcome to Arthur J. Gallagher & Co.'s Third Quarter 2016 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions]Today's call is being recorded. If you have any objections, you may disconnect at this time. Some of the comments made during th
componenttext:
Good morning, and welcome to Arthur J. Gallagher & Co.'s Third Quarter 2016 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions]
Today's call is being recorded. If you have any objections, you may disconnect at this time. Some of the comments made during this conference call, including answers given in response to questions, may constitute forward-looking statements within the meanings of the securities laws. These forward-looking statements are subject to the risks -- certain risks and uncertainties that will be discussed on this call and which are also described in the company's reports filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission. 
Actual results may differ materially from those discussed today. In addition, for reconciliation of the non-GAAP measures discussed on this call as well as other information regarding the use of these measures, please refer to the most recent earnings release and the other materials in the Investor Relations section of the company's website. 
It is now my pleasure to introduce J. Patrick Gallagher, Chairman, President and CEO of Arthur J. Gallagher & Co. Mr. Gallagher, you may begin.

headline: Arthur J Gallagher & Co., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I appreciate you joining us on our third quarter 2016 earnings call. Before I get down to some serious business, I have to start the call by saying go Cubs. With me this morning is Doug Howell, our Chief Financial Officer; as well as the heads of our oper
componenttext:
I appreciate you joining us on our third quarter 2016 earnings call. Before I get down to some serious business, I have to start the call by saying go Cubs. With me this morning is Doug Howell, our Chief Financial Officer; as well as the heads of our operating divisions. 
As I do every quarter, today, we're going to touch on the 4 key components of our strategy to drive shareholder value. Those 4 are, one, organic growth; two, growing our business through mergers and acquisitions; three, improving our quality and productivity; and fourth, maintaining a very unique Gallagher culture. 
The team executed on all 4 of these pillars this past quarter and on a year-to-date basis. 
First, let me start with organic growth. In our Brokerage segment, we posted all inorganic of 3.4%, up nicely over second quarter and right in line with our year-to-date organic of 3.6%. 
I recently returned from the Council of Insurance Agents and Brokers' Annual Meeting, where I met with more than 20 insurance carriers. Based on my conversations with carriers and consistent with our own experience in data, we continue to see the domestic pricing environment as stable. In fact, rate and exposure only had a little over 1 point of negative impact on our domestic property/casualty renewal results in the third quarter. 
I also spent time with our leadership teams in the U.K., Canada, Australia and New Zealand over the past few weeks, and pricing outside the U.S. remains broadly soft. So I see environment for us that could lead to organic growth in the fourth quarter similar to what we saw through the first 9 months of this year. Clearly, that depends on our new and lost business in the fourth quarter. And you may recall, we did have a very large new business month in December of 2015. 
Let me break down our organic around the world. I'm extremely pleased that every single division around the world posted organic growth in the quarter. Our sales culture is truly alive and well. 
Domestically, we saw about 4% organic growth. Within our retail P&C, operation up 3%; wholesale was up 1%; and benefits up nicely, over 5%. We did experience some incremental pressure within our wholesale unit, driven by continued weak property pricing in the quarter, with domestic casualty lines pricing remained similar to last year. 
Exposure units are showing some growth, offsetting some of the rate pressure. Property/casualty insurance market remains in a level where our production teams can grow organically and outperform. 
Our employee benefit consulting operation continues to see great new business opportunities. This business could typically grow us more in the second half of the year, and it did nicely here in the third quarter, and organic growth looks promising for the fourth quarter, too. 
In August, we released results of our annual Benefits Strategy & Benchmarking Survey, one of the large of its kind, with over 3,000 U.S. employers participating. This type of thought leadership and research is a great value to our clients and invaluable, and we are showing new prospects our best capabilities and insights. 
Let me move to our international brokerage operations. As I discussed in our July earnings call and our September 23 Investor Day, all of our operations globally are working together, with integrated sales plans and are living and breathing our unique Gallagher culture. This quarter, we saw 2% organic from our U.K. and Canadian teams and similar organic growth from our teams in New Zealand and Australia. This is simply excellent work as these international teams continue to grow through a rate and exposure headwind that is different than we are seeing here domestically. 
Next, let me move to merger and acquisition growth. The average size for the 7 acquisitions this quarter is $4 million of revenue at an average of 7.6x EBITDAC, putting our year-to-date multiple at 7x. Third quarter acquisition activity was a little slower than normal, but our pipeline remains very robust. 
We have approximately $90 million of revenue associated with agreed-upon term sheets and another $140 million of revenues with term sheets issued being prepared. While not all of these transactions will close, I do think we'll catch up to a more normal pace of transactions here in the fourth quarter. Our pipeline is as strong as ever and full of small, independent entrepreneurs with strong sales skills and excellent client relationships. 
Looking forward towards 2017, we will continue to focus on smaller tuck-in mergers, where we believe we can create value by giving these professionals full access to our capabilities, expertise and resources. 
I want to stop and thank all of our new partners for joining us and extend a very warm-up welcome to our growing Gallagher family of professionals. 
So how did we do through the first 3 quarters in our Brokerage segment? Over 9% total adjusted revenue growth, of which 3.6% is organic; adjusted EBITDAC growth of 11%; adjusted EBITDAC margin expansion of 47 basis points, and we continue to have an excellent merger and acquisition pipeline at fair multiples. 
I couldn't be more pleased with our 9 months' result in the Brokerage segment. 
Next, I'd like to move to our Risk Management segment, which is primarily Gallagher Bassett Services. Risk Management had a nice rebound from the second quarter, with organic back-end-positive territory. The turnaround from the second quarter is due to a smaller impact from performance bonus income and more normal patterns of the business. Client retention rates remain strong, and client satisfaction, both in the U.S. and internationally, continues to enhance GB's reputation and standing, with new sales results surpassing prior year. Going forward, for the Risk Management segment, we believe we can deliver positive organic in the fourth quarter and even better organic in 2017 as recent new business wins in Australia and the U.K. come online. 
Our value proposition of delivering superior claim outcomes for clients will continue to be a differentiator of this business versus our competitors. Further, Gallagher Bassett is an excellent complement to our brokerage operations as it is another business that helps our clients manage and mitigate their total cost of risk. 
Moving now to clean energy. Once again, we had an excellent quarter, and we are 3 quarters into delivering nearly 15% growth in annual after-tax earnings. 
Lastly, let me speak a bit on culture. I hope you had a chance to attend or to listen to our September Investor Day. Tom Tropp, our Chief Ethics and Sustainability Officer, discussed how our unique Gallagher culture drives shareholder value. I truly hope you could take away from Tom's discussion how our culture directly contributes to our organic growth, how it distinguishes us from others in a highly competitive merger environment and how it is the basis for our people coming together as a team to service clients consistently focused on doing the right thing. 
After the meeting, we were asked why culture wasn't in Tom's title. As a simple answer to that, the Gallagher culture is every single person's responsibility, and our culture continues to flourish. 
Okay. Another great quarter and an excellent first 9 months. Over to you, Doug.

headline: Arthur J Gallagher & Co., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: All right. Thanks, Pat, and good morning, everyone. Why he's like that, it's another excellent quarter by the team. Today, I have 5 items. We'll do a refresher on modeling revenues, some comments on margins. We'll do an update on winding down our integrat
componenttext:
All right. Thanks, Pat, and good morning, everyone. Why he's like that, it's another excellent quarter by the team. Today, I have 5 items. We'll do a refresher on modeling revenues, some comments on margins. We'll do an update on winding down our integration efforts. I'll move to -- and then I'll move to clean energy results, and I'll end with some comments on cash and capital management. 
Okay. Let's go to modeling revenues. I suggest using the CFO commentary document that we posted on our IR website as follows: starting on Page 2 of the CFO commentary. Adjust fourth quarter 2015 revenues for the impact of foreign currency exchange that we currently estimate at about $29 million. Remember, start by adjusting fourth quarter '15, not '16. Then apply your organic pick to that number. Next, layer in rollover M&A revenues from mergers that we completed in the first 9 months of this year. Page 5 of the CFO commentary shows that we estimate about $28 million rolling in, in the fourth quarter. 
And then, finally, make a pick -- make your own pick for new M&A revenue that might come from mergers we've closed here the fourth quarter. But please remember to assume a mid-quarter closing date. 
Following these steps should help you from over- or undershooting on revenues and avoid the related EPS impact. 
Okay, moving to margins. Adjusted brokerage EBITDAC margin expanded 20 basis points in the quarter. We continue to get some margin uplift from our international operations, but overall margin expansion was a bit muted because we have some adverse domestic medical plan experience in the quarter, cost us about 20 basis points. It's unfortunate but does happen from time to time. 
Looking towards the fourth quarter, if we hit 3% organic, and I'm not saying we will or we won't, we could hold margins flat with last year's fourth quarter or even squeak out a little expansion. 
As for the Risk Management segment, margin of 16.8% was right in line with our expectations that we shared with you at our investor meeting in September. This is really great work by the team. 
With a return to low single-digit organic in the fourth quarter, we seen margins in the lower 17% range. 
Next, let's move to integration. We're nearly finished. We're about done combining the 4 large acquisitions we did in the U.K. You can see it in the numbers. 
Third quarter integration costs were $0.04 this year versus $0.10 last year. And in the CFO commentary document, you'll see our fourth quarter estimates are -- for integration are at about $0.03, also down from $0.10 in the fourth quarter 2015. 
I'll be back in London in a couple of weeks and I look forward to congratulating the team for a really, really terrific effort over this last year. 
And also, I should -- deserves mentioning, too. Our Canadian merger is also substantially complete with their integration efforts. So it's really nice work to those folks up in Canada, too. 
Moving next to clean energy. We heard Pat say that we had another excellent third quarter, and we remain on track to deliver about 15% earnings growth over last year. Warmer weather helped us beat our forecast in the third quarter, but production might me a little lower in the fourth quarter because we haven't seen much cold weather yet. 
For example, you'll see that there's still a lot of green in the ivy at Wrigley tonight. And don't forget that our production has not only reduced our current year taxes, but we have also generated $430 million of credit that are sitting in our balance sheet. Effectively, that's a $430 million receivable from the government that will help us reduce our cash taxes paid for many, many years. We believe this has meaningful value for the shareholders. 
We also have about $230 million of available cash on our balance sheet. And as I've commented on before, we're making really good progress our bank account consolidation efforts that help us unlock available cash. 
So looking forward, you heard Pat say that our M&A pipeline is strong. We've got nice cash and nice cash flows developing. So I think that we can fund our activity for the remainder -- our M&A activity for the remainder of this year with cash and debt. 
As for 2017, I see even stronger cash flows, given integration will be behind us, and we won't have real estate moves that we have this year either. So we should be well positioned in 2017 to continue funding M&A with free cash and debt. 
So those are my comments and another great quarter and an excellent first 9 months of the year. Back to you, Pat.

componenttext: Yes. We're seeing -- we are seeing some claim volume growth, but it's not as strong as it was a year ago. We're about -- we're seeing about 1 -- about 1% growth in claims value -- volume or claims activity down from probably 2%, 2.5% at this time last year.

headline: Arthur J Gallagher & Co., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, sure. I've said this many times. Personally, I was not in favor for our country to -- I was not a proponent of ObamaCare. But for our company, it's been the greatest thing in the world. So it's helped our merger and acquisition activity, and it's a v
componenttext: Yes, sure. I've said this many times. Personally, I was not in favor for our country to -- I was not a proponent of ObamaCare. But for our company, it's been the greatest thing in the world. So it's helped our merger and acquisition activity, and it's a very, very complicated act. And what that does is create an awful lot of consulting opportunities for us. Our clients need a lot of help. The exchange is one of the things that we help our clients take a look at as they decide how they're going to treat their employee base. We look at the -- we look really at what we're doing from a consulting standpoint as a view of the total rewards that a client is going to use to maintain the employment of their best people. Really, when you come down to it, every business is all about people. And so you have to look at the entire list of benefits that you're going to provide and then figure out how you're going to actually work to help insurance into that. So exchange is popular. We've got probably about 15% of our clients out there taking a serious look at our exchange. And the rest are going to treat their insurance in a more traditional manner.

headline: Arthur J Gallagher & Co., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, domestically, we seeing a pretty stable market, which has been a stable market now for about 5 years, which is pretty unusual in my career. And I think it's a very good thing for our clients. The past is hard and soft market cycle that we live throu
componenttext: Well, domestically, we seeing a pretty stable market, which has been a stable market now for about 5 years, which is pretty unusual in my career. And I think it's a very good thing for our clients. The past is hard and soft market cycle that we live through for the last literally 4 years, that doesn't benefit plans at all. So today, we've got a stable market domestically, a softer market internationally. So what I see is continued international, 1% to 2% organic, and hopefully, closer to 4% to 5% domestically.

Or is it just taking longer, I guess, to get these deals fully signed? And then combined to that, I guess, if a deal flow does -- if these deals do not materialize, would you guys consider repurchasing shares sooner or rather? I know in the past you pointed to me end of '17. Could that be pushed forward if these deals do not materialize?

headline: Arthur J Gallagher & Co., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, let me be clear about this. First of all, we see 3 uses of our cash. And we've said this literally for more than the last decade. The first is we're going to buy brokers. Secondly, we're paying dividends. And third thing we're going to do is buy our
componenttext: Yes, let me be clear about this. First of all, we see 3 uses of our cash. And we've said this literally for more than the last decade. The first is we're going to buy brokers. Secondly, we're paying dividends. And third thing we're going to do is buy our stock back. So if, in fact, for whatever reason, the acquisition activity slows down and we're going to maintain our pricing discipline around our acquisition activity, been here before. 20 years ago, the banks pushed prices all the way through the roof, and we had a bit of a slowdown in acquisition activity while they were doing that. They got their belly full. Private equity will eventually as well. But if we have excess cash, we will buy our stock back.

headline: Arthur J Gallagher & Co., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: As for the multiple, if you look at it year-to-date, we're still about 7x. It's a little higher, 7.6. I don't see us -- there's multiple pressure out there or pricing pressure out there, but I think there's a lot of sellers out there that see us bringing
componenttext: As for the multiple, if you look at it year-to-date, we're still about 7x. It's a little higher, 7.6. I don't see us -- there's multiple pressure out there or pricing pressure out there, but I think there's a lot of sellers out there that see us bringing substantial capabilities to them that are willing to sell at a fair price. So those are the ones that we're going to be going after. Nice entrepreneurial tuck-in, folks that are willing to take a fair price and understand that together, we can be better.

headline: Arthur J Gallagher & Co., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, great. And then one other question. I noticed the revenue hit from currency did go up in the fourth quarter, although the EPS impact did not change. How do you think about, I guess, the hit between revenue and expenses? And what kind of currency hit
componenttext: Okay, great. And then one other question. I noticed the revenue hit from currency did go up in the fourth quarter, although the EPS impact did not change. How do you think about, I guess, the hit between revenue and expenses? And what kind of currency hit we might see on earnings as we start -- given where exchange rates are today as we start to think about 2017?

headline: Arthur J Gallagher & Co., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. The uptick from our September 23 guidance is because of the further strengthening of the dollar versus the pound. We do have a little bit of a natural hedge in the U.K. because we have dollar-denominated revenues and pound-denominated expenses that s
componenttext: Yes. The uptick from our September 23 guidance is because of the further strengthening of the dollar versus the pound. We do have a little bit of a natural hedge in the U.K. because we have dollar-denominated revenues and pound-denominated expenses that service those revenues. So that's why we end up with a de minimis amount of impact on our EPS. And I see, right now, I don't know if the pound going lower or not, but I would say that, that trend would continue then that you could have an impact on revenues but not that much impact on EPS.

headline: Arthur J Gallagher & Co., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question is coming from Kai Pan of Morgan Stanley.
componenttext: Our next question is coming from Kai Pan of Morgan Stanley.

headline: Arthur J Gallagher & Co., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is Chai Gohil for Kai. First question on contingents and supplements. They have grown about 10% to 20% year-to-date. So could you talk a little bit of what's driving that?
componenttext: This is Chai Gohil for Kai. First question on contingents and supplements. They have grown about 10% to 20% year-to-date. So could you talk a little bit of what's driving that?

headline: Arthur J Gallagher & Co., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think there's a couple of things there. I think it's a great question. If you listened to our September 23 IR Day, I got on my high horse a little bit about supplementals and contingents versus base contingent -- or base commissions and fees. I thi
componenttext: Yes, I think there's a couple of things there. I think it's a great question. If you listened to our September 23 IR Day, I got on my high horse a little bit about supplementals and contingents versus base contingent -- or base commissions and fees. I think that you should evaluate us using all-in organic or at least combine the base and supplementals because contingents can be a little bit volatile. Like I said in September, it's important for everybody to understand in 1 year, we may place a piece of -- place a policy with a carrier that has strong base commissions and doesn't pay much in supplementals. But next year, that policy might be better for the customer to be placed with another carrier that pays higher supplementals at a lower base or maybe that carrier would pay a contingent instead. We are completely indifferent in how that gets classified in our financial statements as long as we're being compensated appropriately and with full transparency to our clients. We've got to do the right thing for our clients first, and we can't worry about where that gets posted in our financial statements. So we have had strong growth in supplementals and contingents. And I think that's basically the carrier's preference on that rather than paying base commissions at this point.

headline: Arthur J Gallagher & Co., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. So I guess, one of your peers did comment that the contingents could decline as part of their declines. So how do you see that in '17?
componenttext: Okay. So I guess, one of your peers did comment that the contingents could decline as part of their declines. So how do you see that in '17?

headline: Arthur J Gallagher & Co., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I don't see much of a difference in our contingents. We're getting paid in the first part of '17 based on our '16 performance.
componenttext: Well, I don't see much of a difference in our contingents. We're getting paid in the first part of '17 based on our '16 performance.

headline: Arthur J Gallagher & Co., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: And have -- I think contingents have a higher margin. So can you quantify how much they could have held year-to-date?
componenttext: And have -- I think contingents have a higher margin. So can you quantify how much they could have held year-to-date?

headline: Arthur J Gallagher & Co., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: The contingents and supplementals are a higher margin for us. How much have they affected us year-to-date? They might have helped margins. I got to pull up the number here and look at it. But it's at maybe 15 basis points, something like that. Of our 47 b
componenttext: The contingents and supplementals are a higher margin for us. How much have they affected us year-to-date? They might have helped margins. I got to pull up the number here and look at it. But it's at maybe 15 basis points, something like that. Of our 47 basis point margin expansion year-to-date, maybe 1/3 of that came from contingents.

headline: Arthur J Gallagher & Co., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question is coming from Bob Glasspiegel of Janney Montgomery Scott.
componenttext: Our next question is coming from Bob Glasspiegel of Janney Montgomery Scott.

headline: Arthur J Gallagher & Co., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just curious about, Pat, we've had 4 months post Brexit vote. And now we've got the ability of seeing how the world is changing. Curious what you think this does to your U.K. operation, Lloyd's as a center of gravity. And is there going to be a movement t
componenttext: Just curious about, Pat, we've had 4 months post Brexit vote. And now we've got the ability of seeing how the world is changing. Curious what you think this does to your U.K. operation, Lloyd's as a center of gravity. And is there going to be a movement to Ireland a little bit on the margin for you and the world?

headline: Arthur J Gallagher & Co., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, I don't think so. I think from an insurance perspective, I think it's going to be pretty much of a nonevent. Now that's early days, and obviously, we're monitoring all that. And I think the people in the city of London are very concerned with what thi
componenttext: No, I don't think so. I think from an insurance perspective, I think it's going to be pretty much of a nonevent. Now that's early days, and obviously, we're monitoring all that. And I think the people in the city of London are very concerned with what this means to the financial world. But from an insurance perspective, the expertise is in London. People have traded in that with that expertise for 300 years, and I don't see it moving.

headline: Arthur J Gallagher & Co., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: And any impact to sort of U.K. business flow that you've seen to date?
componenttext: And any impact to sort of U.K. business flow that you've seen to date?

headline: Arthur J Gallagher & Co., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: No. Actually, none. The only real impact has been the impact of the sterling decline.
componenttext: No. Actually, none. The only real impact has been the impact of the sterling decline.

headline: Arthur J Gallagher & Co., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Right. Yes, that's consistent with my perspective that -- I mean, U.K. -- to leave U.K. becomes a little bit more painful with currency where it is, that you're definitely moving to a higher expense.
componenttext: Right. Yes, that's consistent with my perspective that -- I mean, U.K. -- to leave U.K. becomes a little bit more painful with currency where it is, that you're definitely moving to a higher expense.

headline: Arthur J Gallagher & Co., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I don't see -- I really don't see any reason for anyone to decide that they have to move. That's going to differ by people in different industries. But when it comes to insurance, the Lloyd's and London insurance community was incredibly strong befor
componenttext: Yes, I don't see -- I really don't see any reason for anyone to decide that they have to move. That's going to differ by people in different industries. But when it comes to insurance, the Lloyd's and London insurance community was incredibly strong before the EU and they will be strong afterwards.

headline: Arthur J Gallagher & Co., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question is coming from Josh Shanker of Deutsche Bank.
componenttext: Our next question is coming from Josh Shanker of Deutsche Bank.

headline: Arthur J Gallagher & Co., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: So I don't have to remind you a little more -- a little less than a year ago, you guys might have made some comments that got people concerned about 2016. It's been a great 2016 for Gallagher. Let's talk about 2017 now. Compared to how you felt about the
componenttext: So I don't have to remind you a little more -- a little less than a year ago, you guys might have made some comments that got people concerned about 2016. It's been a great 2016 for Gallagher. Let's talk about 2017 now. Compared to how you felt about the year ahead last year, how are you feeling right now? I'm not asking for guidance. But your gut was very concerned, I think, a year ago. Turned out to be probably overconcerned. Do you have any thoughts on the year-over-year change?

headline: Arthur J Gallagher & Co., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I'm very bullish on 2017. And you're exactly right, Josh. You read my sentence well. Finishing up last year, I was little bit concerned and we ended up having an incredible new business quarter in the fourth quarter last year. I'm really proud of the
componenttext: Yes, I'm very bullish on 2017. And you're exactly right, Josh. You read my sentence well. Finishing up last year, I was little bit concerned and we ended up having an incredible new business quarter in the fourth quarter last year. I'm really proud of the team. And I see the pipeline. We use Salesforce.com. I can look into that pipeline. Virtually, all our niches are strong. The business -- the new business opportunities are strong now. We've got to close them, we've got to close it out. But I think 2017 will be another record year.

headline: Arthur J Gallagher & Co., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Very good. And a couple of months ago, I asked you about health care exchanges and you said that you were broadening your offering or you may be were in discussion with a couple health care streams that currently you don't use. Can you talk about what tha
componenttext: Very good. And a couple of months ago, I asked you about health care exchanges and you said that you were broadening your offering or you may be were in discussion with a couple health care streams that currently you don't use. Can you talk about what that broadening is like and maybe give us some details on what your plans might be?

headline: Arthur J Gallagher & Co., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. In fact, Josh, I appreciate the question very much. I'm really proud of our benefits team for how we position ourselves. I think we took a lot of heat 2 to 3 years ago about not investing heavily in the technology to create our own exchange. And what
componenttext: Yes. In fact, Josh, I appreciate the question very much. I'm really proud of our benefits team for how we position ourselves. I think we took a lot of heat 2 to 3 years ago about not investing heavily in the technology to create our own exchange. And what we said to the investment community and to our clients at that time is that we're consultants. We're going to use exchanges where they're appropriate for our clients, and we're going to have 1 to 2 to maybe even more exchanges than that as appropriate for opportunities for clients to deal with their exposures. And we're going to remain consultants. We're not going to be a product sales firm. And I think that's really worked out well for us as we've viewed in the market as helping clients sort through all their opportunities. We have a very nice partnership with Liazon, and we also have other exchanges that we're working with. And whatever is the most appropriate method of handling the clients' exposures in health insurance, we're going to bring that to the table. And I think that's the right position for a consultant.

headline: Arthur J Gallagher & Co., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: What do the other vendors you're working with do for you that Liazon doesn't do for you?
componenttext: What do the other vendors you're working with do for you that Liazon doesn't do for you?

componenttext: Different geographies, different people on the platform, different -- just a different approach.

headline: Arthur J Gallagher & Co., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016

componenttext: And are they competitive models? Or is there an obvious thing that if a client, say, needs an exchange, we're going to go through this provider versus client B who has these issues it's obvious that they're a Liazon customer?

headline: Arthur J Gallagher & Co., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, that's exactly right.
componenttext: Yes, that's exactly right.

componenttext: Just have a numbers-related question for you, Doug. The MD&A schedule that you gave in CFO commentary is great. componenttext: Let me see if I can dig that out. If you go to, I guess, Page 5, of that commentary sheet, I'll grab that here, the rollover impact into next year. Right now, we've closed deals totaling about $97 million. So I think just what we got in the pipeline, $50 million of it should show up next year, plus whatever we close in the fourth quarter will show up also.

headline: Arthur J Gallagher & Co., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: And as you said, the fourth quarter looks strong?
componenttext: And as you said, the fourth quarter looks strong?

componenttextpreview: That'll be 10 months of whatever we close this fourth quarter or so. Say again?
componenttext: That'll be 10 months of whatever we close this fourth quarter or so. Say again?

headline: Arthur J Gallagher & Co., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, great. And then if I could just shift to the follow-up on the contingents and supplemental commission question. Just on a bigger picture thought because I get there what you're trying to get at, that you don't really care how a client may be compens
componenttext: Okay, great. And then if I could just shift to the follow-up on the contingents and supplemental commission question. Just on a bigger picture thought because I get there what you're trying to get at, that you don't really care how a client may be compensating you guys. But can you just talk -- is the commission percentage we use sort of a back of the envelope 10%, if that sounds about right to you? But is the overall commission percentage, when you add in the contingents and supplementals, about the same more, less, than you're seeing?

headline: Arthur J Gallagher & Co., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I guess, I don't understand the question, Quentin. Do it again. Is the commission more or less if we have a supplemental?
componenttext: I guess, I don't understand the question, Quentin. Do it again. Is the commission more or less if we have a supplemental?

headline: Arthur J Gallagher & Co., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: What I'm saying is you're saying that the client is paying you a commission plus a supplemental on top of it. Would that overall number equate to the 10%, whether you had the supplemental or you didn't have the supplemental? It's more about we're going to
componenttext: What I'm saying is you're saying that the client is paying you a commission plus a supplemental on top of it. Would that overall number equate to the 10%, whether you had the supplemental or you didn't have the supplemental? It's more about we're going to get sort of a percentage of the overall premium and that percentage is held fairly constant?

headline: Arthur J Gallagher & Co., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: No. I think if you have a supplemental or a contingent, you'll probably get an extra 2 points.  And that's very important. That's completely transparent with the client, and they agree that we can accept that.
componenttext: No. I think if you have a supplemental or a contingent, you'll probably get an extra 2 points.  And that's very important. That's completely transparent with the client, and they agree that we can accept that.

headline: Arthur J Gallagher & Co., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question is coming from Adam Klauber of William Blair.
componenttext: Our next question is coming from Adam Klauber of William Blair.

headline: Arthur J Gallagher & Co., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Wholesale business, in general, is holding up pretty well. Could you tell us what's driving that despite the market getting more competitive? And are the standard carriers beginning to inch in more in the last couple of months than they were earlier in th
componenttext: Wholesale business, in general, is holding up pretty well. Could you tell us what's driving that despite the market getting more competitive? And are the standard carriers beginning to inch in more in the last couple of months than they were earlier in the year?

headline: Arthur J Gallagher & Co., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'll take those backwards. The answer to your -- to the second question on are the standard carriers inching in, the answer is yes. That puts pressure on us as a wholesaler. Retailers are given to wanting to place their own business if they don't need a w
componenttext: I'll take those backwards. The answer to your -- to the second question on are the standard carriers inching in, the answer is yes. That puts pressure on us as a wholesaler. Retailers are given to wanting to place their own business if they don't need a wholesaler. So that's a headwind. You also have the headwind of the property rates. And I don't think that view is going to make any difference to those property rates whatsoever. So we're going to continue to face softness there. And the reason it's growing is because we're just really good at what we do and we're getting a lot more business both from our own retailers as well as people in the field.

headline: Arthur J Gallagher & Co., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. As far as the overall U.S. P&C market, commercial market, seems like the competitive level is relatively rational. We're hearing rates down flat to maybe 2%, 3%, not too bad. Are you seeing any change in the loss environment? Are they still relative
componenttext: Okay. As far as the overall U.S. P&C market, commercial market, seems like the competitive level is relatively rational. We're hearing rates down flat to maybe 2%, 3%, not too bad. Are you seeing any change in the loss environment? Are they still relatively -- are losses still relatively stable?

headline: Arthur J Gallagher & Co., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think so. We see tort inflation, that continues. I don't see frequency going much. Automobile is a struggle. Every one of our carriers, as we met with them, is really shaking their heads at what's going on in the auto world. And it's interesting be
componenttext: Yes, I think so. We see tort inflation, that continues. I don't see frequency going much. Automobile is a struggle. Every one of our carriers, as we met with them, is really shaking their heads at what's going on in the auto world. And it's interesting because what they're finding as they research their data is distracted drivers. You got everybody on their devices out there crashing into each other.

headline: Arthur J Gallagher & Co., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Right, right. And you mentioned tort inflation. Could you just maybe give us a bit more color on that, what you're hearing?
componenttext: Right, right. And you mentioned tort inflation. Could you just maybe give us a bit more color on that, what you're hearing?

headline: Arthur J Gallagher & Co., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, what we're seeing, just that it's the classic litigation environment. I mean, I don't have a percentage to put on it, Adam, but litigation continues to grow and the costs of that litigation are more expensive.
componenttext: Well, what we're seeing, just that it's the classic litigation environment. I mean, I don't have a percentage to put on it, Adam, but litigation continues to grow and the costs of that litigation are more expensive.

headline: Arthur J Gallagher & Co., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Our next question is coming from Charles Sebaski of BMO Capital Markets.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Our next question is coming from Charles Sebaski of BMO Capital Markets.

headline: Arthur J Gallagher & Co., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I may have missed this if somebody asked about it before. But I'm just trying to get through. I know you guys have repurchased some shares to offset some issuance, but the M&A activity to date would seem below your capacity and so would seem like there's
componenttext: I may have missed this if somebody asked about it before. But I'm just trying to get through. I know you guys have repurchased some shares to offset some issuance, but the M&A activity to date would seem below your capacity and so would seem like there's -- and unless there's a particularly heavy fourth quarter, that there's capacity for share reduction. And I'm just curious if I'm adding that up properly in terms of your cash flow generation and what you're doing.

headline: Arthur J Gallagher & Co., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, good question. I think that there's 2 headwinds against our cash flow this year. The integration costs were still there. And if you recall, we did some substantial moves in the U.K. as we consolidated operations there. And we're doing some big moves
componenttext: Yes, good question. I think that there's 2 headwinds against our cash flow this year. The integration costs were still there. And if you recall, we did some substantial moves in the U.K. as we consolidated operations there. And we're doing some big moves here in the U.S. as we move into a different Chicago-based building. So those costs had forced against cash flows this year. They won't be there next year. So next year, we should have substantially more capacity than what you're seeing on the surface this year. I think M&A opportunities, there's tons of them there. And we are -- again, we just want to make sure we're picking the right partners to join us. But like Pat said, there's $250 million worth of deals sitting on the plate right now for the fourth quarter that we can see having some really nice success with those coming into the first part of the year.

headline: Arthur J Gallagher & Co., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Traditionally, our first quarter is the smallest. So we could see a little low there. But also, it depends on how the election goes, you could have a sentiment that moves against capital gain treatment on sale of businesses. So if that's the case, you cou
componenttext: Traditionally, our first quarter is the smallest. So we could see a little low there. But also, it depends on how the election goes, you could have a sentiment that moves against capital gain treatment on sale of businesses. So if that's the case, you could get a little bit of a rush to the door by the end of this year or certainly before the legislature gets working next -- when they reconvene in January. So I think there's good opportunities. There's still fair pricing out there. It's an immense market. People are seeing our capabilities. So if we have a little low right now, I wouldn't worry about it long term.

headline: Arthur J Gallagher & Co., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. But if I thought about your guidance here this year kind of $90 million required revenue year-to-date, outside of kind of the Brexit and the headquarter relocation, would've thought like at that level, you -- we probably would have seen a bit more i
componenttext: Okay. But if I thought about your guidance here this year kind of $90 million required revenue year-to-date, outside of kind of the Brexit and the headquarter relocation, would've thought like at that level, you -- we probably would have seen a bit more in share repurchase activity. Is that...

headline: Arthur J Gallagher & Co., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: No. I think you that if you look at my commentary, if you go back maybe the beginning of the year, we had $100 million of cash on our balance sheet. We know we've got to $230 million, something like that. Some of that's overseas. So I don't -- one thing w
componenttext: No. I think you that if you look at my commentary, if you go back maybe the beginning of the year, we had $100 million of cash on our balance sheet. We know we've got to $230 million, something like that. Some of that's overseas. So I don't -- one thing we don't want to do is repatriate that money since we got a lot of acquisition activities overseas. So that might be what's causing your tort to poke out in your models.

headline: Arthur J Gallagher & Co., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then more on the operational side. I know it's not huge numbers in -- but it seems like the compensation expense, picking up a little bit. Just curious, on a more overall basis as opposed to the quarter, are you seeing fresher compensation, both
componenttext: Okay. And then more on the operational side. I know it's not huge numbers in -- but it seems like the compensation expense, picking up a little bit. Just curious, on a more overall basis as opposed to the quarter, are you seeing fresher compensation, both from like external in terms of the competitive dynamic, people interested in your people, other things? Is there expectation that there might be compensation pressure going into 2017?

headline: Arthur J Gallagher & Co., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, that's a great question. If you recall back in our September 23 IR meeting day, I said that the raise is typically get -- or given in the latter half of the year. So some of that's hitting us right now here in the third and the fourth quarter. And th
componenttext: Yes, that's a great question. If you recall back in our September 23 IR meeting day, I said that the raise is typically get -- or given in the latter half of the year. So some of that's hitting us right now here in the third and the fourth quarter. And then also we had benefit expense. We had a little adverse development on our benefit program in really July and August. We didn't see that in September again. So that's pressure. Is there overall pressure in the marketplace? Yes. I think skill positions are expensive. They're going up in some of the IT security areas and other areas. And there's always competition for really good brokerage talent, too, that's out there. There's a little wage inflation. We have an opportunity to continue to push work into our centers of excellence in primarily in India and the Philippines. And so we have an opportunity to maybe reduce the impact of the domestic wage inflation by continuing to move offshore to our folks over there. So we have an opportunity to control it, but there is a little bit of inflation out there in the marketplace.

headline: Arthur J Gallagher & Co., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then finally, I recall a quarter -- a couple of quarters back that you mentioned that on some of the international acquisitions, that there was a plethora of bank accounts and trapped capital that you and your team were having to work through to
componenttext: Okay. And then finally, I recall a quarter -- a couple of quarters back that you mentioned that on some of the international acquisitions, that there was a plethora of bank accounts and trapped capital that you and your team were having to work through to aggregate and free up, if you will. I'm just wondering where that process is and is there still left to go on?

headline: Arthur J Gallagher & Co., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Good progress is being made on that. We're down over 30% in our accounts. We've got a list of about another 60 accounts for another maybe 10% that are -- is going to be wound out by the end of the year. And then I think most of that by the midpart of
componenttext: Yes. Good progress is being made on that. We're down over 30% in our accounts. We've got a list of about another 60 accounts for another maybe 10% that are -- is going to be wound out by the end of the year. And then I think most of that by the midpart of next year should be done. Part of that is bringing up that excess cash internationally that's coming from that exercise. So we're making terrific progress. I was in Glasgow, where we do a lot of that work in September, and the team's really got a good eye to get that done by the midpart of '17.

headline: Arthur J Gallagher & Co., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: We're showing no additional questions at this time. Do you have any additional or closing comments today?
componenttext: We're showing no additional questions at this time. Do you have any additional or closing comments today?

headline: Arthur J Gallagher & Co., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I do. I'll just make a quick comment. Thank you again for being with us this morning. As we've done all year and in the past, our focus remains on executing on each component of our value-creation strategy. We're going to grow organically. We're goin
componenttext:
Yes, I do. I'll just make a quick comment. Thank you again for being with us this morning. As we've done all year and in the past, our focus remains on executing on each component of our value-creation strategy. We're going to grow organically. We're going to grow through acquiring the best brokers. We will improve our quality and our productivity. And we're going to continue to invest in our culture. 
I'm pleased with the first 3 quarters of 2016, and I'm excited about wrapping up 2016 and delivering a fantastic year next year, 2017. 
Thank you, everyone, for being with us this morning. We appreciate it.

headline: Arthur J Gallagher & Co., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Ladies and gentlemen, thank you for your participation. This concludes today's teleconference. You may disconnect your lines at this time, and have a wonderful day.
componenttext: Ladies and gentlemen, thank you for your participation. This concludes today's teleconference. You may disconnect your lines at this time, and have a wonderful day.

headline: Arthur J Gallagher & Co., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good morning, and welcome to Arthur J. Gallagher & Co.'s Third Quarter 2016 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions]Today's call is being recorded. If you have any objections, you may disconnect at this time. Some of the comments made during th
componenttext:
Good morning, and welcome to Arthur J. Gallagher & Co.'s Third Quarter 2016 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions]
Today's call is being recorded. If you have any objections, you may disconnect at this time. Some of the comments made during this conference call, including answers given in response to questions, may constitute forward-looking statements within the meanings of the securities laws. These forward-looking statements are subject to the risks -- certain risks and uncertainties that will be discussed on this call and which are also described in the company's reports filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission. 
Actual results may differ materially from those discussed today. In addition, for reconciliation of the non-GAAP measures discussed on this call as well as other information regarding the use of these measures, please refer to the most recent earnings release and the other materials in the Investor Relations section of the company's website. 
It is now my pleasure to introduce J. Patrick Gallagher, Chairman, President and CEO of Arthur J. Gallagher & Co. Mr. Gallagher, you may begin.

headline: Arthur J Gallagher & Co., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I appreciate you joining us on our third quarter 2016 earnings call. Before I get down to some serious business, I have to start the call by saying go Cubs. With me this morning is Doug Howell, our Chief Financial Officer; as well as the heads of our oper
componenttext:
I appreciate you joining us on our third quarter 2016 earnings call. Before I get down to some serious business, I have to start the call by saying go Cubs. With me this morning is Doug Howell, our Chief Financial Officer; as well as the heads of our operating divisions. 
As I do every quarter, today we're going to touch on the 4 key components of our strategy to drive shareholder value. Those 4 are, one, organic growth; two, growing our business through mergers and acquisitions; three, improving our quality and productivity; and fourth, maintaining a very unique Gallagher culture. 
The team executed on all 4 of these pillars this past quarter and on a year-to-date basis. 
First, let me start with organic growth. In our Brokerage segment, we posted all inorganic of 3.4%, up nicely over second quarter and right in line with our year-to-date organic of 3.6%. 
I recently returned from the Council of Insurance Agents and Brokers' Annual Meeting, where I met with more than 20 insurance carriers. Based on my conversations with carriers and consistent with our own experience in data, we continue to see the domestic pricing environment as stable. In fact, rate and exposure only had a little over 1 point of negative impact on our domestic property/casualty renewal results in the third quarter. 
I also spent time with our leadership teams in the U.K., Canada, Australia and New Zealand over the past few weeks, and pricing outside the U.S. remains broadly soft. So I see an environment for us that could lead to organic growth in the fourth quarter similar to what we saw through the first 9 months of this year. Clearly, that depends on our new and lost business in the fourth quarter. And you may recall, we did have a very large new business month in December of 2015. 
Let me break down our organic around the world. I'm extremely pleased that every single division around the world posted organic growth in the quarter. Our sales culture is truly alive and well. 
Domestically, we saw about 4% organic growth. Within our retail P&C, operation up 3%; wholesale was up 1%; and benefits up nicely, over 5%. We did experience some incremental pressure within our wholesale unit, driven by continued weak property pricing in the quarter, with domestic casualty lines pricing remained similar to last year. 
Exposure units are showing some growth, offsetting some of the rate pressure. Property/casualty insurance market remains in a level where our production teams can grow organically and outperform. 
Our employee benefit consulting operation continues to see great new business opportunities. This business could typically grows more in the second half of the year, and it did nicely here in the third quarter, and organic growth looks promising for the fourth quarter, too. 
In August, we released the results of our annual Benefits Strategy & Benchmarking Survey, one of the large of its kind, with over 3,000 U.S. employers participating. This type of thought leadership and research is a great value to our clients and invaluable when we are showing new prospects our best capabilities and insights. 
Let me move to our international brokerage operations. As I discussed in our July earnings call and our September 23 Investor Day, all of our operations globally are working together, with integrated sales plans and are living and breathing our unique Gallagher culture. This quarter, we saw 2% organic from our U.K. and Canadian teams and similar organic growth from our teams in New Zealand and Australia. This is simply excellent work as these international teams continue to grow through a rate and exposure headwind that is stiffer than we are seeing here domestically. 
Next, let me move to merger and acquisition growth. The average size for the 7 acquisitions this quarter is $4 million of revenue at an average of 7.6x EBITDAC, putting our year-to-date multiple at 7x. Third quarter acquisition activity was a little slower than normal, but our pipeline remains very robust. 
We have approximately $90 million of revenue associated with agreed-upon term sheets and another $140 million of revenues with term sheets issued or being prepared. While not all of these transactions will close, I do think we'll catch up to a more normal pace of transactions here in the fourth quarter. Our pipeline is as strong as ever and full of small, independent entrepreneurs with strong sales skills and excellent client relationships. 
Looking forward towards 2017, we will continue to focus on smaller tuck-in mergers, where we believe we can create value by giving these professionals full access to our capabilities, expertise and resources. 
I wanted to stop and thank all of our new partners for joining us and extend a very warm-up welcome to our growing Gallagher family of professionals. 
So how did we do through the first 3 quarters in our Brokerage segment? Over 9% total adjusted revenue growth, of which 3.6% is organic; adjusted EBITDAC growth of 11%; adjusted EBITDAC margin expansion of 47 basis points, and we continue to have an excellent merger and acquisition pipeline at fair multiples. 
I couldn't be more pleased with our 9 months' result in the Brokerage segment. 
Next, I'd like to move to our Risk Management segment, which is primarily Gallagher Bassett Services. Risk Management had a nice rebound from the second quarter, with organic back in positive territory. The turnaround from the second quarter is due to a smaller impact from performance bonus income and more normal patterns of new business. Client retention rates remain strong, and client satisfaction, both in the U.S. and internationally, continues to enhance GB's reputation and standing, with new sales results surpassing prior year. Going forward, for the Risk Management segment, we believe we can deliver positive organic in the fourth quarter and even better organic in 2017 as recent new business wins in Australia and the U.K. come online. 
Our value proposition of delivering superior claim outcomes for clients will continue to be a differentiator of this business versus our competitors. Further, Gallagher Bassett is an excellent complement to our brokerage operations as it is another business that helps our clients manage and mitigate their total cost of risk. 
Moving now to clean energy. Once again, we had an excellent quarter, and we are 3 quarters into delivering nearly 15% growth in annual after-tax earnings. 
Lastly, let me speak a bit on culture. I hope you had a chance to attend or to listen to our September Investor Day. Tom Tropp, our Chief Ethics and Sustainability Officer, discussed how our unique Gallagher culture drives shareholder value. I truly hope you could take away from Tom's discussion how our culture directly contributes to our organic growth, how it distinguishes us from others in a highly competitive merger environment and how it is the basis for our people coming together as a team to service clients consistently focused on doing the right thing. 
After the meeting, we were asked why culture wasn't in Tom's title. As a simple answer to that, the Gallagher culture is every single person's responsibility, and our culture continues to flourish. 
Okay. Another great quarter and an excellent first 9 months. Over to you, Doug.

headline: Arthur J Gallagher & Co., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: All right. Thanks, Pat, and good morning, everyone. Why he's like that, it's another excellent quarter by the team. Today, I have 5 items. We'll do a refresher on modeling revenues, some comments on margins. We'll do an update on winding down our integrat
componenttext:
All right. Thanks, Pat, and good morning, everyone. Why he's like that, it's another excellent quarter by the team. Today, I have 5 items. We'll do a refresher on modeling revenues, some comments on margins. We'll do an update on winding down our integration efforts. I'll move to -- and then I'll move to clean energy results, and I'll end with some comments on cash and capital management. 
Okay. Let's go to modeling revenues. I suggest using the CFO commentary document that we posted on our IR website as follows: starting on Page 2 of the CFO commentary. Adjust fourth quarter 2015 revenues for the impact of foreign currency exchange that we currently estimate at about $29 million. Remember, start by adjusting fourth quarter '15, not '16. Then apply your organic pick to that number. Next, layer in rollover M&A revenues from mergers that we completed in the first 9 months of this year. Page 5 of the CFO commentary shows that we estimate about $28 million rolling in, in the fourth quarter. 
And then, finally, make a pick -- make your own pick for new M&A revenue that might come from mergers we've closed here the fourth quarter. But please remember to assume a mid-quarter closing date. 
Following these steps should help you from over- or undershooting on revenues and avoid the related EPS impact. 
Okay, moving to margins. Adjusted brokerage EBITDAC margin expanded 20 basis points in the quarter. We continue to get some margin uplift from our international operations, but overall margin expansion was a bit muted because we had some adverse domestic medical plan experience in the quarter, cost us about 20 basis points. It's unfortunate but does happen from time to time. 
Looking towards the fourth quarter, if we hit 3% organic, and I'm not saying we will or we won't, we could hold margins flat with last year's fourth quarter or even squeak out a little expansion. 
As for the Risk Management segment, margin of 16.8% was right in line with our expectations that we shared with you at our investor meeting in September. This is really great work by the team. 
With a return to low single-digit organic in the fourth quarter, we seen margins in the lower 17% range. 
Next, let's move to integration. We're nearly finished. We're about done combining the 4 large acquisitions we did in the U.K. You can see it in the numbers. 
Third quarter integration costs were $0.04 this year versus $0.10 last year. And in the CFO commentary document, you'll see our fourth quarter estimates are -- for integration are at about $0.03, also down from $0.10 in the fourth quarter 2015. 
I'll be back in London in a couple of weeks and I look forward to congratulating the team for a really, really terrific effort over this last year. 
And also, I should -- deserves mentioning, too. Our Canadian merger is also substantially complete with their integration efforts. So it's really nice work to those folks up in Canada, too. 
Moving next to clean energy. We heard Pat say that we had another excellent third quarter, and we remain on track to deliver about 15% earnings growth over last year. Warmer weather helped us beat our forecast in the third quarter, but production might me a little lower in the fourth quarter because we haven't seen much cold weather yet. 
For example, you'll see that there's still a lot of green in the ivy at Wrigley tonight. And don't forget that our production has not only reduced our current year taxes, but we have also generated $430 million of credit that are sitting in our balance sheet. Effectively, that's a $430 million receivable from the government that will help us reduce our cash taxes paid for many, many years. We believe this has meaningful value for the shareholders. 
We also have about $230 million of available cash on our balance sheet. And as I've commented on before, we're making really good progress on our bank account consolidation efforts that help us unlock available cash. 
So looking forward, you heard Pat say that our M&A pipeline is strong. We've got nice cash and nice cash flows developing. So I think that we can fund our activity for the remainder -- our M&A activity for the remainder of this year with cash and debt. 
As for 2017, I see even stronger cash flows, given integration will be behind us, and we won't have real estate moves that we had this year either. So we should be well positioned in 2017 to continue funding M&A with free cash and debt. 
So those are my comments and another great quarter and an excellent first 9 months of the year. Back to you, Pat.

componenttext: Yes. We're seeing -- we are seeing some claim volume growth, but it's not as strong as it was a year ago. We're about -- we're seeing about 1 -- about 1% growth in claims value -- volume or claims activity down from probably 2%, 2.5% at this time last year.

componenttext: The benefit segment sounds like you had good growth. I think you said 5%. Any update on -- of the exchange -- the additional help that a client need? Just some more detail there would be good.

headline: Arthur J Gallagher & Co., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, sure. I've said this many times. Personally, I was not in favor for our country to -- I was not a proponent of ObamaCare. But for our company, it's been the greatest thing in the world. So it's helped our merger and acquisition activity, and it's a v
componenttext: Yes, sure. I've said this many times. Personally, I was not in favor for our country to -- I was not a proponent of ObamaCare. But for our company, it's been the greatest thing in the world. So it's helped our merger and acquisition activity, and it's a very, very complicated act. And what that does is create an awful lot of consulting opportunities for us. Our clients need a lot of help. The exchange is one of the things that we help our clients take a look at as they decide how they're going to treat their employee base. We look at the -- we look really at what we're doing from a consulting standpoint as a view of the total rewards that a client is going to use to maintain the employment of their best people. Really, when you come down to it, every business is all about people. And so you have to look at the entire list of benefits that you're going to provide and then figure out how you're going to actually work to health insurance into that. So exchange is popular. We've got probably about 15% of our clients out there taking a serious look at our exchange. And the rest are going to treat their insurance in a more traditional manner.

headline: Arthur J Gallagher & Co., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, domestically, we seeing a pretty stable market, which has been a stable market now for about 5 years, which is pretty unusual in my career. And I think it's a very good thing for our clients. The past is hard and soft market cycle that we lived thro
componenttext: Well, domestically, we seeing a pretty stable market, which has been a stable market now for about 5 years, which is pretty unusual in my career. And I think it's a very good thing for our clients. The past is hard and soft market cycle that we lived through for the last literally 40 years, that doesn't benefit plans at all. So today, we've got a stable market domestically, a softer market internationally. So what I see is continued international, 1% to 2% organic, and hopefully, closer to 4% to 5% domestically.
